description:
What if I just kept on walking, what if I decided not to check this place out?
But I did! And now I keep coming back there every time I get a chance.
The food is out of this world!!! Wine selection is perfect. 
I wish they made outside area more comfortable. Maybe they already did... I have to come back and check!
author: Mariya Delilah D.

description:
This was one of the most disappointing experiences I've had in a while, at any restaurant in any city. It's a particular shame, because this place is right around the corner and could easily be our local go to spot.

When you first walk in, the restaurant smells like bleach or cleaning product. I guess it's good to know they clean the place, but the smell is overwhelming and a real turn off.

We were given a table for four in the corner, and the server - who is very friendly but not particularly intuitive to guests needs - started rattling off the specials before my mother could even put down her bag. By the time she was settled into her seat, he was done listing the specials and asked if we needed some time. It all felt overwhelming and we couldn't tell if he was just over eager or in a rush.

Unfortunately, it just got worse from there. The food was absolutely atrocious, there's simply no other word for it. I had the Moules Marinières and I think I ate 5 mussels before I set the dish aside. You know the funky flavor that mussels have when they're off? Every single mussel tasted like that. As did the sauce they were cooked in. I noticed it on the first one, but sometimes that happens and you get one that's a little funky. Literally every single one tasted disgusting. I'm rarely so harsh in reviews, but there is simply no other word for it. Thankfully, the fries that I ordered on the side where delicious so that was my meal. When the waiter cleared my plate, it was clear that I had barely touch the mussels, but he didn't seem to notice, or didn't think to ask.

My mother ordered the Bouillabaise. It was really fishy, because they used salmon instead of a traditional white fish. It was edible, but definitely not good. Maybe a C-. My husband ordered the duck breast. It was cooked properly, but came with a sticky, sickly sweet sauce that covered the entire plate and made the whole dish taste almost like dessert. There was absolutely no finesse to the dish, it looked and tasted like an amateur chef from the 80s was making it. Again, edible but not at all good. A C would be generous. My mother-in-law had the beef cheeks. The flavor was bland, but at least not bad like the other 3, but the meat was so dry it made me sad to see a beautiful protein cooked in that way. She thought they were OK, because she's never had them before, but I really really wanted to go back and cook them all over again and do that beautiful piece of meat some justice. 

The three of them also ordered starters, he soup which was very bland and a citrus salad which was good but overdressed. 

The salt in the wound, is that we walked out spending $250. My husband and I are foodies, our moms are not, and all four of us thought the food was pretty awful. There's no way we would have gone back even if we had spent half that much, but spending $250 on a dinner that required me to go brush my teeth immediately afterwards to get the taste out of my mouth was really awful.

I hate to bash local restaurants, because I really want to see them thrive, but I recommend you stay far, far away from this place. It really is quite awful.
author: Rebecca W.

description: Excellent food and excellent service. Their meats are really good. The desserts are worth it too. I can't wait to come back
author: Sara-Fleur S.

description:
Last day of four day work trip and after missing my flight home found this casual french restaurant on Yelp.  Solo at the the bar which was nice, friendly staff and enough room to relax. 

Enjoyed the classic duck confit. It is served over a hearty lentil, tomato & sausage.  Hit the spot.  The duck breast another diner was eating looked real good too.  The soup to start and lemon tart were also good.

Really good Gerard Bertrand pink sparkling wine to start and ok Russian Riv Pinot with main course. 

Parking tip.... parking is a challenge for visitors in this SF neighborhood.  I found a bus zone two blocks on Central that had no parking signs (fine print was until 6pm).  I asked a local and he said it was fine outside of the hours. Several spots were wide open as signs are not very clear and it was 6:45ish.
author: Bret B.

description:
Back here after almost 3 years, and this time for dinner.
I have to say that I was totally mesmerized by the lights on the ceiling.
It gives the whole place such a great, romantic, look. Really beautiful.
The absolute winner of the night was risotto and scallops. 
Fantastic flavors, scallops done to perfection.
Escargots were great, endive salad very tasty.
All other dishes that we had were good. 
There are few dishes that are missing a bit of flavor, like sweet breads, and fish on the special was a bit dry. 
We took almost every dessert on the menu.
All of them were great. Really beautiful presentation.
Very casual atmosphere, and not so easy to find a parking on Saturday evening.
Overall, nice atmosphere, good service, and good food.
author: Bianca G.

description: Really boring place with unexciting menu and service. No wonder it was totally empty on Saturday brunch. Would be surprised if it is much different at night.
author: Cawa B.

description:
We tried out this place for New Years and I was a bit underwhelmed. All of the dishes sounded amazing, looked amazing, but they just needed something else. I ordered the chicken and it tasted very healthy but it had no extra pizzazz or flavor. It just tasted like chicken cooked in chicken stock. The dessert was the best part, but honestly there was not enough intrigue for me to return.

The staff was excellent and so was the service!
author: Larissa S.

description:
Worst brunch ever.  Incredibly disappointing, low quality, exorbitantly high prices for such low quality and flavor.  My fault though--I should have known by the ease in making a reservation the day before, and my husband and I literally being the first customers to the restaurant on Sunday at 10am.

$17 French Toast--two slices of thin but decent french toast...but what kills me is that they had the audacity to accompany it with previously frozen fruit.  See pictures of how translucent that small spoonful of fruit is.  I'm fine with paying higher prices for quality--but this dish left me feeling extremely ripped off and wronged.

$19 Croque Madame--menu says pan de mie, however the minimal size was that of loaf white bread from the market, and slices were thin.  Bechamel was barely there.  I don't cook, but I would have been better off making a ham and cheese sandwich on my own.

Seriously--PASS on this place, don't waste your money here.
author: Vanessa O.

description:
Went there already two times and it's always a exceptional experience. It starts with the interior that is not too fancy but has a good style. The staff and especially the waiters are soooo nice and helping out with wine recommendations that are on point!
The biggest selling point is the food, it is so delicious I can't even describe it. 
I had the Rossini and the moment i took the first bite I smiled and was happy. This food literally makes happy.
The only downside is a little smell when you pass by the kitchen to the bathroom. I guess the garbage is close somewhere there. But this is really the only downside.
For a good Dinner for 2 person with Wine and dessert you'll pay ~$150. It's worth every Penny.
author: Leonard S.

description: This little French bistro is a gem in the City. Really good dining value for the great food and friendly service. Nothing fancy here, just simple French bistro fare all done well. Everything on the menu is consistently delicious and presented without pretense. The food here is really meant to be eaten and enjoyed. One bite will easily lead to the next with comfort. My friends and I are totally satisfied here every time. The service staff are totally down to earth. This is a place where one can feel at ease and enjoy a lingering relaxed evening with good friends.
author: Giovani T.

description: Good service, good food! Nothing to complain about, didn't blow my socks off either. Solid 4 stars out of 5!
author: Ryan K.

description:
I had an amazing dinner here this evening!

French restaurant, French accents from the servers, and delicious items on the menu that I can't pronounce...yes!  Made a reservation on yelp to ensure we had a table.  Easy peasy.  Parking is terrible in the area so it would be best to find alternative ways to get there.  

As an appetizer, we started off with the baked brie which was served with tomatoes, roasted garlic, and bread.  A little heavy as a starter but I'm such a sucker for brie.  Delicious flavors though and I was smitten anyway.  

For our entrees, we ordered the risotto aux coquilles St. Jacques.  Basically, this was perfectly cooked risotto with lobster broth and scallops.  Delicious if you're interested in a heavier seafood dish.  Our other entree was one of the specials on the board, tournedos rossini.  Filet mignon, foie gras, and potato gratin.  My goodness...this is a must order if you come here and they happen to offer it.  Flavortown was definitely all over this plate of goodness.

We asked our server for wine recommendations and we went with a French malbec and a French chardonnay.  Perfect pairings with our meals.  

If I had to mention one negative, it would be the dessert we ordered, basically a chocolate lava cake.  The flavor was quite mild for a lava cake which should be rich with chocolate flavors.  The ice cream and what appeared to be some sort of praline disc was amazing though.  

Server was on point as he was thorough and extremely helpful.  I love this spot and can't wait to return again.
author: Jen W.

description:
Things have changed and so have my feelings. 

I'm still warmly greeted but no longer with a hug and kiss.
The menu is similar but the food that I'm eating is not the same. 
The wine list is totally not what it once was.
The prices are what they were but I'm not licking sauce off my plate or counting the days until my return. 

We ordered the Rossini, Filet Mignon, and a fish special. Except for the fish, the meats were disappointing and weirdly flavorless. The sauce, which I was previously a massive fan of (Bistro Central Parc is where I became a sauce convert) was a watered down version of what it once was. Where it once complemented the meat, it was now it's sole source of flavor. Luckily, we were sharing mains, and we all enjoyed the fish. But 1/3 isn't good math for us. We ate in sad silence, later acknowledging that this was probably the last time we'd come here.

The service was great. It's still a great location for a lovely day strolling through the Panhandle. The fish was good. But we miss the old version :'(
author: Loli L.

description:
Made reservation for Feb 14. Total let down.

- made to wait for 45 min even with a reservation
- finally seated in the cold outside in the sidewalk on a cheap metal table. Manager refused to seat us indoors even when told we could wait. We're here for the ambiance and the seating outside is clearly an afterthought.
- wind curtain isn't even down all the way! Pretty chilly ankles while writing this. Lady next to me has a jacket wrapped around her legs.
- 1.2 hours later, two slices of bread were tossed at us by some guy who sounded like he was about to have a breakdown.

Still haven't received food yet and not sure I really want to at this point.
author: Vinod C.

description: A really cozy neighborhood restaurant that provides hearty and delicious food and intimate service
author: Gretchen J.

description:
This looked like the perfect Valentine's Day restaurant when I booked six weeks in advance.

Little did I know.

I arrived on time, and couldn't make it in the door because there were so many people waiting to be seated. I felt like I was on one of those overbooked United flights where they were about to ask for volunteers to get off the plane. The hostess was completely overwhelmed by it all, and it was 30 minutes before we were seated. They had packed in the tables so tightly that the waitstaff couldn't make it to our table properly, and so the diner beside us had to sit at a right angle for the waitstaff (and other guests) to get past. It was another 20 minutes for them to take our order. And while the appetizers didn't take too long, it was 90 minutes into dinner before our mains finally appeared.

The food wasn't bad, but it'd have to have been extraordinary to make up for the restaurant's greed in completely booking themselves out like this -- and being shortstaffed with only one hostess and two waiters for Valentine's Day. Snails were ok, soup was bland; the mains of the lamb and the salmon pie definitely redeemed things but who knows? I was so hungry at that point that anything would have tasted good.

A truly disappointing experience: think a French version of United and you're not too far off.
author: James A.

description: Found this place on a whim Saturday evening and walked in for dinner. They were fully booked but had walk-in availability at their bar. Really cute spot, great ambiance and excellent service. Had an appetizer, duck confit, and split a half bottle of bordeaux. Cute for date nights!
author: Wei W.

description:
1/8/17:  What can I say?--this is a prime example of sub-average food for hyper-inflated prices.  Make it the place look great.  Make it hipster.  Make people pay the hipster pricing.  All it's missing is the 2 word adjective-noun name.  That's the formula--then as long as the food ain't utter crap, money will be made!

Well, first of, for those who have been to France, you would know there is no such thing as a French meal, be it breakfast, lunch, or dinner, without bread served first.  Period.  Never.  (Well, unless we're talking eating at McDonald's.)  So guess what?--they never gave us table bread.  Maybe that sounds silly to us Americans, but I'm pretty sure that's a crazy huge deal if committed in France.

Alright.... so.... that's kinda how it went...

1. Coffee $4.50:  It's bitter without body.  I guess it would have been okay, but for four and a half bucks?--hell no.  3/10

2. Baked Brie $16 "roasted garlic, concasse of tomatoes":  I was absolutely stunned when I saw this in front of us.  Like, where's the cheese!?!?  Most of us have had baked brie before right?--big round of cheese oozing from the white outer crust, often breaded?  Well, the cheese was totally an after thought.  They just basically put a quarter of a round of brie, possibly microwaved, cause the crust was all broken and dry--just plopped there.  Got some tomatoes and bread, which both were good.  But the cheese... wow... amazingly amateur.  2/10

3. Soupe a l'Oignon $14 "traditional French onion soup":  You know, like most of us I've had dozens of these over the years.  Many from straight-up American restaurants, some from fancy schmancy French places too, and of all of them this might be the worst I've ever had.  The onions were so pulverized they were just a pile of mush on the bottom.  The bread was completely mushed too.  The soup was pretty flavorless.  Crap.  2/10

4. Moules Marinieres $20 "white wine, shallots, parsley and cream":  Alright, things were looking better now.  The mussels, though pretty small, were very juicy and tender.  The sauce/soup was pretty good too.  Creamy and tasty.  The bread they served it with though just ruined it.  Like cheapo stale bread a day old from the supermarket.  Again, if you've been to France, you know how seriously they take their bread.  This ain't French bread.  Trust me.  5/10

5. Confit de Canard $25 "lentils and lardon":  I think this is their super specialty.  I'd have to admit, the duck itself is probably one of the best duck confits I've had.  The texture is perfect without the meat completely falling apart.  Skin was crispy and very savory.  Great.  The lentil thing I didn't like though.  I do not know if it's traditional or what, but it tasted a lot like the Chinese green bean soup my mom used to make, without the sugar.  Just ain't great.  But if it weren't for that, would have been pretty dang good.  8/10

6. Profiteroles $9:  Straight up--they took bought some puffs from the store, gave them to some kids to stuff with ice cream and top with chocolate and nuts.  I'd guess 7 year olds.  Tastes fine, but just a total mess.  Check out my pics.  3/10

If you wanna blow a ton of money, and at the same time gain a few thousand calories of nice waistline.... have at it.

2/5

#french #sanfrancisco
author: Dean C.

description: Food was mediocre at best, but the service was the absolute worst. The men that work in the kitchen are kind and super helpful, but the waitress is one of the worst I've seen yet.
author: Tasha R.

description:
I used to absolutely love this place.  But it changed ownership a couple of years ago and has lost a good deal of its appeal. First of all, no one wants to smell cleaning fluid throughout their dining experience.  It's gross to begin with, messes with your sense of smell/taste, and ruins everything.  And that is the first impression.  It hits you as you walk in and never leaves until you walk out.  Yuck.  Second, a big part of the experience is the service.  I would say it is perfunctory at best, and lacks the warmth and charm it had under the former owners.  Lastly, the food is ok/fine, but not finely done as it used to be; it just seems like the kitchen staff are tired of putting out the same food night after night -- like there is no heart in the preparation anymore.  Sigh.  So sad.  Its off my list now.
ps -- the music selection is strange too.  Really out of sync with what the vibe used to be.
author: Catherine N.

description:
Sadly, almost five years later my five stars have gone to two. I live in the neighborhood and this was my husband and my go-to place to eat outside with our dog.

The restaurant changed ownership about two years ago and it's just not the same place. The positive is the wait staff is very nice and the food for the most part is good.

The negative is the food has become outrageously over priced. A few months back I ordered an egg white omelet with cheese, spinach, and mushrooms and it was $22. Eggs Benedict are now $16. The dinner entrees and wine are all way over priced.

We kept coming back because we used to love this place but last night was our last time. I ordered a salad that was on the daily special. Given how over priced everything is, I should have known to ask how much. The salad consisted of some lettuce, four segments of grilled artichoke, a few pieces of broccoli, carrots, and cauliflower. We get our bill and could not believe that they had the audacity to charge $30. Seriously? $30 for a measly salad!

The restaurant is almost empty on Friday and Saturday nights these days. Goodbye and RIP Bistro Central Parc. We'll remember the good old days when Jacques owned and ran the place.
author: Teri M.

description: Awesome food, good energy, and a great experience. This place never disappoints. I've been here several times for dinner and twice for brunch.
author: Janell F.

description:
Firstly, I don't particularly like or seek out French food but decided to check this place out per friend's recommendations. 

- Beef tartare: 2/5 didn't particularly enjoy this. More visually appealing than the actual taste. The salad had a weird dressing on it and the beef also had a similar dressing, with a sour tinge. The salad and beef definitely taste better separately. Just personally wasn't one of my favorites. 

- Curry mussels: 3/5 couldn't really taste the curry flavor and the broth was too creamy and weighed down the flavor of the mussels. It may be just personal taste, but I enjoy my mussels to be a little lighter tasting. 

- French fries: can't even give this thing a score. They were just French fries. The guy really sold us on it, saying we should dip the fries into the mussel broth for an amazing experience but it was honestly just a "meh" combination. Didn't add much to the fries and the mussel broth couldn't sufficiently cling onto the fries. Would pass on this for sure. Totally overpriced at $7/serving 

- Rossini: filet mignon, foie gras, potato. 4.5/5 Very good but very rich. So rich that I wasn't sure if we could finish it. All together, a good flavor combination. 

- Beef cheek: 5/5 favorite dish. The beef cheek is fork tender and delicious with the underlying beet purée. Little stumps of potatoes that cake with it also very tasty. The cheek, the mushrooms, and the beet sauce really work well together, to create a tasty complete bite. 

- service: 1 person seating people and 1 waiter. Not enough man power and therefore, things were missed. For example, water not refilled, the fries not delivered until we asked for them. Took a while to get the check. Etc. But overall, acceptable and no significant problems since the staff was nice when they did come by. 

Overall, this restaurant had French food with a little more flavor than usual (everything was a bit more sour than usual-- but not necessarily in a bad way). But a disclaimer that I'm not a French food connoisseur, so this review is more so of my opinions on how the food simply tasted to me and my taste palate.
author: J P.

description:
I found my favorite French restaurant in the city - and it's in my hood.  Probably a good thing - because the first time we came here - we ate WAY too much, so the wall home was welcomed!  The French onion soup was full of flavor - so delicious!  The mussels were cooked to perfection and sauce they were cooked in was delicious- light cream / wine / butter - can't really go wrong!  
We shared the risotto and scallops - I loved the presentation at the table and it was so good.
Of course - at this point - we were full - but the dessert menu was too tempting !  Profiteroles !the very best profiteroles I have EVER had! 
The choux was fresh and crunchy, ice cream inside was delish and the chocolate sauce with crunchy slivered almonds made the dish. 
We are definitely returning soon!
author: Nicole C.

description: What a comfy restaurant and luv the ceiling lightings. Romantic and homie, feels like a warm welcoming dinner setting. My gfs bday celebration here with a party of nine. Sat us right in front by entrance and window. I did not taste the food but the girls said the steak with foie gras and duck confit were yummy. Servers brought out several pretty desserts, prepared candles and sang birthday song with us. Kindly assist with fotos taking with no hesitation. Awesome attitude, thanku!
author: Vee V.

description: Trying out a new place with my bf and a friend..it was a quiet Saturday morning and I actually never seen or heard this quiet neighborhood restaurant,definitely good for breakfast/brunch..I'll definitely have to try dinner here as well,minus one star for the service although friendly slightly pushy
author: jonathan h.

description: The food and service was excellent. I love the light on the ceiling it is like you are looking up to a forest with the night sky (see photo). It kind of makes you think you are eating outside. The French onion soup and mussels are a must as an appetizer. Then check out the specials as you can't go wrong with any of them.
author: Vanessa B.

description: I like these place. Stable quality never disappoint me. Don't have a lot of food choice. Their service is pretty good
author: Johnny L.

description:
We came here with a reservation for dinner on a Wednesday night. Not too busy so we were promptly seated. There's also bar and outdoor seating.

Loved the appetizers! The heirloom tomato salad special was light and refreshing though the polenta could be better seasoned or omitted. Big fans of the risotto with its super flavorful, slightly garlicky mushrooms. 

The duck breast entrée was tasty. Bloody meat is not my thing so I ordered it medium. It was a tad more cooked than expected so I'll go with medium-rare next time. The potatoes and bacon were yummy and filled me up.

The bf had the sea bass special. The mango garnish was a very nice touch.

For dessert, we shared a pretty looking tarte tatin since we were full by this point. Not the best option for people who don't like warm cooked apple but the pastry was good.

Overall, Bistro Central Parc is a solid option for a nice dinner.  Tasty and filling food.  Good service.  Not so busy on weekdays that reservations are required.  Biggest con is probably that parking spots are hard to come by.
author: Venna L.

description:
Was nearby for an urban hike one evening and decided to stop in for a late birthday dinner celebration with the wife and in-laws.

Among the four of us, we had the French onion soup (looked amazing, tasted good) and the baked brie with roasted garlic (the garlic was amazing!) as appetizers. Everyone had the petrale sole entree except me, and I opted for the filet mignon special with seared foie gras. While everything was good, I was jealous of everyone who had ordered the fish, as my own particular entree surpassed "good" but never quite made it to "mouthgasm." The petrale sole definitely made a better showing, but it was still not quite anything to phone home about.

For desserts, we split a crème brulée and an apple tart. Both good, but I've definitely done better for $9 a piece.

All told it was a very competent and would be good for a romantic dinner for two if you don't mind it being a little on the pricey side.

Recommendations: Baked Brie, Poisson du Jour (fish of the day, ours was petrale sole AKA flounder)
Avoid: N/A
author: Torrey W.

description: What a great place. The food and the service is amazing. David was in charge of our table and he did a great Job. I will definitely come back.
author: Pablo V.

description: Homey French recipes - American portion size- warm atmosphere at reasonable price.  Reservation recommended - even though I had no problem switching the time on a busy Saturday night- 4/20 to be precise!    Group of four went there for dinner, the place was semi full, the yellowish lighting gave it a warm feeling.  Great wine list- ordered 2 bottles of Ecole Bordeaux - Pomerol one of the best in that area.  We ordered Endive and pear salad, gem salad and muscles (in a light cream lemony sauce). All tasted great.  For our entree 2 of us settled for Beef Cheek (highly recommended), Bouillabaisse which is a seafood stew and Roasted chicken and vegetable.  The seafood was amazingly fresh, you could just smell the freshness out of the plate.  The beef cheeks would just fall apart with a touch of fork and chicken and vegetable was prepared as healthy as our picky eater ordered. At the end, we were all happy.   Go there with a reservation, good company and hungry!
author: Megan K.

description: I haver no words to accurately describe how truly amazing this restaurant is.  It was love at first bite, my husband and I were only in town for four days but dined here three times after our first visit.  EVERY SINGLE item we ordered was cooked to perfection (and we ordered A LOT).  Gina, the beautiful brunette, made each dinner even better with her conversation and patience while we showed her pictures of our four kids.  CANNOT wait until we can go back!  A few favorites: wild mushroom risotto, beef cheeks, tenderloin topped with foie gras (special order) and French onion soup (top 3 and I've tried 100+).
author: Lisa T.

description: Service here is a complete disaster. Simple breakfast items are way overpriced. Nothing particularly interesting about the food and wish we had gone to the grocery store and made some basic faire ourselves. Potatoes tasted freezer burned. Pancakes hot and cold spots throughout. Probably microwaved. Would have been better and much less stressful.  First they brought us someone else's food. Set it down for two minutes and then came back and picked it up and brought to the rightful owners. When the food did finally arrive, they missed my daughter's pancakes.  Nothing like having mediocre food be served to your table while your child sits hungry. I had to chase someone down to get my bill. Then I waved and waved and finally had to walk up to the counter and pay.  This is the first time I've never left a tip. You would do well to eat anywhere else.
author: Brian D.

description:
I made reservations at this restaurant for Valentine's Day, and it was God awful experience. The worst experience I have had at a restaurant. They overbooked and did not have enough tables! so they put a bunch of tables outside on the concrete. We sat inside a dirty, old, ragged tent. It was disgusting. Many couples who made reservations at this restaurant walked out and left. Really sad to see so many people looking forward to a simple VDay dinner have their night upset. 

I made a yelp account just to write this review. if you are thinking about coming here please think again. This restaurant's greed will get the best of you-- they do not care about your experience and will not hesitate to serve you food out in the cold.
author: Jesse C.

description:
Food is just ok. Prices are too expensive. The location is sort of secluded. It's like a mirror of San Francisco. Wishing it could be great, but too expensive to be genuine. Not trying to knock the city though, as I love it so much. But I would probably pass on this restaurant.

We ordered the fillet mignon and the scallop risotto. Risotto was earthy and fishy. Fillet mignon had a weird sweetness because the sauce was overpowering. The roasted foie gras, however, was really decadent. 

Service is great, but why go to a restaurant for just the service?
author: Anthony G.

description:
Talk about a typical French enriched meal!

From the service to the actual dining you get exactly what you came here for...The French!

Excellent recommendations and offerings.

We opted for the Brie appetizer which I can see why some may not appreciate it because of the size but I thought it was perfect for the two of us.

We also got the filet mignon with foie gras and scallops with risotto. Both excellent choices. The sauce was a little too rich for my blood on the steak, but still delicious and the scallops were cooked perfectly and balanced everything out.

The dessert was actually a bit of a bummer. A chocolate lava cake that didn't ooze out like it should. It was warm/cold even and just left little to be desired. Perhaps we should've skipped dessert. 

All in all a great corner neighborhood restaurant and I look forward to coming back.
author: Guisela L.

description:
I am almost afraid to rave about this hidden gem for fear that everyone will want to go and I'll never be able to get in again!  Authentic French cuisine, fabulous specials, diverse wine list, attentive staff and reasonable prices.  All in a cozy, perfectly lit warm atmosphere.   And let's not forget that fabulous art installation on the ceiling!
Escargots. Coquille St. Jacques, duck confit and sole meunière are but a few of their delectable offerings.   Check it out: they even have an outdoor patio when whether permits.    Bring yourself and those you want to impress!   "I'll be back!"
author: Doug W.

description:
Decent place to go and easy to get reservations. Our waiter was French so made the place feel more authentic haha.

Our favourite dish were the sweet breads and escargot. I loveeee garlic so the escargot was perfect, lots of parsley and lots of garlic. 

We also had the duck leg and beef tartare, which were average.
author: Rohenne L.

description:
I've been heartsick for French food after eating well in Lyon, Nice, Bourgogne, etc. during a couple of years abroad. i didn't have high hopes beyond a decent fix for my craving. I had a tough time deciding among all the French restos in NoPa and Hayes Valley, especially as they have similar menus. I knew we chose the right place when I called to make reservations and the hostess (or manager? Seems like she is very hands-on with the business) offered seating "on the terrasse".

The pictures alone should win you over. The presentation was just as gorgeous in real life. Every dish that passed by our table caught my eye. Though the specials sounded fresh and well-thought out, i had to have the baked brie, braised beef cheeks with red beet sauce, scallop risotto with a lobster bisque base, and creme brulee. It may look like smaller than the American average, but the richness of each dish will satisfy you. I would have been uncomfortably full if we had gotten any more than that, between the two of us. 

The dishes came out in good time; our server was efficient and attentive, without  interrupting our conversation. The bistro feels intimate and unpretentious - but is rather loud at dinnertime on a Saturday inside, so I'm glad we were outside (with heaters, if Karl worries you). I unfortunately could not allow myself to eat here too frequently, but the prices are fair by being comparable to other French restaurants. I would love to go back for special dinners in the future.

PS: i was able to make a reservation the day of. Even if it is only a couple of hours ahead, make the call. We saw groups waiting outside for a table when we left around 8 pm.
author: Cat N.

description:
Came here with a party of 7 for my girlfriend's birthday. I was last to arrive, but we weren't given menus until we had to ask =/ We started off with a bottle of Riesling to share and dove into our appetizers. Everything came out at once so our table was packed! I enjoyed the entrees a lot more than the appetizers.

Appetizers:
- (2) French onion soup: One of my more favored appetizers. I liked the cheese and soup with plentiful onions - the soup wasn't too salty as most spots make, but this one had a good savory level.
- (2) American Kobe-style Beef Tartare: The tartare was a little bit too relish-y tasting for me, but my friends enjoyed it a lot. The ones I had in Paris were never this masked in pickled flavor, so they made it a little too overpowering.
- (2) escargots: Wayyyy too salty, which completely masked the taste of the snails itself :(
- Classic Moules Marinieres (mussels): mussels were a little on the fishy/unfresh side, but my friends & I enjoyed the sauce it came with to dip our super hard complimentary breads.
- (2) Baked Brie: My favorite of this dish was the brie and the roasted garlic - this ranks second on my more favored appetizers. The way we got to pull out each clove from the garlic was satisfying and unique too. The bread also went well with the cheese.

Entrees:
- Steak Frites: The meat and sauce was cooked perfectly with the potato layers underneath. I enjoyed this dish and would order again.
- Risotto aux Coquilles St. Jacques (risotto with lobster sauce & scallops): I was also a fan of this scallop dish, however the risotto was a little on the harder/uncooked side. Flavor of the lobster in the risotto alone would make me order this dish again though.
- Carre d'Agneau (lamb): I am not a lamb fan, but my friends really liked it. I tried a small bite and it was indeed a lot less gamey-flavored than most lamb people tell me to try. They super enjoyed it.
- (2) Pomme Frites (+ truffle oil for $2): We originally ordered 1 of these, but the truffle oil on them were so delicious, we ordered a second one because 1 was not enough to share among 7 ladies.

Desserts:
- Creme Brulee: Not too sweet, but prefer a thinner layer of sugar on top. Would order again though, because I love creme brulee and I have yet to encounter a one I hate.
- Ice cream puffs: The combination of the thin puff, ice cream and dark chocolate really worked for me - I liked it and would order again.
- strawberry puree: This was one of least favorite due to the sour strawberries. It was warm with ice cream on top, if the strawberries were sweeter, I think we would have liked a lot more.
- lemon tart (daily special): the thickness of the lemon part was so delicious - i really enjoyed the texture and piece of tart at the bottom. I would order this again if it was on the menu.

Overall, decent restaurant, but not completely impressed with the food. The service picked up after they forgot to provide us menus. The birthday girl got a special glass of bubbly with surprise singing with the restaurant lights turned off by the workers just for her! Good, but nothing outstanding for me to want to return.
author: Amanda C.

description:
Totally standard neighborhood place. Went for Brunch.

Eggs benedict and eggs florentine: ok. buttery hollandaise. Great diced potatoes. mustardy dressing on lettuce wasn't great.

Perfectly mediocre. Nothing truly bad or wrong but nothing amazing about it or reason to ever go back.
author: Ryan B.

description:
Average service, steak tartare was a little too sweet and wet. NY strip steaks were mediocre quality and slightly over cooked.
Won't repeat.
author: Bert V.

description:
We were really impressed with the quality and consistency of the food here! 

Fresh ingredients, solid preparation, beautiful but unfussy presentation AND generous portions! I'd say Bistro Central Parc is excellent value for money, wonderful for a date night or for out-of-towners staying locally.
author: Nina N.

description: Damn. Everything was exceptionally delicious. Scallops. Onion soup. Filet. Brie. Top notch. Pricey, but worth it for a date night.
author: Justin S.

description:
Great service and specials during dinner service.

Delicious, rich food, beautifully plated. Stuffed bellies. 

Casual, relaxed atmosphere so I can wear comfortable clothing next time while stuffing my face. 

Wine was also delicious. Great in-house sommelier.

Fulfilled my gluttonous fantasy for the month. Hope to be back sooner than later!
author: jolie L.

description: Finally.  An authentic French restaurant in San Francisco [in the North Panhandle neighborhood by Golden Gate Park]. My daughter ordered the petrale sole with capers, green beans and roasted potatoes, while I ordered the filet mignon with fois gras.  The deserts were awesome Crème Brûlée and Chocolate Lava Cake.  The bread was excellent and the staff was predominately French and the prices were reasonable.  After living in France for three years in my twenties during which I worked in restaurants and attended the Sorbonne for two years, it is such a joy to find this jewel in the City that is unpretentious, reasonably priced and serves excellent French food.  So nice to find a bit of France in San Francisco.
author: A. T.

description: My favorite part about this place is their exceptional and friendly staff. They make great recommendations and we're always treated like family. It's a very nice ambience and my girlfriend always mentions how cute the place is inside or out. The food is always perfectly cooked and everything I've had on the menu is excellent, especially the filet mignon that's served as a tower with au gratin potatoes underneath and foie gras on top with a few truffles (better than any steakhouse I've been to). Their wine is awesome, the dessert is awesome, it's a great date spot, and nobody knows about it! Always a table ready for us. I think this place is a hidden gem in San Francisco and only write this review because I like the owner Gina so much who's always here to greet me. Otherwise I'd keep it all to myself.
author: Casey C.

description: Best food, service and presentation I've experienced in a long time. Thank you for making our night special.
author: Vita V.

description: All restaurants have occasional off nights, but we came here two weeks ago, a group of four adults who live within walking distance and like good food and wine. The service was slightly quirky (confusion about when  one could order duck confit) but friendly. We shared salmon tartare and endive salad for appetizers, had beef cheeks and steak frites as our mains, and three desserts. Everything was cooked, or not, as ordered, full of flavor, and attractively presented. Rebecca W's review had made me nervous, but we experienced no weird smells of cleaning products or questionable food. It was not cheap, but not out of line for this type of food and wine in San Francisco.
author: Susie L.

description: Last night we tried Bistro Central Parc for the first time and we will be back there again! From the moment we arrived, we were greeted by a lovely women who showed us to our table. The service was outstanding and the food was delicious. We started with the frissee, lardon salad with a poached egg on top and it was simply fantastic! Our entrees were the steak frites which had an amazing flavour from the marrow butter. The other entree was the petralesole which was simply prepared with butter white wine and capers. The fish was so fresh and perfectly cooked. We cannot wait to go back here again.
author: Robert A.

description:
Fantastic all around.

My friend and I came on a Tuesday night before attending a concert in the neighborhood. The restaurant wasn't too crowded, and although we made a reservation in advance, we probably didn't need it. The wait staff was exceptionally friendly to my friend and I when we arrived. One of the owners is actually from the same region in France as my friend. It's a small world, isn't it?! They treated us very well over the course of our dinner. 

We both ordered the fish of the night: sole with roasted potatoes and green beans. The fish was very good, but the potatoes were a little salty for our taste. My friend previously ordered the duck and thought it was cooked perfectly! Although the fish was good, I may have to order that next time. We also shared an amazing dessert of roasted strawberries with balsamic, black pepper, caramel, and vanilla ice cream. If you read this in advance, order the strawberries!! It was very unique and the flavor combination was delicious. 

I highly recommend diverting from the usual restaurants on Divisidero and trying Bistro Central Parc. It's a very nice neighborhood restaurant with exceptionally prepared French food. I have a few friends living in the neighborhood, so you bet we'll return soon!
author: Rachel S.

description:
I've been here a few times and have always walked away (with my belly) content and enriched. 

This restaurant is tucked in NoPa neighborhood and like most of SF - parking sucks but that's kinda given when you see a restaurant located in popular neighborhoods like this.

We've always experienced a warm welcome from the owner, as the restaurant is small with simple modern decor. Waiters can range from super bougie douche to a kind of relaxed bougie douche (such a big difference right?) I wouldn't expect anything less from a French restaurant, but a sense of bougie douche-ness altogether.

Regardless of the waiter, the food is what I'm really here for:

(1) Escargot - drowned in a heavy amount of butter and parsley (which is prob the only way I'd eat snails = drowned in butter) were delicious little suckers.

(2) Mussels (Moules Marinieres) - light, succulent, and tasty. Definitely one of my favorites here.

(3) Ratatouille - side dish we got as an appetizer was definitely my least favorite. It was just a little too soggy and mushy for my texture palate. 

(4) Kobe Beef Tartare - was pure Amazing! So much I didn't even get a picture! The first thing to come out for a group of hangry beings, therefore devoured without mercy. 

(5) Scallop Risotto (Risotto Aux Coquilles St Jacques) - super rich but creamy heaven. My scallops were cooked perfectly. The lobster sauce and rich risotto came together well. 

(6) Profiteroles -  puffy deliciously filled with vanilla ice cream, then topped with rich chocolate and almond. I don't really like sweets, but this was something special.
author: Saleen L.

description: How did this place receive near 5 star is beyond me, came here for Valentine's Day with a reservation and was seated outside, I came here for the ambience not the cold. Needless to say it was quite awful, from ordering food to food being served took approximately 1 hour and 45 minutes. Yes it is busy on Vday but close to 2 hours is unacceptable, and witnessing seated guests just stood up and left was quite a scene. Worse of all, the food is okay at best, cold and unappealing. Honestly I tried hard but couldn't think of anything positive, I would avoid coming here on any special occasions, chances are it will be memorable, in a bad way.
author: Alan L.

description: I'm sitting here in this restaurant on Valentine's Day and I can confidently say the day was ruined. The minute I arrived, there were at least 15 different couples who made reservations the same time as us. None of us were seated until one hour later. The worst part: we were seated outside on the sidewalk in the bitter cold in a make-shift tent. This Valentine's Day is just awful, it's like we are not even eating at a restaurant! To think we actually cancelled reservations at another place to eat here. I wish I could be anywhere but here!
author: S D.

description: Poor, unfriendly service. We asked if we could get a 1/2 portion as was offered for a similar item, and the waitress charged us pretty much full price ($2 off). She did not provide appropriate serving ware. And she was rude and made us feel that we were bothering her when asked for a spoon for granola. Cold, inappropriately cooked food - egg was so undercooked the white was runny. Overall just a bad experience. One of the worst in SF.
author: Anna R.

description: What a disappointing experience! We walked in without a reservation and asked for a table for two- the woman literally laughed in our faces as if it was a ridiculous question. She then tells us that they are booked except for two open seats at the bar and several open tables outside. So basically there were absolutely tables for two and her rude laughter was totally uncalled for... it was so off putting that despite the open spots we ended up leaving. Luckily there are plenty of good spots in the neighborhood and we caught a great meal at Barvale. Still it was really unfortunate that the hostess was rude. The manager should be aware and perhaps train the person 'greeting' their patrons to have a better attitude.
author: Claire S.

description:
One of the best meals I've had in SF and I've been to all of the top rated restaurants.  
The ambiance was perfect, it was Warm, inviting and had great energy. 
We started with a perfectly balanced cheese plate. I then had an incredible French onion soup- the best I've ever had. Followed by an amazing filet mignon - it was truly a perfect dinner.
author: Gil S.

description: We had a pretty bad Valentine's Day experience. On any other day I figure it's likely a great little restaurant but on Valentines Day we were packed in with other customers like a can of sardines and our waiter was on the computer the whole night instead of waiting on his tables. It took over a half an hour to order drinks after being seated. The hostess was nice. But we saw some drama go down where a few of the waiters were arguing and one guy eventually grabbed his belonging and stomped out of the crowded restaurant abandoning his job. When I received my soup it would have been nice to add some salt and pepper but it was dropped on our table in a rush and I didn't see the waiter again for twenty minutes so of course I had to eat the soup before it went cold. It was not a romantic Valentines Day at all, I think they got a little greedy and tried to take on more business than they could serve.
author: Doug B.

description: Bistro Parc Central has been under a new owner. Happily, Mssr. Jaque's amazing standards for delicious simplicity remain. Staff are wonderful, place is tight, loud and exciting. Everyone is always having a good time. And fois gras is no longer illegal in California, so we can now gorge on fat goose liver to our hearts extent.
author: James R.

description:
Bistro Central Parc is my favorite French restaurant! I am always amazed and wowed by the quality of food here. I don't really have a go-to dish because everything is so good. Tonight, my sisters and I ordered the following.

Baked Brie (appetizer)
Baked Brie and diced onions and tomatoes on a toasty crostinis.

Cassoulet:
This mixed meat dish consists of duck confit, lamb, sausage, all on a bed of white fava beans drenched in a delicious, creamy sauce. The duck confit, lamb, and sausage were all succulent, tender, and tasty to perfection. The lamb tasted gamely but it was not overpowering. My sister calls this plate the "Meat lovers dish." Overall, this dish was not too heavy, but just right.

Filet of sole
Although I was apprehensive of ordering fish for dinner, I was pleasantly surprised by the buttery, grilled taste of the sole. I'd say I tasted perfection! The sole rested on a bed of roasted, crisp green beans. A side of potato wedges completed this delicious, healthy cuisine.

Steak frites (French fries and steak) 
My sister claims her steak was grilled to perfection! It was very tender and the fries were crisped to perfection.

We recommend pairing your dinner with a bottle of Pouilly-Fuisee (2012) from France. It is a white wine that's good for both wine drinkers and non-wine drinkers.
author: Joanne K.

description: I enjoyed a wonderful holiday dinner with my best friend at Bistro Central Parc last night. The ambiance was romantic and beautiful. We savored the notes contained in a bottle of Pinot Noir we ordered for the table. I had the french onion soup, the cheese plate, and a filet mignon topped with goose foie gras. Every part of the meal was prepared to perfection and the service was fantastic. The owner Gina is an amazing woman and was so passionate about her business and customers. I highly recommend this place to anyone looking for a family or romantic dinner.
author: Jason J.

description: Fabulous French restaurant nestled in a SF residential neighborhood. Excellent service. Our server knew described the menu choices eloquently and made good recommendations. In fact, service was so friendly yet polished that it felt like they were friends by the time we left. The menu has a nice variety and something to please everyone. The escargot was perfect, with the right amount of garlic and butter. I haven't had such good escargot since Left Bank in San Mateo (which sadly closed years ago). The risotto with ratatouille (vegetarian) was so delicious that we did not even miss the meat.  The bouillabaisse had succulent fish and shellfish in a light broth tinged with tomatoes. The steak and pomme frites were totally consumed by the youngest teenage girl in our party. For dessert, I recommend the poached pears which come with a side of warm chocolate sauce and vanilla ice cream. Absolutely delicious. We shared a nice bottle of Bordeaux which had deep complex but smooth flavor. The coffee is freshly made and very, very strong. Even with cream. I loved the decor, especially the leaf-shaped lights in the ceiling, on a light fixture made to resemble branches with many little leaves. Breath-taking, romantic, relaxing and totally relaxing. Expensive meal but I would do it all over again and again.
author: Lucy L.

description:
Minus one star for service. A waitress hissed at us when we tried to get our waiter's attention. Okay, bitch. We were very polite to our waiter, as he deserved, so save your attitude. Also, we were barely checked on and overall didn't get the warmest vibe. 

We had beef tartare appetizers. I would have loved to split two different ones, but we didn't go that route. Oh well. Great start. The risotto with scallops and lobster sauce was excellent. The filet mignon with potato and foie gras was pretty good but didn't wow me. I had had foie gras twice since it became legal recently, but I ate it in smaller quantities in the past. It's nice as an underwhelming complement. A big piece isn't so much my thing, I've realized. Presenting the steak cut, as Range does, for example, would have been awesome, but it was tender enough and therefore not too difficult to manage. I would've preferred potatoes on the side to a potato base. While the layering is cool conceptually, the functionality is poor. My meal kept sliding. I made an effort throughout to eat the components together, as I figured they were intended. 

Loud. Not screaming loud like a sports bar. Still, the noise level was too much for me. I strained to speak and tried hard to listen. Not my ideal ambiance for dinner. 

Wine and beer only.
author: Paulina F.

description: I can't tell you about the food because the service was so bad.  After the waiter brought water I never saw him again.  After 20 minutes I left.
author: Mike S.

description:
I came here on a blind date (L-O-L) and it was A-OK, hence 3 stars from me. They were out of hollandaise (how??) so I ordered the omelette and it definitely looked and tasted like something I could have made in 10-minutes. It took way longer to come out, obvi. I think I'm allergic to spinach; I discovered it here. It might just be a mental allergy.

Saturday 1pm, no wait - which was surprising. The space is not that big and feels a bit cramped bc I think they tried to fit too many tables. The service was pretty nice though and nothing was extremely bad. Maybe it would have been a better experience with some alc.
author: Juliana P.

description: We started with a perfectly balanced cheese plate. I then had an incredible French onion soup- the best I've ever had. Followed by an amazing filet mignon - it was truly a perfect dinner.
author: Emmet E.

description:
Great service, great atmosphere, food excellent!!!
The asparagus salad with goat cheese and the sole specials were off the charts good.  Try the escargot with pesto for a new twist from all the butter. We will be back!!
author: Karen E.

description: I absolutely love this restaurant! The food is amazing. I would suggest any of their risotto dishes! The creme brûlée is also to die for.
author: Chance V.

description: Cute little place to have an intimate dinner. Went with some coworkers after work for dinner and the staff is really friendly and patient. Bistro Central Parc is really delicious but it is quite pricey.
author: Amaya B.

description: About as fine a meal and service as you can get. The Hanger Steak was cooked to order, the lamb stew was a special treat, and the roasted chicken was flavorful, but not overdone. We will return! Very fair wine list as well, and those desserts........
author: David R.

description: Nice place. Very expensive. A little pretentious. Good for weekend brunch as there is no line. Food quality was really off last two times.
author: Gunner W.

description:
Date suggestion! Mom and pop run place, good price point, quick service and clean joint. Pretty hole-in-the wall, and is only open hours are fairly restrictive, but a sweet place to grab a "picnic" item and walk 5min over to the Presidio park to find spot. I got the Vietnamese cold coffee (7/10), with the pork belly baguette sandwich (8.5/10) and an oatmeal raisin cookie (8/10) = $14.00
Generous proportions and freshly made. 
8/10, would def picnic here again.
author: Gia P.

description:
On a date with my wife, we were greeted and graciously served by Emily just before lunchtime on a quiet afternoon.

We've eaten here once before for dinner and really enjoyed it.  That was sooo good. So we decided to try their brunch.

We started off with the french toast.  It was perfect.  The bread used was almost like angel food cake, which made it light, slightly sweet and delicious.

I had ordered the eggs benedict with spinach added.  It was awesome. For desert, I ordered the Tart Tartine. To die for.

A great little place for some quality time, delicious food and fantastic service.

A must go.
author: Carl B.

description:
I come for the mussels, I stay for the desserts. 
Nice French bistro ambiance.
author: Tony M.

description: A lovely neighborhood spot with amazing food. Service is somewhat lacking and the wine list is small and expensive. However the food makes up for all of this
author: D P.

description:
I have seen this place in my friend's neighborhood for a couple years and finally had dinner there.

The place is amazing!!! The food, service and atmosphere were really spectacular.  I will definitely be back again very soon.
author: J d.

description:
Cute little bistro with classic french food. 

Onion Soup
Beef Tartare
Escargots
Sweetbreads
Bouilibasse
Steak Frites

And everything else when i think of classic French Food. They have tons of specials too (came on a sunday night). Service was also pretty good good, although they did forgot my friend' endive salad but that wasn't a big deal. The servers also were attentive with refilling water and asks about our food and such. Parking is available around the block but may take you a bit depending on if you come on a rush hour. I wouldn't mind trying the breakfast menu next time if im in the area.
author: Cavin T.

description: This is the place that I wanted to, to taste the food that makes me satisfied and enjoyable for that moment. Excellent!
author: Team M S.

description: Delicious food and friendly service, but we were a party of four and half of our food was barely warm when it arrived.
author: Nasir K.

description: Despite good reviews, we didn't have a very good experience. I had a steak and egg. The steak was so dry that you couldn't even eat it. I asked for an over easy egg, but got a hard boiled instead. They were out of apple juice, cranberry juice, and steak sauce. And the bread was so dry and hard to swallow. The waitress also looked liked she just woke up and didn't want to be there. So now you can see why I'm surprised why this place got such a high review.
author: Ben K.

description:
Unfair to diners and the waitress to expect that person to serve an entire restaurant basically alone. It meant waiting for her to explain the menu and take orders, waiting for the wine menu and ordering off of it and receiving what one had ordered. Did someone else call out? Who knows. The waitress appeared run off her feet and apologetic to the point that each time she appeared before us she was apologizing, which sours after a bit.
We ordered a mixed green salad, some scrambled eggs that was supposed to come with fries but instead came with country potatoes, a side of ham, and a glass of white wine. Over $40. The ham was processed cold cut variety, $7. I asked for and was kindly given some good bread, but no butter. No dijon mustard or mayonnaise for the potatoes. A restaurant at this price point should mind the details. 
The space is elegant, but the meal was shabby.
author: Brian G.

description: A neighborhood gem. A few blocks off Divisadero to avoid the crowds.  But some of the best traditional French food in the city.
author: David G.

description:
Always a good place, great service at the bar and the tables. French-American! 
Try their specials as marked on the chalk board behind the bar...
author: Oliver L.

description:
Ugh.... Guys.... This is why we can't have nice things.

Came by for brunch as I know it's a solid spot and we can sit outside. There were plenty of tables open inside and outside, but it was just my gf and I - and the two 2-person tables outside were directly next to an open window where other diners were sitting (inside) and even awkwardly hanging their arms out the window.

We sat at a 4-person table away from the window and the waiter balked at us. So we stood up asked for a two person table not next to a window so we could have a shred of privacy. "There's none open".

I pointed out they had plenty of open seating. Could we just move a table and like magic turn that 4-person table back into a 2 person? "No! They are set up this way for a reason"

I'm not doing a great job of explaining how rude and uncompromising this guy was. He needed to make it clear that he was in charge and we were not to have any influence on where we get to sit at a restaurant that is 30% occupied.

So, we got up and left. Sorry you hate your job dude- but do long as I see your bald head waiting tables there, we're not going to return.
author: Ross H.

description: Very good French food! We had to sit at the bar because they were packed!  Bartender served us well.  Food was delicious, totally exceeded my expectation as I have very high standard for food. :-). However not too crazy about the atmosphere, very crowded, and clostaphobic feeling. Therefore minus one star.
author: Kelly L.

description:
Bottom-line... try the Confit de Canard!!

Bistro Central Parc is tucked away amongst the residential houses of NOPA.  You would never find it unless you were looking for it.  This is definitely a "destination" restaurant, but well worth the special trip. 

Inside you feel like you are in an authentic Parisian bistro.  Our waiter, Sebastian, was as French as they come - accent and all.  The wine list features a wide selection of French wines, from all areas, even those that are a bit esoteric. 

I've eaten here several times, even on weekends and never needed a reservation.  But if you have more than 4 people I'd recommend calling ahead because it may require them to shift some tables around.  (It's a small spot.)

My go to dish is the Confit de Canard.  It's a large helping of duck that's been deep fried with the skin on.  Juicy as could be.  They serve it on a bed of confit, which is sitting on a bed of lentils.  Very filling and delicious.

Parking is EASY.  This is a lightly trafficked residential neighborhood.  I've always been able to find a space within 1 block. 

Noise level is low.  Lighting is great.  Service was impeccable.  There also open for bruch on the weekends if that's more your thing.
author: Joel B.

description:
Walked by this place so many times as I live down the block. Me and my wife decided to check out the menu, but we walked in and they were not open yet. No problem, They were happy to let us look around and see the menu.

We ran the rest of our errands and showered and got dressed for dinner. We were seated right away and fully taken care of. Kyle was an amazing waiter and helped us to find some wine similar to a wine that my wife wanted, all based on a picture of the bottle. The whole staff was amazing too. I never knew this gem existed right up the street from us. It should be said I and my wife have blue and purple hair, and are covered in tattoos, yet we received the best service we have gotten in years and felt totally welcome. I love the open kitchen, you can see the chefs working on your meal, and looking for reaction when you take your first bite. Everything was excellent. Its like they were reading my mind how I wanted my lamb. The food and service was great!



Thank you guys! We will be back!
author: Japhy F.

description: A very cute little cafe restaurant tucked in nopa, SF. Have gone here multiple times and have never been disappointed at all by the food. The servers are excellent, very traditional french food. Had the filet mignon, escargot, as well as the risotto all very good.
author: Ed B.

description: It's fabulous experience. The server was super nice and attentive. The scallop risotto and grilled trout were delicious.  The atmosphere was cozy. The restaurant is located at a quite and peaceful neighborhood.  After I paid and walked out- I forgot my cell phone on the table and she ran to hand it back to me. It was a really nice experience.  I will return soon. Thank you.
author: Candy S.

description:
Mais oui, c'est bon! 

Happy Bastille Day, mes amis. Not so coincidentally, visited Bistro Central Parc over the weekend for a 5-star French meal worth Yelping about. 

Reservations are encouraged, but not required. Our group of 6 called ahead. Lucky for us, a true Frenchman was in the group and able to parlez his way into an 8:30 pm seating. Who needs OpenTable when you've got someone who speaks the owner's native tongue? When in doubt, there's generally seating at the bar as well.

We were given a warm "bonsoir" upon arrival and it was quite amusing to watch our friend schmooze with the owner en Fracais, making decisions about wine and appetizers to get started. We had a lovely Beaujolais as well as a bottle of vino that I swear smelled like asparagus in a bottle. 

To start, go with the baked Brie and garlic. Everyone at the table must eat a little bit, 'cause that's the rule when eating whole garlic cloves. Sure you leave smelling like a vampire murderer, but it's a group effort. 

It's not every day that I have the pleasure of enjoying a nice cut of meat. So anytime I see steak frites on the menu, it's all over. Bistro Central Parc's version is parfait! Hot fries, medium rare meat. If you can convince the person sitting next to you to order the mussels and share, do it. Dip those frites into the buttery white wine sauce and try not to think of all the calories you're consuming. 

By this time, I'd consumed a few glasses of red wine, steak, fries, garlic, mussels, not to mention the dinner rolls and butter. Though there's normally room reserved for dessert, it just wasn't happening. However, when I come back again, will set the bread aside in anticipation of a sweet treat finale. 

Overall, Bistro Central Parc a pleasant surprise tucked away in NoPa. Had it not been for friends who lived nearby, would never have been. I can't speak for its authenticity, but my French friend loved it. And that's good enough for moi.
author: Abby S.

description:
The food was good, but I wouldn't come back here. The dining area was empty except for 3-4 tables. We asked to be seated at a table, but were told all of those tables were reserved, and could either sit at the bar or outside. It was a cold and windy morning, so outside wasn't an option for us. I understand that those tables were reserved for 1130, most for noon or later, but we would've been done by noon if not earlier. Like I said, I understand, but it sucks to sit at a cramped bar, surrounded by an empty dining area. 

I had the French onion soup, which was good. Absinthe makes my fave onion soup, but this was a close second. I also had baked Brie, tomato concasse, and roasted garlic with toasted baguette. The roasted garlic was buttery and crispy all at the same time.

It took at least 15 minutes to get our check because the two waitresses were busy. It seemed like once they got busy, they needed more staff than they had. Annoying, after sitting at a cramped bar for our breakfast.

I wouldn't eat here again. I'm sticking to Absinthe.
author: Gabriela W.

description: This is a beautiful hidden gem in the western edition. It features French cuisine in a quaint cozy setting. Great for a first date or a family dinner. The attentive staff make you feel at home. They host an impressive wine collection and the chef's specials are always spectacular. A must for the dinning enthusiast.
author: Lawrence P.

description: Truffle risotto was amazing! Beef tartare was good although slightly too lemony. The Languedoc Bottle of red was the best value and way better tasting than the Bordeaux we ordered first. Overall very decent French food!
author: Amy Y.

description:
This place has a new owner, so unsurprisingly, everything has gone up about $5 more per plate.  When you add 3-5 plates, it's a significant increase when you're used to going often.

The food is almost the same quality, but seems slightly lackluster.  I think the charm is waning and I'm just not feeling it anymore, sadly.  

This place is so nice to eat at, especially outside on a warm sunny day.  I feel torn.  It is no longer a place I frequent, but rather reserved for rare outings now.

J
author: John M.

description:
Overall, my first (and probably last) experience was disappointing.  Not in a major catastrophe kind of way but just falling significantly short of expectations from the rave reviews. 

We arrived around 11:15am for brunch and the place was barely half full with almost two dozen seats empty inside.  We were told politely they were all taken/reserved and had to sit at the bar or outside (where it was freezing cold, no thank you).  So we sat elbow to elbow at the bar while most of those two dozen seats remained empty until we left.  Understand the policy but it was pretty lame and it's why most places don't do reservations for brunch; most parties show up late anyway and it leaves couples like us fending at the bar watching a mostly empty dining room.

Food was ok overall but nothing epic.  French onion soup was the standout, one of the best I've had in the city and almost as good as Absinthe's.  My Eggs Benedict was just ok; tasted pretty average just like everything was assembled together as expected and the English muffin was way too doughy and underdone.  My wife's Brie with toast was decent.

People were nice but the two girls were overwhelmed at the end and we were stranded waiting for our check for almost 15 minutes.  

I suppose if you're in the neighborhood, this isn't a terrible bistro but if we are gonna to venture out, we'd rather just go to Absinthe or Bisou which are a lot better.
author: Saminda W.

description:
We loved our waiter!  He joked around with us and made us feel really at home throughout our entire meal. The food was good, some dishes better than others, but overall, an enjoyable meal.  Really, this is a 3.5 star joint. 

Highlights included:

Mussels marinière:  fresh big mussels cooked in a delicious white wine cream sauce. Get extra bread to sop up the extra sauce!

Baked Brie:  this wasn't a complicated dish by any means but we liked the head of roasted garlic that came with it. 

Our escargots were overwhelmed with parsley and needed more butter and garlic. 

Everyone enjoyed their mains. However, the fish of the day (halibut) was dry and overcooked. The duck confit skin could also have been crisper. 

We enjoyed our meal here as the restaurant has a great casual laid back vibe and friendly service. The food was a bit more hit and miss though.  Regardless, this is a great neighborhood restaurant.
author: Ada C.

description:
My goodness this place is a MUST have! This was the absolute best food I have had in a long time, no I think it is EVER! 

Everything from atmosphere, service and food was extremely authentic and the flavor was so rice and flavorful that every bite I felt like I was in bliss. 

We ordered everything off the specials but honestly everything here is probably delicious!!! 

Props to the chef, the servers and the owners for making my day! I came in with a headache and came out with pure happiness!!!
author: Sophie Y.

description:
Decided last minute that I wanted to stop by this place before leaving the city. I made reservations at 5pm on NYE the night before! Somehow they were able to squeeze me in (amazing, right?). Our waiter was great. He made us feel welcomed and explained all the specials and answered all our questions about the menu.

Beef Tartare: I wanted my mom to try this dish because she never has. She ended up really liking it. Loved how it came with a small frisee salad. Great flavor and fresh meat.

French onion soup: I was a little scared that the soup would be really salty, but the soup here was delicious. The sweetness of the onions comes through and cheese adds a great element and balances out the sweet onions. My only issue with the soup was that it was just lukewarm. Would have liked it a bit hotter so that by the time we finished the soup, it would be cold. 

Seabass: Fish of the day special. I was really excited about this dish, but I was a little disappointed. The fish seemed over cooked just a little. But i enjoyed the creamy polenta and broccolini it came with. 

Filet mignon with foie gras: The star of the night! The filet was cooked to a perfect medium. Nice and pink in the middle. It was tender and juicy; I couldn't have asked it for any better. The foie  gras was amazing! Melt in your mouth amazing. And the sauce/reduction they used made it all the better. There was no sauce left by the last bite! 

Volcano chocolate cake: Cooked perfectly. Sometimes I hesitate to order these because even if it it's left in the oven for one minute too long, you lose the "lava" part of the cake. But when I picked up my fork and cut into it, the chocolate oozed out of the center. I was surprised (not in a bad way) with a bite of cherry after eating a few bites. 

Service was great. They were all very nice and attentive. My mom had mentioned that we were there for my birthday as we were finishing up and they were asking us how our meal was. Boy were we in for a surprise! As our dessert came out they put a candle on the plate and I could see it from afar. Then all of a sudden, the lights went out and it was completely dark inside. As the cake approached the whole staff started to sing Happy Birthday! It was great!! Thank you for doing that Bistro Central Parc!
author: Chris K.

description:
I ve been here twice, brunch and dinner .

Their brunch selection is vary. I ordered the egg Benedict and my friend ordered a croque monsieur. They were not bad, but not surprising at all. I m happy that they have the snails, escargot at brunch, which tasted flavorful with the sauce, it went perfectly with the bread. Overall, I enjoyed their food and service, had a good time with my girl friend.

And for the dinner, I think they have different people work for day and night, I m not sure if they are owners or what. The lady helped us was smiley less but helpful.
She explained different dishes to us, since we don't understand French haha. This time, we ordered duck confit and scallop risotto. I wanted to have duck confit for so long!!!I expected it to be very soft and melted in mouth, but this one came with bit tough..one star deducted from that. But I liked how they pair the duck with lentils and bacon in vinegar sauce. Its refreshing.

After the entree, we got the apple tart for dessert, its bit too sweet for me, but OK.
author: Natasha L.

description:
We went here for an early dinner on a Sunday evening, my first choice in the neighborhood being unable to take us. Having looked at the reviews I was not surprised to see the place relatively empty. Our reservation was for 6pm,the cusp as it turns out of the happy hour; we were just in time to order a glass of the house white each before the witching hour struck. The house wine is not available by the bottle and there was nothing on the wine list for less than $45,with much of the list being in the $65-75 range, This left me feeling uncomfortable, thirsty but unwilling to spring for a bottle at those prices in a neighborhood restaurant.
The dish that had appealed to me while browsing the menu the night before ( risotto with lobster sauce and Coquilles St Jacques) was not available. However we shared an excellent starter plate of charcuterie which included rabbit and chicken liver pate, pate de fois gras and a selection of smoked ham. Two of us had the moules mariniere and one had the bouillebaisse; having recently returned from France, I thought that the boullebaisse looked a bit paltry. I tasted the soup though and it was good. All in all we enjoyed a good meal,but I was left with the feeling that this place is way too expensive for the neighborhood.
author: Charles R.

description:
This place used to be great before the chef and the French staff left. Though the menu is basically the same, the care and preparation is lacking. The food is still pretty good, but the atmosphere feels stale. 
FYI, The former chef is now at Revelry Bistro.
author: Rocio P.

description:
After a series of cancelled reservations and constant rescheduling with at least 3 groups of people. I finally got to try Bistro Central Parc half a year after friend initially said we should go. I went with my family and we ordered escargots, steak tartare, and the endive salad to share. I'm personally not a big fan of escargot, but the steak tartare was popular even with my parents who usually like their steak well done. We ordered the duck breast dish, filet mignon with foie gras, fish of the day (trout), bouillabaisse, and scallop risotto. Everything came on piping hot plates, which was nice. The duck was a bit gamey and I wish the skin was crispier, but the fruity sauce in the dish was interestingly addictive. Mom said there were some small bones in her fish but she liked it otherwise.

Service was very attentive and friendly and they had a really pretty ceiling installation. Finding street parking was difficult.
author: Tina X.

description: Lovely neighborhood spot that never disappoints.  The dishes range from traditional to imaginative, all are well-prepared and satisfying.  Service is excellent and welcoming.
author: Dan C.

description:
I find my judgement and opinion of Bistro Central Parc all over the place. Some parts of my dining experience, I enjoyed; some other parts, I did not care for. The ups and downs ultimately make me feel like BCP is mediocre, thus I gave it 3/5 stars. Rough explanations to follow.

Convenience of the restaurant? Poor. 
I'm told that reservations must be made a month in advance for prime dinner hours, elsewise eat rather early or rather late? I understand that great restaurants are known to have backed up reservations, but I did not find myself wowed by the food. This is why I feel like the reservation hassle for BCP was not worth it. The restaurant is also located uniquely in a neighborhood of homes, yet parking proved difficult. I know that SF has terrible parking availability in general, but to drive up and down those blocks of residential homes at 5pm to find a spot should not have been that hard... I don't think so? 

Food? Great, good, & kinda sucked... depending on the dish. 
When I went, my table of two ordered three items:
American Kobe Style beef tartare - The great dish. I loved it. Delicate, aromatic, delicious. 
Risotto aux coquilles St Jacques - The good/okay dish. That's just it. Was good, but no more.
House special of the night ribeye steak - The dish that kinda sucked. This dish was ordered by my partner for the evening. It was him who said it first, but I agree that it tasted like... a chain-diner quality steak. It was so below average and bland. Rib eye is my favorite cut, too. What a shame.

Service? ________ (Haha, no comment.)
All of the servers are attentive and nice... enough. It's just, I couldn't buy their accents or personas. My opinion of the authenticity of their french characters may be irrelevant, which is why I'm choosing to leave it out. Let's just say that my experience at BCP did not share any similarities to the restaurants I had enjoyed during my time in Paris. 


Bistro Central Parc, in all, was just blazé to me... french accents and all.
author: Mimi N.

description:
Amazing!! From the service, quality of food, decor, I loved everything about Bistro Central Parc!! It's definitely a great place for a birthday dinner, because they sure made my birthday special.  Here's my story:

I love scallops, heard about this place from friends, and saw that it was 4.5 stars on yelp. So when my friend said he'll treat me out for my birthday, I suggested here. 

Prices are reasonable for the qualify of food you get.  Appetizers around $10, dishes around $22-27. My birthday is in December, so they had nice Christmas decorations on the ceiling that gave it a wonderful holiday atmosphere. 

** FOOD **

KOBE BEEF TARTARE - (5/5) - "raw beef with a raw egg on top?? Alan, are you trying to kill me on my birthday??" 
"Fine, do you want me to try it first?"
