I'm from Orange County but the last two times that I visited SF, Bistro Central Parc was a definite MUST on my itinerary. My girlfriend and I adore this spot due to its quiet location and understated elegance. Nothing really stands out about this place from looking at the exterior because it's tucked away in a quiet neighborhood. Then when you walk in, everything changes.

The servers and the owner are all friendly and warm hosts. Both times I have been here, the dining experience was great for the food and the welcome. I recommend the confit de canard, the beef rib, the fried lard with poached egg, the kobe beef tartare, and the warm brie on potato pancake. I've tried all of them and they've never been short of fantastic.

I so wish we didn't have to travel 400 miles to dine here, because there is really nothing quite like Bistro Central Parc where I'm from. But it's part of the reason why this place is so special for me and my girlfriend. Every time we go to SF, we have something we can for sure look forward to. We were in Paris last summer (and will return this summer) and we often compared some of the food we had there to the plates at Bistro Central Parc. This restaurant, for us, is as good a French meal as you can get without flying a few thousand miles.
author: Donovan B.

description:
To paraphrase another reviewer, "four star is too low but it is not quite yet five star."
I got real lucky to find a parking space only two blocks away. The neighborhood seems safe enough to walk through. The place was packed at 6pm Saturday night. The four of us shared a shrimp ceasar and a melon salad, both were very good. The appetizer was never served - misunderstanding with the waitress. Main courses were scallops on risotto, spare ribs special, mussels with spinach side and fish of the day. Again all were not quite five star. We had to wait about 5 extra minutes for the fish (it was served to another diner). With two bottles of wine and tip the final tab was about $250 - which is normal now days.
author: Wayne J.

description: Everything we tried was so delicious. Service was amazing - our server even bought a round of our drinks because the entrees took awhile! Best food Ive gotten in SF for such a reasonable price. Scallops and bone marrow are a must!
author: D C.

description:
Had their Scallops risotto with lobster sauce, sweet bread and a side of fries and Ratatouille. For desert I had their Creme Brulee.

Risotto - Scallops were cooked perfectly, probably the most tender scallops I've had, and I've had some good scallops. Risotto was cooked al dente, which combined with the tenderness of the scallops nicely. On top of all this, there was a hint of lobster that took this dish to a whole new level. The only problem I had with this dish was that I feel the risotto was a tad over seasoned. 

Sweetbread - I had to share this starter with 2 other people, which made me kind of sad because the sweetbread was absolutely delicious.

Fries - Good fries, very good fries.

Ratatouille - Not very good, I don't recommend getting this even if you are a fan of ratatouille.

Creme Brulee - I am a big fan of Creme Brulee and I must say this Creme Brulee was very well made. The caramel was crunchy, doesn't stick to your teeth too much, and the custard had just the right amount of sweetness to compliment the caramel. 

Overall, very nice place.
author: Eric C.

description: This place is such a cute French restaurant. The food is also amazing. I had the braised beef cheeks. It was my first time having beef cheeks. They were so tasty and tender...they just melted in my mouth. It was amazing. I also had the brie which was also really good. The service is top notch here. The waiter was amazing.
author: Rebecca D.

description: Food and service were great.   I would recommend the Filet Mignon with Foie Gra it was really tender and tasty.  The duck breast wasn't bad but wasn't it wasn't special enough in my opinion.
author: Tommy P.

description: Brunch: It's a nice small place but unfortunately I won't be coming back. The food was mediocre at the most. I had a sandwich with an egg on the top (Mademoiselle or something) , and well, I could make it better at home. The side salad was basically couple pieces of salad greens without any dressing and couple pickles. It did not make sense for me to put those things together on one plate. They did not compliment each other at all. I'm disappointed to be honest- This place has really good reviews. The service is nice and friendly
author: Natalia M.

description: This place is amazing! Was visiting my friends in San Francisco and they are regulars at this place. It is in a cute part of town, small place, but that's what makes it even better. The service was outstanding and the recommendations were on par. The baked brie was out of this world as was my entree, filet mignon with potato gratin. My friends, as usual, were delighted with their entrees as well. It is well worth the price and the wait.
author: Megan R.

description: Amazing food, amazing service. Nuff said.  A little jewel in the SF food scene. I highly recommend this place. The filet is awesome, as are the beef cheeks, the lamb, the skate and the risotto. And dessert tops it all off.
author: Fareed P.

description:
So, you know I RARELY give 5 stars on a first date. But yes, it was a 5-star experience, so I can't really not. 

Took JJ here for his birthday dinner as he was hankering after some good lamb. Reservation made - sat down immediately. Great service - Alex, our server, recommended a faboo wine that went with our entire meal (and *not* the most expensive one either). 

The food was delectable, especially the main course and dessert: we started with escargot for moi and warm brie for him, then we had lamb and filet mignon with the pomme frites (delightful), and the spinach (unnecessary but delish). Both meats were rarer than medium rare but neither of us minded as I'd rather have my lamb/beef a tad rare than a tad overdone. We had the molten chocolate cake for dessert - the menu says to order ahead, but as it was JJ's birthday, they brought it out with a candle and a song. 

The birthday boy was DELIGHTED by the whole experience. He like the crowd (mixed young/old, hipster/non-hipster), the ambiance (lively but not deafening), and, of course the food. Me, I liked all of the above, and the price ($150 total + 20% tip!). 

Thanks to all you Yelpers for pointing me to a great place to which I will return again and again and again (I hope!).
author: Mi M.

description:
Combining delicious, well presented and perfectly prepared food, with an attentive, knowledgeable service with a smile (thank you Alex!), made this family celebration of our Anniversary a wonderful event!
The Rossini special was indeed special with a cooked to perfection fillet Mignon topped with an amazing piece of tender liver, perfectly coupled with a port reduction sauce. Everything else was just as good. For wine pairing, simply ask for an advice.
Thank you!
author: Udi P.

description:
Great food, amazing service.

This place is right down the street from me so we'll be going back.

The scallops were out of this world. My husband had the muscles which he said were ok, but not great. Either way, I'll be back.
author: Emily K.

description: I've been here a few times and am never disappointed!! Such great food, friendly people and cozy atmosphere! Great wine list. Our last visit was on a Sunday night, the live music was a great touch.
author: Pamela R.

description:
Was looking for a nice date spot and ended up choosing Bistro. Just from the pictures I could tell it would be a nice cozy spot with some quality looking food.  We had reservations at 9 but got there around 815 and Jacques let us sit at the bar. 

Started off with a glass of bordeaux for the lady and a zinfadel for myself along with the duo de tartare de saumon. Individually the dish wasn't amazing, but eating all the components together (tartare, gravlax and roe) made the dish much tastier. 

The lady ordered the seafood paella special and it looked amazing! I had a bite with a mussel and it was delicious. I ordered the carre dagneau ratatouille which came out looking stunning. The lamb was delicious with a perfect medium-rare doneness. The ratatouille made a nice compliment to the lamb, though I would have to say the sauces seemed like a bit of an afterthought. 

Finished off the meal with poached pear dessert (can't find the name :/). Not the most impressive dessert I've ever had, but the ice cream and ginger tuile (I think?) made a pretty good combination. 

The ambiance and service were definitely top notch and I was very happy that we got to eat here. The food was overall pretty good. Definitely might have to make this a new spot!
author: Kiha L.

description:
The food is phenomenal, I was more than satisfied with the quality of our dishes. 
You're short one star because the host was very off- we asked for a slightly secluded table(something quieter, away from commotion) and the host looks me in the eyes and tells me there is no such thing and they will be very loud in 40mins because of how busy they are. It never did get loud and the way he said it with such disdain, like I should know better than to ask for a quiet table at some restaurant I've never heard of. 
Beyond that the waiter was very awkward but none the less helpful, maybe it was an off night but regardless of service the food is well worth it. I'll likely be visiting again to try something else
author: Bryan H.

description:
Fun place to dine -- everything from the kitchen to the host is all in one rectangular space -- very efficient and pretty impressive!  We ordered:

--Fried frog legs ($?, Special) -- Biggest frog legs I've ever seen -- might as well have been small chicken drumsticks.  If it's still around when you go, I recommend trying it!  If you've never had it, the texture is a cross of chicken and fish, with the best of both flavors.
--Steak frites ($21) -- Green beans were really tasty, but the steak itself was not amazing.  Very thin and a bit overcooked.  I guess that's why they say to order the mignon!
--Risotto aux coquilles St Jacques ($22) -- the scallop risotto, as everyone else promised, was delicious.  The lobster broth made the already perfect scallops taste extra sweet and succulent.  The scallops are on the raw side, but when its quality stuff, that is how it is best served.  The risotto itself was very basic, but SCALLOPS, so who cares :).
author: Kendra W.

description:
mussels (the cheaper one) - delicious. Mussels taste fresh, though a few had a bit of sand unfortunately. About 20ish pieces? The broth is amazing. Highlight of the meal. Definitely ask for more bread (free) to dip in the broth. Enough for a meal if you ask for a bunch of bread

sweetbread - meat is very good. Definitely worth ordering. I disliked the mushrooms and sauce however

salmon tartare - didn't taste great. Would skip next time. 

scallop risotto - scallops tasted nice, but didn't enjoy the rice. Would pass.

ratatouille - has a subtle hint of olives, but i couldn't find any in there. I hate olives, so I hated this. Took a few bites and gave it away to others.

fries - Very good quality fries. Delicious and fresh. Definitely worth getting

If it weren't for the mussels, I'd give it 3 stars. 4 stars because I ordered the mussels. Excited to come back.
author: Mark D.

description: Shocked to see no line on a Saturday Morning , the wife and I waltzed right in and had a top notch meal , great food, great service, great coffee, friendly staff , no problem parking -  once again I have to point out that we just walked in , on a SAT morn and had a superstar meal, no 30 minute wait in line with hipsters - I ca n't  imagine this place being a secret much longer
author: Chris B.

description:
Cozy little restaurant. Service wasn't bad, but food was good

Salmon Tartar-fresh salmon wrapped around a piece of smoked salmon. This was really fresh and good

Beef Tartar-this was huge and full of flavor. They even have a raw quail egg on top.

Charcuterie-nothing special

Brie with roasted garlic-this was so good, especially when you spread the garlic over the bread

Wild Mushroom Risotto-not sure if it was risotto because the texture was very different. However it was really yummy. Small portion, but filling

Mussels with white wine and shallots-very good. 

Breast of Duck-Delicious. Cooked perfectly and full of flavor

Fish of the day-pan fry sole. This you can pass. Least favorite dish. 

Fries-pass

Dessert-Pear something-yummy.
author: Karen H.

description: Very good french style bistro.  Not pretentious and good prices.
author: Frederic R.

description:
The brunch at Bistro Central Parc was really disappointing and overhyped. The steak frites was overpriced, bland and tasted like they used low quality meat. The salad on the side was wilty and over dressed. I did like their french toast, but find it kinda weird that they charge extra for pure maple syrup (shouldn't quality ingredients always be served?). The mussels were okay, but I've had better, fresher mussels at other places. I would probably get the Croque Madame next time since that looked better, although on my friend's dish, the egg looked overdone.

The service was good, and they were able to seat us pretty quickly for a Saturday morning. I'd give them another try for dinner probably, but not for brunch.
author: Vivian H.

description:
Ooh la la! 

Another great solid French restaurant in the heart of SF.  I took my family and Matt T. here on Christmas Eve night to get our French on.  Everything was delicious but I hate to say it.  "It ain't no Chapeau!"  You can't help but compare after having one of the best French meals in SF.  They were close though, I give Central Parc Bistro 4.5 stars. 

They give complimentary bread but it wasn't warm or toasted. 

Highlights for appetizers: 

The traditional French onion soup ($8.50) hit the spot real good.  It came out steaming with perfectly baked cheese on top and warm, ooey, gooey cheese with onions inside.  It's just a bowl of happiness in my opinion.  I really hate to compare it to Chapeau! but one thing Bistro Central Parc was missing was some good crunchy pieces of bread in the soup. Le sigh. 

The mussels au curry madras ($12.50) had white wine, shallots, parsley, curry madras, and crème fraiche.  The steamed mussels were drenched in a very creamy and delicious sauce.  I would use my spoon to drink it while I slurp up the mussel meat!  I recommend you dip the complimentary bread in the soup base.  Beware, the white wine is a little strong so you may get a nice light buzz off of it.

Pommes frites ($5) were solid. They tasted really fresh and crisp. Great to go with an entrée.  

The warm brie on potato pancake with mizuna salad ($9.50) was good but not outstanding.  The salad gave it a more asian fusion taste.  The sweetbread with mushrooms ($10)  was an interesting dish but not memorable to my taste buds.

Onto the main course!

I was so happy that they were doing specials off the menu for the Tournedos Rossini ($28).  It was everything I could ask for in a French meal: filet mignon with foie gras.   The presentation was fierce since it was literally a tower of goods.  The filet mignon was toppled on top of fried potatoes along with the foie gras in this amazing black truffle sauce. The filet mignon was black pepper galore and I loved it.  I had it medium and it was done to pink perfection.  The foie gras was...different.  It was served more lukewarm and had a different texture to it.  It didn't have the crunchy texture but it melted in my mouth.

I tried the beef bourguignon ($18 and it was my second favorite dish.  It was drenched in a rosemary-red wine sauce and seasonal vegetables.  The meat was cooked oh so tender, I barely had to chew.  The sauce is a tad bit salty but it went great with the vegetables and you can taste a little wine in it.  They are fearless with their wine in the dishes!  

The Risotto with seared scallops in lobster sauce ($18) was delicious but something I wouldn't order again.  The scallops were cooked perfectly and they were good sized.  However, the risotto could definitely use a little more flavor.  However, I'm sure my taste buds were immune to salt after having heavy beef dishes.  The risotto had a great creamy texture to it as well.  Other main courses were the fish of the day and the lamb both looked delicious but I didn't get to try.

Desserts:
The creme brulee ($7.50) and the pyramide de chocolate ($9) were my favorites.  Creme brulee had a nice crispy sugar coated on top of the rich cream underneath.  The pyramide had a really rich and fluffy chocolate cream with the cake.  We also had two Buche de Noel: one chocolate and one caramel ($9 each).  This dessert was like a spiral sponge cake with caramel or chocoalte inside.  It reminded me of the chinese round sponge cake so it wasn't anything special.  I hope they vary up their desserts next time!

Overall, still a solid experience. Make sure you order the right dishes and you will have a magical meal.
author: Cam C.

description:
On my last trip to San Francisco I heard the our visit overlapped with some friends who were also in town. We decided to meet up and my friend decided to try Bistro Central Parc. This restaurant is rather small and I was surprised they were able to accommodate our party of 10. The service was satisfactory and the food was decent. I think the prices are reasonable considering the quality of the food. They serve high quality French cuisine and I believe no entree was more then $25. For my meal I had:

Kobe Beef Tartare - This was the first time I have ever consumed raw beef. I normally eat my steaks medium rare, but this was the first time I ordered beef tartare. I would say that it wasn't bad. It was actually pretty good. I think it had a little too much acid (a bit on the sour side), but it was an overall tasty dish. I think I also need to get use to eating raw beef, before I can be a true critic. I remember the first time I had sushi. I was just glad to get it down, but now I love it!

Seared Seabass - The Seabass was delicious. Cooked perfectly with a crispy skin. It was light, but yet just enough to fill me up. 

Bistro Central Parc was surprisingly good considering the affordability. It is definitely a good place to check out if you want good quality food!
author: Richard P.

description:
I really wish I would've loved this place, it would be convenient, but the food here is kinda bad :/ 

The snails are frozen and I think mine were heated up in a microwave. The main course was just 'ok'. It just really felt like the chef's/chef were unenthusiastic and the food made me a little sad. I feel kinda bad writing this, but hopefully they can get better, fresher, simpler french cuisine because the guys working there are really sweet and nice. 

Perk up Bistro Central Parc!
author: Sloth S.

description:
Wow, we were blown away by this amazing place! It's a hidden gem that I will definitely be returning to soon. Great service, incredible quality, and each bite was absolute perfection! 

Highlights were the baked Brie, escargot (it was my bf's first time trying it and he loved it! Recommend asking for extra bread to soak up the parsley butter sauce it comes in...yummmmm!), and scallop risotto in lobster bisque. 

If you go here, you'll walk out with very happy taste buds :0)
author: Lindsay U.

description:
I've had a decent experience here for brunch, a great one for dinner. 

Brunch: Mother's Day. Crowded, noisy, long wait. Good food, but nothing out of the ordinary. Coffee was French Roast of the inky-black variety which stays unaffected by any amount of cream your pour into it. Disclaimer: I generally hate brunch. No eggs are worth waiting 45 minutes for.

Dinner: Girlfriend's birthday. Food was beautifully prepared and delicious. They modified a special entre to accommodate my girlfriend's diet with no fuss. The super-warm owner came over to our table, chatted, and gave us a small present to commemorate our special night. Left stuffed and happy.

This is a real French bistro run by a real French guy. If you are super-picky, or in a hurry, you will probably get some of the famous Parisian attitude. But don't let that discourage you, because the place can be great. Be civilized. Call for a reservation; show up for it on time. Order a bottle of wine and ask what's good tonight. Take the time and savor your meal, rather than just gulping it down and asking for the check. Make some small talk with the owner; it's a digestif.
author: Joe V.

description:
Great atmosphere, love the location. The apps were amazing. Only downside, which took away that fifth star, was they over cooked my Stiped Bass so it was super dry, but the sauce and the veggies it came with was phenomenal.

Overall, definitely interested in coming back.
author: Lisa W.

description: Wonderful food, atmosphere, and service! Anything with polenta or polenta cake is highly recommended.
author: Kayli S.

description: One of the better meals I've had in a while . Kind of a strange spot for French food but once inside transported you to the Seine. Awesome food, great sauces-it is French so sauce is important. Started with the charcuterie plate that was one of the better ones I've ever had, duck confi, pate, cornichons and olives. Attentive but not overbearing staff. Portions aren't huge but the flavors make up for it. You just want to savor each bite
author: Matt A.

description:
Wow. 

5 stars for the wonderful food + service! Bistro Central Parc's staff made me feel like I was eating a michelin star eatery, actually I've been to many michelin'ed star-ed restaurants and I think they were even better! 

I ordered the beef cheeks and they were a tad 'powerful' tasting- a little gamey and i know that sounds ridiculous (because its beef!!) but i couldn't eat it. I don't remember if i've eaten beef cheeks before but i probably will have to avoid them in the future. 

The wait staff asked me about my order and I told them my concerns. They graciously asked if I would like to get something else. I asked for the pasta of the day and got the most delicious carbonara. My friends got the scallop risotto (yummy!) and the seafood stew (also very tasty!). We finished with the creme brulee (creamy, thick, and should be shared because its a big portion!). 

I'm not one to turn away a plate but I'm sooooo thankful of the service at Bistro Central Parc. I felt really bad but I could tell that they really wanted their customers to be happy. 

I'm going to be going back and back to this restaurant because as I can get delicious food in a lot of places in the city, outstanding, welcoming, and friendly customer service is hard to find.
author: Cicely T.

description: Rainbow trout almondine was superb! Desserts are always amazings. Staff is very knowledgeable and helpful with wine pairings. I believe they can do no wrong...and if you think they have, just ask them to do it over and they will happily oblige.
author: Jason K.

description:
I can't say enough nice things about this restaurant. I live off of Stanyan north of the Panhandle, and there's really a lack of "nice" restaurants within walking distance. I was so pleased to find this place.

A friend was in town visiting from New Zealand and it was the first time at BCP for both of us. We ordered the short ribs, rabbit special, strawberry deliciousness for dessert, and a half bottle of wine. It was just over $100, which for the quality of food and ambiance was definitely worth it.

I went in to cut the short ribs so my friend and I could share - I barely put pressure on my fork and it fell apart. Amazing. The rabbit was well done and the vegetables complimented it well. The wine list wasn't extensive per se, but the wait staff was well versed in pairings which matters more to me anyway. What good is a $300 bottle if it doesn't go well with your meal?

One thing I really appreciate is the owner stopping by each table with a smile to make sure everyone was having a good time. There were quite a few regulars or friends who came and gave hugs to the staff throughout our meal. I felt like I was at a family dinner. I'll definitely be back to try brunch!
author: Kate S.

description: Came here with local family who live in the neighborhood.  they had been here many times before and "never once had a bad meal. "  The new owner 'Gina' went out of her way to make us feel at home.   (she has a great sense of humor also)  We started with the bree which was perfect.   Moved on to a salad, and the suggested wine. Again , it was perfect.  The French onion soup was probably the best I've ever had.   But, as many others have said,  they make the bat chicken in San Francisco.  Flavorfull, moist, and perfectly seasoned.  Really, make sure you try it.   After the meals were done Gina suggested dessert.  I didn't think I could eat another moral but was talked into it by my daughter. Glad I did. some of us thought the dessert was the best part of the meal.  Whatever you do when dining at this establishment,  don't leave without having something from the dessert menu.
author: Peter G.

description:
Delicious. Very friendly service. A great local restaurant 
Plan to go back often.
author: Bob C.

description: Consistently great meal. Food is tasty and the staff are exceptional. This is one of my favorites in San Francisco. Tonight's Filet, Foie Gras, and Brussel Sprouts totally hit the spot.
author: John C.

description:
So much to say,... I will summarize it with: It just became one of my favorite restaurants in the city.

I gathered some of my closest friends and came here for a special intimate birthday dinner. I had such a wonderful time, especially because of the absolutely amazing and impeccable service. The waiters were friendly, the owner is a sweetheart and they made me and all of my friends feel like we were having a family meal with no time restrictions. We stayed there 1.5 hours past their closing time, and AT NO POINT, we felt like they had already closed. Yeah... that kind of service. 

Now to the best part, the food. OH MY GOD!!!!!!!!!!! It was a culinary orgasm. 

The menu is small, but all of the options are just so tempting. I believe I must have tried about 80% of their menu since my friends each ordered something different. The food was simply delicious, uniquely made and unforgettable. 

I fell in love with this place.

Thank you Bistro Central Parc for making my birthday this year one to remember.
author: Monique T.

description: Don't think we could have experienced a better meal. We all ordered something different and shared our food liberally. The duck was perfect as it sat on a throne of potatoes, bacon, spinach etc. The chicken was the finest we've ever tasted - moist and seasoned to perfection. The Steak and Frites - was out of this world with melting herb butter all over it. And the filet mignon was taken to church and blessed before being served on a palette of potatoes. A wonderful experience with incredibly attentive staff.
author: Steve R.

description:
French cuisine is my weakness after trying many places, this is by far one of my favorite French bistros.
Everything I had there was fantastic, especially braised beef cheek.... Heavenly!  It melts in your mouth.
The service was very friendly, attentive and pleasant.
I just can't wait to go back.
author: Tomomi K.

description:
What was it the Queen said a few years ago?  Something about "anniblus horriblus"?  That, for me, is 2010.  Good riddance 2010, and don't let the door hit your ass on the way out.

So, to send out the anniblus horriblus year, I congregate with friends who've helped see me through it.  What I want is a warm, welcome hug of a place with satisfying food.  And I don't want to be rushed through it all;  I want the hug to linger. 

On a stormy December morning, four of us congregate at Central Parc Bistro.  They take reservations for brunch.  Not many places do that.  They serve up fresh, strong coffee with steaming cream.  It fills my soul.  They serve hearty, solid omelets and satisfying, cheese-encrusted Croque Madame's.  They don't rush us to order or to move on.  They continue to refill our coffee, letting us enjoy, linger, laugh, and savor.  All in all, a pretty perfect ending to this year or any.
author: Tracey A.

description:
In a word: lovely. In two words: perfectly so.

So far, I can only speak for brunch, but I plan on going back for dinner very soon. My friend and I had the salmon benedict and the croque monsieur. From these dishes and the menu in general, Bistro Central Parc seems to specialize in perfectly executed French standards. You're not going to get the latest exotic ingredient or unexpected fusion - instead, you'll get the most divine version of something you probably already love.

The ambiance was perfect. Bright and active but not crowded. The waitstaff was attentive but not overbearing. Even some live music! Greatgreatgreat. So glad to have this place in the neighborhood.
author: Sarah S.

description:
I finally made it out here with friends after bookmarking the place forever.  It was so good I made a reservation right there right then for mom's birthday in a week.  For both visits, food did not disappoint us at all.  Bistro Central Parc is hands down one of the best French bistro in SF.  It reminds me so much of Paris, where there are tons of bistros tucked away in the corner of a quiet residential block off the main streets.  

In my opinion, good food is what gets you 4 stars, but service is what earns you the 5th star.  And they clearly deserve that here.  At mom's bday dinner, the owner came and greeted her personally.  The entire staff sang happy birthday to her.  And she even got a mug as her bday gift!  If you are looking for Michelin rated service, this won't be it.  But if you want the super friendly staff and atmosphere, you have to check this place out.  I can't wait to go back and try the other dishes on the menu!
author: Eva S.

description:
I am so stoked about this place that I don't even know where to begin.

From the very beginning, I had a great experience with this restaurant.  It all started with trying to find a delicious restaurant where we could sit outside with our dog.  I called a few different places that had strict rules against dogs and weren't very nice about it.  After seeing that Bistro had 4.5 stars, I thought, "Why not?"  A gentleman with an authentic French accent answered the phone and told us that of course we could bring our dog!  In fact, that they were excited to see him.  He asked for his name and told us we were all set.

This restaurant is nestled in a quaint neighborhood in the Western Addition where people walk their dogs, walk to the grocery store and hang out at Bistro Central Parc.  The restaurant doesn't look like much, and it certainly doesn't look like a 5 star restaurant but I promise you that it is!  Everyone is so welcoming and happy to see you there.  It's like you have been friends for years visiting their home.

Their food is simply magnificent.  Everything is fresh and as gourmet as can be without being too bougie.  All of their food was portioned perfectly and enough for 3 people (and a dog) to taste.

-Wild Mushroom Risotto: A sophisticated take on one of my favorite home dishes, Campbell's Mushroom sauce over rice.  The mushrooms were absolutely fresh and the risotto had a thick mushroom sauce over it that was so delicious.  I highly recommend this one on a cold night.  
-Warm brie on potato pancake over mizuna salad: Not one of my favorites but who doesn't love warm brie?  I thought this was an interesting idea but I didn't really like the potato pancake.  It needed to have more flavor in order to pair better with the brie, which is by nature very mild (taking off 1/2 a star for this.)
-Scallops with risotto in lobster sauce: this one was a special request that they were nice enough to honor.  I saw this dish in a picture on Yelp and it looked amazing.  I asked if they could make it and they were more than happy to make me a dish that wasn't on the menu.  That was REALLY nice of them!  This restaurant really knows good customer service.  A few of the risottos were a bit cold on the inside so I need to take off 1/2 a star for that as well but everything else tasted heavenly.
-Chicken W/ Mashed Potatoes: wonderful!  The chicken was nice and moist and pulled apart easily.  It was seasoned to perfection and the mashed potatoes were delicious.

This restaurant is A+ in my book.  Service was outstanding, food was impeccable and they are dog friendly.  I highly, HIGHLY recommend coming to this place at least once in your life.  The food is amazing!
author: Victoria C.

description: I've been here for both brunch and dinner and it is in my top 5 fav in the city!  Love love this place!  The filet mignon with foie gras and scallops is a MUST, you will not be disappointed!
author: William C.

description:
Duo de saumon- great
Bone marrow with tomato jam- amazing
Beef cheeks- melt in your mouth and incredible
Bouillabaisse- not my dish
Stewed strawberries- interesting and pretty good, a little too much pepper
Chimay and rose brut wine- intoxicating

Best french food I've had in the city so far. 

A++++++ would definitely do business again.
author: Linh H.

description: Came here on the suggestion of my date who lives in the area. This French restaurant is tucked away from the usual busy NOPA area in a quiet neighborhood setting. The food presentation, taste and quality was fabulous, service was spectacular and the price very reasonable. I would definitely come back and suggest this restaurant to my friends.
author: John N.

description: I brought my husband here for his 45th birthday. The food was excellent (we shared a tartare appetizer and I had the duck entree and my husband had the steak). We shared a lovely bottle of cabernet. We were too full to order dessert, but they still brought out a tasty profiterole with a candle in it, as the whole room sang happy birthday, once the lights were lowered (this must be a tradition, as the whole restaurant joined in). The service was impeccable. We'll definitely be back.
author: Mishka L.

description: I give it a 4.5. I would rate it 5 if it were not for a bit of slow service at the end. This is a find, and our first at the Bistro. We were greeted warmly and the waiter was exceptional, except at the end when he was swamped. I am not much of a meat eater, but the beef cheeks made me reconsider meat--it melted in my mouth and the taste was sublime. The others in the party had the sea bass special of the day and duck leg. Both were great, although mine was the best, according to all three of us. The salad was creative--eggplant with citrus and arugula. All the desserts were "regulars' on the menu--the four we tried were good. The place gets busy after 7 p.m., even on a weekday.
author: L G.

description:
Solid low key bistro. Been here numerous times before we changed neighborhoods. Great for brunch or dinner. The eggs benedict is delightful. Prices are decent and most dishes are good but don't blow you away. Overall this place is pretty darn solid.

One of the major bonuses is that this place doesn't have that much hype, which means it's usually very easy to get a table (much easier than Chez Papa and nearly as good).

Just can't give a restaurant 5 stars if they have log cabin syrup. Just sayin.
author: Zack S.

description:
This place is absolutely amazing. It has easily become our favorite go-to place for a great meal, great wine, and even better service. 

The French onion soup, the Filet, and a side of fries is a perfect meal, but always check out the special board for a treat.
author: Peter S.

description: This quaint, tucked away spot in a lovely neighborhood is the perfect place to unwind and enjoy an amazing meal! The owner is wonderful and from the moment you walk in, you feel part of the family! And then the decision to order the food and select your wine. I've been here a few times and have always had an amazing meal. You can't go wrong with any of it! I'm a big fan! My favorite restaurant in SF!
author: K B.

description: YUM. my boyfriend and i had a fantastic meal here last night. we started with the escargots bourguignon and the moules marinieres. i ordered the risotto with scallops and he had the beef cheeks. everything was so GOOD! we finished the meal with a warm chocolate cake with a scoop of ice cream. i don't like sweets but that cake was delicious. five stars for good food, great service and a nice atmosphere.
author: Jae C.

description:
Amazing Brunch. I can't wait to try dinner out here.

It's easy to not venture off the main path and stick to Union, Chestnut, or Fillmore for brunch, but this gem is definitely worth the drive.

I had the Croque Madame, which was absolutely epic. Check out my picture. It's basically a ham and cheese sandwich, with the cheese melted on top. Then top it off with a fried egg. Seriously. Go to the gym before you eat this thing, but then devour it.

The service was very attentive as well, and we didn't have to wait, even on a Sunday afternoon. I will return for dinner (and definitely for brunch)!
author: Kevin H.

description: VERY RUDE SERVICE.  It doesn't seem like the staff cares about the customers or making the experience pleasant.  Don't bother with this restaurant!
author: Cristina M.

description:
This place was mad yummy. The ambiance was nice, understated. The staff was attentive but not pushy or looming. French onion soup was exactly how it should be, mushroom risotto was like a flavor punch in the mouth, and the duck breast entree was so good I wanted to slap somebody.

I would come back here any day of the week. I can't wait to try the brunch menu
author: Jarrod B.

description:
Oh my goodness!! Holy deliciousness!! 

Boyfriend and I went for a nice dinner, and whoa did we get one! 
Beautifully plated and presented, perfectly cooked, perfect flavor and texture..and very resonably priced for the quality!  

I had the scallops with lobster sauce risotto- perfection!  
My boyfriend had the fliet mignon, he said it was perfectly cooked and flavorful. 

The staff was very friendly and helpful as well. 

Very happy with our choice!
author: Dayna E.

description:
Probably the best service I've had in the past year in the Bay Area.

The Chef Jacques welcomed us in French as soon as we arrived. We were served by Jerome, who also speaks French, which is a really plus for me. I am french-speaking and love to be talked to in French when I'm in a French Restaurant. They both knew my first name from the reservation and called me that way. It felt so homey, I liked it.

The place is really nice and I love all the lights on the ceiling.

Concerning the food, I would say it's always nearly prefect but not quite 100% perfect.

I had the Marrow bones as appetizer, the "magret de canard" as entree and the "Fraises à la Modena" for dessert. Everything was good, and the meet was absolutely amazing, it melted in my mouth! The marrow bones were sort of grilled and served with a little salad. Both had much too much salt on it (and I already usually put a lot of salt on my food), which is kind of a pleasure killer. The duck was great, served with potatoes and spinach. It was delicious, except that for me, the sauce had too much sugar in it. The strawberries were very good, served with vanilla ice cream. Jerome told us that they added sugar to the preparation and I wouldn't do that. Too much sugar, again.

My husband had the Onion Soup, he loved it, the filet mignon, melting as well, and the chocolate Volcan, delicious.

So I would say, great place, great people, affordable prices, and good food. It was just not the complete wow effect I was expecting for the food, because of too much salt/sugar, which covers all the other tastes. Still, I'll go back to try other stuff on their menu, because still, everything looks delicious.
author: Emilie M.

description:
Dear yelp haters,

Please stop going to a place 1 time, assume you know everything about the place and then trash a place and people based on your visit-specific details. You suck. 

I just moved back to this neighborhood after living here 20 years ago. BPC doesn't need my review or your review; fortunately, it's that good.

This is exactly what it purports to be: a French bistro. Nothing more or less. Not extraordinary in Paris, but that's the point. Jacques, the owner, is a classy dude. Love most of the staff, especially Zarina.

If you want a solid French meal, come here.
author: Carmen A.

description: I've been here twice now. The food was great both times and with pretty reasonable prices. A good neighborhood spot for a special occasion or whenever you want something a little fancy, but still pretty causal.
author: Amy S.

description:
Awesome, just awesome.  Where in the city can you find reasonable prices for main courses?  Alongside, they were really busy, our waiter hustling around, forgot our drinks.  Realizing, he hurried to get it without a problem.  On top of that, he was very friendly, gave us all his recommendations (including what he didn't like).  The food came super fast and hot and delicious.  Be warned with the copious amount of butter!

Risotto, steak, and the mussels were excellent.  Creme brulee was very typical, but reasonable for the price, and the special dessert beignets were awesome.

As the waiter left the check, he comped us the drinks and didn't even tell us (or maybe he forgot).  That's professionalism (or luck!)

Definitely will be coming back.
author: Adrian E.

description: I've been here numerous times over the past three years and have never had a bad meal. The service and food are always outstanding.
author: A P.

description: Bistro Central Parc is a great date spot, tucked away in NOPA. I like that it's off by itself, right in a neighborhood, not really near other restaurants. It adds to an already quaint and quiet atmosphere that the restaurant provides. Service was spectacular. Very friendly and attentive. The (new) owner stopped by our table to check on our experience and that's always appreciated. And the food was excellent. Not the best $100+ (for 2) I've ever had but everything was prepared perfectly and had excellent flavors. I could stand for the portions to be a little bit larger but hardly anything to be unhappy with.
author: John H.

description:
For brunch: 

Eggs benedict with potatoes and salad. Every bite was delicious, I wanted to eat it as slowly as possible and savor everything,  even the salad was outstanding. Mussels in butter cream sauce to die for ! Very cute little neighborhood restaurant .
author: Christy D.

description:
Disappointed. I have been regularly to Bistro Central Parc but since it changed owner, prices went up and portion smaller. Escargot are less good than some other French places in SF and really expensive (14$ while we can find better quality and with the shell at $9 elsewhere), same for the Brie, the portion was so small and pricy $15! (While we can get 3 times more for $10 at other nice French places). The duck breast was good though. I wish the potatoes were freshly cooked in the duck fat but it wasn't, it was pre-cooked since a while looking at the texture and flavor. The bouillabaisse came with too few broth...
I would just go back for the duck breast because it's hard to find and to try the riz de veau too, but not for appetizers. 
With previous owner, budget was about 40$ wine, food and tips included. Now, it's about 60$ for the same but in lesser quantity. I am French and I was also surprised that they got rid of most French employees, replaced by pushy waitresses and different kitchen staff. Sounds like they cut off on expenses at the detriment of quality and raised the price to pay the rent of the restaurant itself...
The only French guy I talked to was probably the boss, a bold guy, and he was really rude. Not smiling, not even a thank you. Not surprised he got also a bad review earlier just for himself.
Disappointed.
author: Anne T.

description: This is my favorite restaurant of all time! I have gone to Bistro Central Parc for my birthday dinner three years in a row and I will continue to go. The food is amazing and more importantly, the service is exceptional! I highly recommend going to Bistro Central Parc for any sort of occasion.
author: Adriana A.

description:
so yummy. Price is great and will keep us coming back. (too often fine dining is priced too expensive) but i can see why this place is full house every night. 

Appetizers: 
Brie on potato pancake - top notch, perfect mix of flavors - 
Salmon Duo Tartare - fresh taste, smoked salmon was unique that it was fruity tasting - excellent. 

Main: 
Scallops risotto - Excellent!!
author: Vanessa L.

description:
I would like to start off by saying this was my second time dining at this restaurant.  The first time was for dinner and I received excellent service.  I've meant to come back for brunch and today was supposedly that day where I could celebrate Mother's Day.

I had made reservations at 12:30pm for a party of five.  When we arrived, the restaurant was not busy and we were probably third table seated at the restaurant.  About 12:40pm, we ordered our food.  Three people ordered soup along with the main course.  Our server, ZARINA, asked if we would like the soup served with our main entrees or split into two individual courses.  We chose the latter option of two courses.  So far, so good.  About twenty minutes later, we received our soup.  It was a little late given the low number of tables, but this was not the issue.

This is where it gets interesting.  About 1:30pm, our main courses had not arrived yet.  Between the five of us, we had ordered a ham and cheese sandwich with a sunny-side up egg, risotto, mussels, side spinach, roasted potatoes, a side of smoked salmon, and side of fries.  We also had an order of French toast which came out with the soup.  We asked ZARINA what was taking so long with our food.  By now the restaurant was full of customers who had arrived after us and received their entrees before us.  They were either in the middle or finishing their meal.  

ZARINA started to lecture us in a condescending tone and stated we chose to have our soup first which caused the delay.  I understand that it was normal practice for restaurants to space out courses; however we had been waiting for over THIRTY MINUTES after we had finished our soups.  At this point, we were watching other customers eat their full entrée.  Please keep in mind that it had been about 50 minutes since we ordered.  After she gave her condescending remarks, she continued to glare down at us for an additional three minutes as if we were idiots for even asking the whereabouts of our food.  We were all speechless.  Were we supposed to get the food or cook it ourselves at this point??

About five minutes passed and ZARINA returned to bring more bread to our table.  Apparently she also brought her attitude with her.  She bent over at me and started to reprimand me saying, "NEXT time...."  I could not believe I was being lectured once more.  I quickly interrupted her and told her, I was tired of hearing excuses.  The table next to us had their appetizer and was finishing up their main course.  Guests with parties larger than ours were seated after us, served their entrees before us, and were either finishing up their meals or even paying their restaurant bills.  Rather than finding out what had happened to our meal, ZARINA was lecturing us again.   If she would have apologized or said, "Let me check," rather than lecture me, I would not have complained about been upset.

What was supposed to be a pleasant brunch turned out to be a disaster.  I told the other male server/host that I did not want her serving us anymore.  The only saving grace for this restaurant was the owner.  He came and spoke with us personally and was apologetic over his employee's service.  He later comped us four desserts.  After speaking with the owner, we had excellent service by the same male server/host I most recently spoke with.

About 2:15pm, towards the end of our dessert, ZARINA came to apologize.  I honestly felt it was forced and she tried to make excuses yet again.  

I used to recommend people to this restaurant.  The French-style cuisine was good.  I was looking for another small bistro-type restaurant like "Chapeau!" and thought I had found one until this experience today.  We ended up leaving the restaurant at 2:30pm.  It had taken us an entire TWO HOURS for brunch with one cumulative hour spent waiting for food in a restaurant which was not fully booked.  What a waste of time on a beautiful Sunday.

I hate writing negative reviews, but I feel this issue needs to be addressed.
author: Ernest Y.

description:
Stellar.

Could not get to Paris, Nice, or Collioure, so I took the 43 over to Masonic and Hayes and walked a couple of blocks.

No jet lag, and very rapid drink service.

Bistro Central Parc is now a staple of my life.

My meat-crazed pals get to have lamb shank and bone marrow while I eat a posh vegan dish, a daily fish special made "seagen" style, or my standby - the heavenly, heavenly Bouillabaisse.

It's all about the food and wine.  The interior is pleasant, but simple.  The service is real.
author: Patricia P.

description: Food is good.  Service, not so much. Servers have apparently been trained at the TSCB (Trump School of Charm and Blaming).  After several requests for a side dish that finally arrived just as main course plates were about to be taken away, the waiter's impatient response was "I'm not the chef, don't blame me."  His counterpart, upon delivering the $180 check for an anniversary dinner for two, had another object of blame: Us.  "We offered to comp your desserts but you didn't want any, so... "   When you compare this to the absolute graciousness of the staff like L'Ardoise it's easy to decide when to revenir au Bistro Central Parc - jamais.
author: Tim M.

description: Reeeaally great food! The muscles alone are worth the trip! We had the French onion soup, which was very good also, the bouillabaisse, fillet minion, and creme brulee! Great service and atmosphere.
author: Jamie S.

description:
Oh my goodness. This place is amazing. We had come here on a last minute ditch to try out some foie gras before the ban. SO happy that we stopped by here, despite the terrible parking in this neighborhood.

FOOD
- Brie with potato & salad: was amazing! The salad itself was so fresh that it's changed my whole view on how "fresh salad". The textures of the rich brie and potato was nicely balanced out with the lightness of the salad. It turned out to be a great combo
- Sweet breads with mushrooms: I swear for the longest time, i couldn't figure out what the bread was (I wasn't the one who ordered the food). It was so soft and so delicious, I had my speculations on it being a type of meat? Hey, give me a break, I was super sleep deprived, okay? But if you pick an appetizer, I highly recommend this dish! 
- Foie gras: now now, i know foie gras is officially banned from being purchased, but I have to speak about how great this dish was. Yes, this is considered a form of torture. The foie was so rich and had that hard to pinpoint savory taste to it. Then when you got tired of how rich the foie was, you had the other components to balance out the flavor. So this is what went down. One bite foie gras, went to foodie heaven, had a bite of the potatoes, then went the taste buds were happy, then another bite of foie gras, went to heaven AGAIN. 

I swear my tastebuds were so happy after that dinner! I would definitely go again!
author: Stacy X.

description: We had a wonderful dinner here last night. Everything was great, from the french onion soup to a delicious warm strawberry dessert.  Our waiter was Kyle and he was delightful. We stretched out our dinner but the restaurant made us feel very welcome and did not try to rush us. The owner is super friendly and relaxed.  We look forward to going back.
author: Karen H.

description:
I had no idea this place even existed right in front of my nose.  Granted it's in a somewhat unique location in Nopa on the corner of Grove/Central ... but I'm still not quite sure how I missed this charming little bistro.

We came for a celebratory dinner (thank you!) and I loved the neighborhood feel of the place.  Unpretentious and authentic (French), the menu is hearty and well-executed.

For starters, we had the daily appetizer special - spicy squid salad served with frisee.  The presentation could have been a little nicer but taste-wise, it really was nice.  We also had a side of the ratatouille, which was just ok (I guess we had imagined more of a stew/soup rather than sauteed veggies (peppers, onions, squash) served on a long plate.  The pommes frites, however, were piping hot, satisfyingly crunchy and perfect.

For mains, my filet mignon was good (although clearly more medium than the medium rare I requested.  Served atop potato gratin and with a green peppercorn sauce.  Pretty good and not too large of a dish (although plenty enough to make you full, I'd say).

I had a few bites also of the beef cheeks entree, which I actually preferred.  The tender beef was amazing.

For dessert, the special - cherry and pistachio bread pudding was better than I expected ... definitely recommend it.

We had a nice bottle of Bordeaux (2010 Chateau Saint Andre Corbin).  Not a huge wine aficionado but no complaints here!

Service is casual yet attentive.  I'd like to return to check out other items and maybe also come back for brunch.
author: F. P.

description: I had high expectations for this restaurant but the service alone ensured we won't be coming back.  After being seated at the bar at 6pm we sat for almost 15 minutes with out being acknowledged.  The busser was on the other side of the bar doing roll ups, wouldn't look up at us, no one even stopped by to say that they would be with us shortly.  One of the waiters finally came over, briefly took our drink order...took quite some time for him to come back, still no waters offered.  Then another couple was seated at the bar and another server was right with them, and then offered his services to us.  We were ready for our check, waited another 10 minutes, my husband had his credit card down for quite some time, even the hostess saw that his card was down and nothing.  I feel like all the staff didn't work together, maybe they were understaffed, but there was no cohesiveness.  We won't be back.
author: Brye L.

description:
Our meal was amazing! From the charcuterie and kobe beef tartare, to incredible entrees (rack of lamb, beef cheeks, breast of duck, filet mignon, risotto with lobster sauce and scallops and more) with intense flavors and thoughtful presentations, to phenomenal desserts and fantastic wines. Simply perfection. The service was remarkable; we were a group of eight and our server didn't miss a beat, always with a smile and great attitude.

We were fortunate to have the owner come and sit with us. She was warm, charming, and upbeat, much like the restaurant itself. I'm looking forward to returning to this neighborhood gem for brunch and many more lovely meals!
author: Victoria S.

description: I've held my tongue about this place as I wanted to support my local businesses and lots of people like it here. I'm writing about brunch, I don't get here for dinner. The worse thing is for a restaurant and its staff not to care, to accept 'sufficient" as a benchmark and to treat well meaning local customers apathetically. On my last visit it was the owner sniping at us about our order. This time the experience was so mundane, the food so run of the mill and the service so bland it convinced my partner and I to never return. It's a block from our apartment and all we want is a pleasant brunch. Boring isn't part of our wish. So, you don't serve bread for brunch. Ok. You didn't even try to make your French toast offering to be special or delicious. It wasn't. And I should have made my croque Monsour at home. I could do it better. Brunch has always seemed like an after thought here, perhaps an obligation. We hoped a change in ownership would make this visit better. It didn't. This visit just convinced is to make it our last.
author: Richard A.

description:
The service is impeccable! No wait at 5:30PM on a Friday. But reservations are still highly recommended!

For starters, the duck confit salad with goat cheese and bacon dressing is nice. Definitely ordering it again. The mussels were so so; ok but not mind blowing.

They serve complimentary dinner roll HOT out of the oven. Which is a plus!

MUST TRY THE BEEF CHEEKS with red beet puree!! SOOOO GOOOOOOD!!!! I've never have had beef cheeks before but this blows it out of the water of what anyone thinks beef cheeks are. It's fall off the bone tender (w/o the bone lol) and melts in your mouth like BUTTER! I'm absolutely coming back for this. The size of this dish was unbelievable; my friend and I couldn't even finish it. Fit for 3 to eat!

The menu is great. But their SPECIALS for the day are even better. It's an entire menu of its own with like 8 additional dishes!!

Great selection of desserts: poached pear, flambéed strawberries with ice cream, profiteroles, creme brulee, petit fours, chocolate lava cake, ice cream sundae.

However, the creme brûlée was a disappointment. I always order the creme brûlée no matter where I go but this was not silken smooth and creamy as others I have had.

Overall, definitely coming back. And coming back soon!!
author: Keiko C.

description: We came here to celebrate my birthday and had a wonderful time. Ordered the French onion soup, baked Brie with garlic, curry mussels (so good), and scallops risotto (get it). There's also a fantastic wine selection to choose from! The host was so nice and made the entire evening so wonderful. The owner also gave us a little gift for celebrating a special occasion with them.
author: Christina C.

description:
A French Restaurant that does not serve French bread. If you like onion soup, forget this souless $11 ripoff. 
The main course, poulet, roti was good..We had to ask for extra sauce, since one
came fine, but my friend was given less..
The waiters were okay, one was dressed to go camping, a bit strange at a 
French restaurant.
author: David A.

description: Conveniently located across the street from my friend's apartment, this is a great neighborhood french restaurant.  We went for dinner, and were greeted by friendly owner and staff with french accents throughout dinner, oui oui!  My friend ordered her usual, and quite delicious scallop risotto, and I ordered a special on the menu - pork belly with mashed potatoes, though I was in a pasta mood, and they were very accomodating and switched in al dente penne pasta, with garlic, parsmean, and fresh herbs... yum.  The pork belly and the wine reduced sauce was porkalicious, but you have to love pork fat.  Paired with a glass of champagne, we had a very nice dinner and enjoyed the cozy atmosphere.  The only issue I had was it took awhile for the bread to arrive, but I was happy that it was served warm and fresh.
author: Nova P.

description:
Positively "meh." 

Neither my wife, nor I were please with anything we got. The duck was so-so and the lamb was just a slight step above "ok." We much preferred Chez Papa, which was considerably better.
author: Joel F.

description:
Bistro Central Parc is one of the top restaurants in all of San Francisco. This quaint French bistro is authentic and worth every penny.

The ambiance and decor of the place istasteful, humble, and classy. The folks that run the restaurant are cordial and polite and, on most nights, work the door and graciously welcome all guests who enter.

The food is delicious, I have gone back 5 times and it is always consistent. The escargot is exquisite, the french onion soup a lip-smacking treat, and the steak frites is always a safe bet. 

The only flaw would be it is on the pricier side... but what good true French restaurant in San Francisco isn't.
author: Caleb M.

description: Bistro Central Parc is my absolute favorite place for lunch/dinner as their service is excellent and the food even more so. Highly recommend the pork chops. Parking is tricky on the weekends but the restaurant is worth it.
author: Patrick P.

description:
My mother has a strong opinion on everything.  According to her, because she's my mother, she is the only one who will tell me the "real" "truth" "everytime."  For example, the day before yesterday, we were browsing wedding gowns online.  Not looking for anything specific, just getting an idea of what is out there.  I clicked on a link and scrolled through the options.  

My mother immediately said, "These are not representative of what the dress will look like on you.  These models are all tall, willowy and slender.  Of course the dresses look nice on them.  For you, you should look at PLUS SIZE BRIDAL GOWNS.  That would be a more realistic example for you."  Oh mother.  I love you and all your opinions.  

The very same day, I had reservations at Bistro Central Parc.  I can always count on good French food to have lots of butter.  I love butter and salt.  Luckily, I dined with a cardiologist that evening who was carefully monitoring my butter/salt/wine intake (high/high/very low).  Marina and Vic have been here more regularly than I, even though I live the closest.  It was walking distance from my residence.  I walked it in anticipation of the heart attack.  

We were seated in the quiet corner near the back.  The front of the restaurant was bustling and got crowded as people arrived and their table was not ready yet.  Our fault, really.  We had a really nice meal and really great conversation.  I told the story of my engagement.  And I consider myself the foremost expert on all things relationship and getting-along.  

For appetizers, we ordered: mushroom risotto, escargot, trio of foie gras, kobe beef tartare.  The trio of foie gras kept Marina so happy.  Her face lit up when the waiter described it.  It was one generous slice seared served atop a poached pear, one tourchon pate, and one macaroon with foie gras filling.  I had the beef tartare and the escargot.  The beef tartare was a very generous serving, at least 3 oz.  The seasoning was mixed in already with the exception of the quail egg which was resting on top for a beautiful presentation.  It was served with toast and a small salad of frisee which I had to wrestle to fold-n-stuff into my mouth.  There's no lady here.  Vic polished off the mushroom risotto without the slightest complaint.  The escargot was the weakest part of the appetizers.  It needed salt.  And it didn't have the same ka-pow as I remember escargot to have.  

For entrees, I got the mussels marinieres.  Marina got the scallop risotto, Vic got the special filet mignon with foie gras on top.  The mussels were in a rich cream and wine sauce.  It was so delicious and the mussels were so fresh that I could smell the salty sea air and the wind blowing on my face, as though I was by the ocean.  Marina loved her risotto.  It had lobster sauce so I did not try it.  Vic's filet mignon was bathed in a beautiful sauce.  I dipped a frite in the sauce and swore that I would get it next time.  

For dessert we got the special which was this huge plate of lots of different dessert elements together, with a macaroon.  Lots of nuts, to my chagrin.  

The crowning glory, the reason this place is my special place forever and ever: when I didn't finish my mussels and asked to have the mussels and frites packed to-go, the waiter did not hear my request for the mussels to be packed.  He THREW THEM AWAY.  When he informed me of this mishap, I looked like I was about to cry.  War crimes.  Atrocity.  Violence against mussels.  But I said "that's fine" and tried to console myself.  A few moments later, the waiter presented me with a heavy white box and said he was so sorry for the mistake, he had the kitchen make up a NEW BATCH FOR ME TO TAKE HOME.  My heart leapt.  I was so happy.  My smile lit up the western hemisphere.  

The dinner experience went above and beyond my expectations.  It made me feel special, loved, singular, and bathed in buttery goodness.  Whenever the wind blows, I will always hear it whisper "Bistro Central Parc Mussels."
author: Christina C.

description: We live in the neighborhood so we started frequenting Bistro a couple of years ago. The food and staff are fantastic, especially, Zarina - who is our favorite server. The whole team is wonderful, and we never get tired of going back - over and over again. Given that San Francisco is the food capital of the United States, that says something!
author: Ellie T.

description: Great spot for brunch. Yummy food and very nice waitstaff. We forgot an envelope while we were there, and they were nice enough to send it for us!
author: Bryan K.

description:
It's been about 8 years since I've ventured off to Paris, France and far too long to not have even tried to attempt French Cuisine on American soil. At least...until my boyfriend managed to stumble upon Bistro Central Parc.

It's a really intimate place, but if you're not seated at a booth it feels a bit cramped. Not only that, I think it was a little too dark for my taste, that it made it kind of hard to read the menu sometimes. My boyfriend and I decided to try the beef tartar, which was seasoned pretty good, but I'm not much of a fan because tartar isn't really my cup of tea. I had the risotto with lobster sauce and scallops for my entree, which was really delicious and just the right portion because sometimes risotto can be a bit heavy. The scallops were seared to perfection and the sauce was amazing! 

I would definitely come back, because the food really reminded me of Paris and I like how super friendly and welcoming all of the staff were, including the owner.
author: Alexis A.

description: Jacques, and his restaurant, are delightful. Great ambiance, food, and wine. Amazing!
author: Erika G.

description: Like the food, typically like the wait staff, but had an issue with one waitress there recently.  She seemed so put out to seat us I couldn't believe it.  When we were ordering she walked away and helped another table and came back and said, "go ahead".  And no I wasn't taking forever to order.  When she brought the food, she actually dropped the plates in front of us like it was crap.  However, when she brought the check that was when the magic began.  She walks up the to table with a s**t eating grin (first time she came close to smiling all evening) and placed the check on the table like it was GOLD!!  Voila!!!  Really annoying  - so much so I took the time to write this review.
author: John E.

description:
"You should take me out on a nice date this weekend," she says over IM while we are at work on a Tuesday. Only a few months in and I'm already at the point where I need to be reminded to step it up in the romance department. Not a good sign.

Never one to trust my own instincts in this area, I turn to the all-knowing Yelp search algorithms to help me recover from my extended period of coasting. I want something a little pricey so she knows I care, but not expensive enough that it looks like I'm trying too hard... $$$ sounds about right. And what about cuisine? You can't go wrong with French, they always seem to have the most seductive foods. An OpenTable reservation would probably be a good idea - nothing kills the mood faster than a 90 minute wait for a table. And obviously I need a place that's well reviewed. There's no way I'm taking a chance on that sub-four star spot tonight. With this fairly strict set of criteria, my best option seems to be a place called Bistro Central Parc. I've never even heard of the joint, but it looks like it could work.

Fast forward to the weekend: We arrive to find a cute, bustling bistro that has delicious aromas wafting out the door and a waiting crowd. Things are looking good so far. We are soon seated at a table right by the entrance. It's maybe the second worst seat in the house (the spot right in front of the front window is worse), but it wouldn't be too bad if there wasn't a party of 15 waiting to be seated across from us for a birthday dinner. They are all standing around their table instead of sitting, presumably in some sort of competition to see who is the going to cave and sit down first like a wimp. They stand for most of the night. They are also enthusiastically speaking only in French even though none of them seem to speak it fluently. There is a lot of repeating parts of conversations, each time spoken louder than the time before, as if the problem is that they are butchering their French too quietly.

Before I can let "le parti des idiots" ruin my romantic evening the server brings our food out. You know that feeling you get when you are staring so intently at your lover that the rest of the world just fades out and it's just you and them and every other person could just vanish off the face of the earth and you wouldn't even notice? Well that's how it is with me and the braised beef cheeks. Everyone raves about the filet mignon, but the braised beef is not to be missed. I'm pretty sure my girlfriend is also enjoying her meal, but you'll have to ask her. I don't even remember what she had, that's how into the braised beef I am. The portions here are surprisingly large for French food, and I'm not complaining one bit. The crème brûlée (accents added so that you know I'm serious about crème brûlée) is especially large, and was surely designed to be shared. Get it and do that thing where you pretend you are splitting it down the middle but you each secretly are eating from each other's half so you can eat more.

By the time we wander out of the restaurant two hours later, we are stuffed and happy. I can probably coast for another few weeks now.
author: Mark A.

description:
Stopped by for brunch with three friends this morning.

I had an spinach and salmon omelette while also sharing french toast with the table.

The omelette was cooked just right - not too raw and not overcooked. The french toast was even better. Served with real maple syrup, creme fraiche, and fruit, it was a simply delicious dish.

The waitstaff was friendly, although the decor wasn't anything special. Definitely a great neighborhood joint that I'll be frequenting often in my new 'hood.
author: Naeem I.

description: Just had a tasty half order of French toast with smoked salmon.  Very yummy--so glad I came in for brunch but now I need a nap!!
author: C L.

description:
The food here is excellent. The service is attentive and friendly. The portions generous and the prices unbelievable for the quality. I made a reservation on a Friday afternoon through Open Table and got an 8:30 p.m. reservation for 2 same day. I was a bit nervous we'd have to wait as I've heard it gets crowded, but our table was waiting for us when we arrived. 

I ordered the sweetbreads appetizer and my wife the escargot. Both dishes were excellent. The texture of escargot was right-on, not chewy like they sometimes can be. These were melt-in-your-mouth snails. And the sweetbreads were just as tender. For our entrees my wife had the rossini special. The foie gras was excellent. I had the rack of lamb. It was stellar. Perfect temperature, large portion, delicious (and for around $20). All the dishes had sauce on the side in little pitchers so nothing was drenched and you could portion to taste.

We finished the meal with the cheese plate. (Four cheeses, large portions.) And a bottle of the relatively unknown Loupiac dessert wine. It was nice to find such a well-priced rarity on a dessert wine list in a corner bistro. 

This restaurant is an amazing addition to the neighborhood. I'm glad it's off the beaten path, or you'd never get a table.
author: Jason G.

description:
Good neighborhood style French. Like a joint you'd find anywhere in Paris (limited menu but all made very well in trad french style). Like most good French restaurants they focus on the quality of food - not the baloney that goes with it. 

Also, the service is outstanding and led by the owner himself - he's always come over to say hello to us. The personal touch goes along way.
author: Paul V.

description:
This place has good ass brunch.  Good brunch is not easily done!

I really want to try it out for dinner.  These are the same folks that run Baker St. Bistro, which also has good brunch but definitely showing its age.  Central Parc is like an update of it.
author: Erika C.

description: I am so fortunate to live within a couple of blocks of this neighborhood gem.  The food is awesome, the service is friendly, and the prices are reasonable.  Generally, I opt for authentic Italian or Spanish restaurants over French, having found the last to be pretentious and pricey without reason more often than not.  Bistro Central Parc is exceptional, in every sense of that word.
author: Bob S.

description:
An undiscovered gem in the Western Addition, Bistro Central Parc turns out authentic and tasty, yet reasonably priced, French fare.

Upon entering, patrons are treated to minimalist, urban chic decor--trimmings that do not detract from the artful presentation and fantastic, rich flavors of the food.  Tables are set rather close together, so don't plan on discussing anything deep with your dining partner, lest your neighbors are advised of the most intimate details of your life.  The noise level is a little high, but that's because diners are busy exclaiming how good the food is.

Dressed sparingly, but flavorfully, a simple mixed green salad ($7.50) highlighted the freshness of the produce.  Rich with butter and white wine, moules marinieres (steamed mussels, $12.50) were delicious, while the accompanying pommes frites (French fries) were wonderfully light and crispy.  Architecturally presented in a soaring tower, tournedos Rossini (beef pan-fried in butter served on a bed of scalloped potatoes and topped with a slice of foie gras, $19.50) was rich with slices of black truffle and finished with a deep Madeira demi-glace sauce.

Service was spot on.  Water glasses were always filled, dishes arrived promptly, but not so fast as to rush the diners, and more wine was never far away.

While limited in scope, the wine list featured a sufficient number of offerings to adequately complement any of the delicious French dishes on the menu.  By the glass selections did not break the bank ($9-$10), nor did bottles did not carry a sky high markup.

With the profusion of TV chefs and mega-restaurants owned by "personalities," it is gratifying to see that there are local establishments that still offer fine food at reasonable prices in The City.  Skip the Michelin-starred, over priced pilgramage to gastronomy, and save yourself the airfare to Paris; visit Bistro Central Parc for soulfully produced Gallic fare.
author: CJ G.

description:
I came here with my wife for our anniversary dinner and it's the best decision I've ever made (besides marrying my wife...lol). Food was fantastic, price was affordable and service was excellent!! Can't wait to go next time!

Ps: Try their Wagyu Beef Tartare... amazing!
author: P C.

description: Nothing fancy, but it was good. Fresh and very french food.
author: Rodrigo D.

description:
Came here with the gf for date night
cozy little restaurant, modern decor
great service
she ordered the risotto with scallops. "Best risotto she ever had".... at the time
i ordered the chicken which was on top of mash potatoes and spinach. pretty damn good
we started off with beef tartar. i personally liked it, gf cringe at raw beef
overall great dinner
ordered a salad, caesar i believe. pretty good as well

would definitely come back
author: Andi I.

description: This my favorite French Bistro. It is a bonus that it is within walking distance of my home. I love to hear their specials, but I almost always order the mussels with pomme frites. Have never been disappointed.
author: carolyne c.

description:
What a cozy neighborhood joint! 

Order the risotto: to-die-for.
author: Alexander M.

description:
Where do I start!!! One of the restaurants I'll definitely visit again. Amazing ambiance, super tasty food and very friendly staff. One thing that I loved about the place was the owner coming over to say hello. You don't see that often. Definitely earned the place some brownie points.
No surprises here that the French Onion Soup was simply delightful.
Everyone who loves seafood must try out the bouillabaisse. It is exquisite.
Will go there to try out other dishes
One of the few French Bistros out there. A tad bit pricey but the great food and friendly people are definitely worth it.
author: Michael R.

description:
Great French cuisine, with a touch of California creativity. 
Very good magre de canard, as well as beef cheek in red beet sauce. Really real authentic tart tatin - delicious, with a friendly service in a hipster atmosphere
author: Sergei B.

description:
I walked over here for brunch yesterday and thoroughly enjoyed it.  It's a very quaint spot in a mostly residential neighborhood.

I had heard good things about the French toast, so I ordered that.  In the meantime, I had coffee, which was good, but not stellar, and orange juice, which was being "squeezed" right in front of me and was amazing, as most freshly squeezed orange juice is.  The woman using the orange juicer was (I think) from France (?) or at least lived there for a while.  She spoke English with a slight accent and spoke French very well and mentioned being in France a couple of times.  Very friendly.

The French toast was thick-cut toast, which I think is probably harder to cook to perfection.  It was good, and thoroughly drenched (I hate dry French toast!), but a bit undercooked in the middle.  Dipped in the crème fraîche it was quite good (is anything dipped in crème fraîche bad?), but still not on par with Baker Street Bistro, which uses thinner bread.  The fresh fruit was good as well, although I would have preferred larger cuts.

Anyway, overall it was a very good brunch and I'll return, both for brunch as well as to try their other meals.
author: Christian D.

description: We had beef cheek and scallops. They are great and the portion is just nice, you can have a great dinner without worrying about your figure :)
author: Huifang L.

description: Absolutely delicious. The beet and goat cheese purée was amazing!
author: Katie D.

description:
We had never been here, and decided on it due to Yelp reviews and the fact that they had a table for two open on a last minute reservation

It turned out to be a fantastic evening, starting with the owner, who greeted us at the door and helped direct us to parking (we found street parking nearby, but there is also a Lucky store with parking underneath which we may utilize in the future).  The evening continued on a positive trend, with a great waiter (the owners nephew), who I let direct my meal choices (I like surprises).  The owner came over a few times to engage in conversation.  

For appetizers, I had the wild mushroom risotto, which was packed full of flavor.  My husband had a cauliflower soup -- good, although not amazing.  My entree was a special - lamb sirloin with roasted brussels sprouts and squash -- scrumptious flavors!  My husband had the filet on the regular menu, also very good.
