For desert, I'm gluten-free, so I opted for the poached pear -- very yummy, and my husband had the to-die-for lava cake.  Oh yeah, and we had an awesome bottle of cabernet for $40.  Prices were very reasonable.

I loved the neighborhood feel of the restaurant, the friendliness of the staff, the quality of the food, and the value.  We have recommended to our friends to live in SF, and will be back ourselves!
author: Margie E.

description:
Tiny and crowded with lots of personal attention from the owner. 

My data and I had a lovely evening here.
author: Rick S.

description:
Very cozy restaurant with super friendly staff. The head chef greeted us at the door and profusely thanked us at the end of our lovely meal. We dined at 6:00 on a Sunday and the place was packed. Parking, as others noted, is not great in the area.

I had butternut squash soup (yummy, very thick and flavorful), heirloom salad with crusted polenta (polenta was bland but the tomatoes were wonderful and ripe) and wild mushroom risotto (mushrooms were a nice sliced blend and the risotto was a tab al dente). I'd definitely come back for a casual, romantic dinner with the hubby another night.
author: Jennee D.

description:
I used to love Baker Street Bistro, my friend told me that they changed owner, and the owner opened this place, Jack I believe is the owner name. 

Parking - HORRIBLE. Last time I was here we had to go around for 30 mins before finding parking. This time the wait was 40 mins. 

Seats - Standard, tables a bit close to each other. 

Service - 
We only called 15 mins before arrival, the wait wasn't long at all. The server who I believe may be related to Jack was very nice, helpful, friendly, and sorta good looking (not that it mattered). 

The waits between food were a bit too long for me that night--I had a flight to catch--but in the normal circumstances around 2 hrs for a four courses meal seems fine. 

Food - Everything was above avg, except the lamb shank. 

(Appetizer)
French Onion Soup - Simply amazing. This is one of the best I've ever had (and I've had many since it's one of my brother's favorite soups) 

Grilled brie and potato cake on salad - Not a big fan of brie, the potato cake was avg, but the salad was very tasty. 

Grilled mussels in white wine cream sauce - Tasty! I always prefer the smaller mussels over the bigger one, perfectly done, very tender and the sauce was tasty (I ate a piece of bread just dipping it in the sauce). 

(Main)
Lamb Shank - It was very "sheepy".. I didn't like it. 

Scallop, lobster sauce, risotto - Delicious. There were three medium size scallops, very tender and still had the seafood sweetness. Risotto was perfectly done. The sauce complimented very well with the dish. 

(Dessert)
Poached Pear - I used to love their poached pear, I've to admit I was very disappointed as they changed the recipe and I no longer can have the taste I remembered. They used to poach it with wine and serve with ice cream. Now they pour chocolate over it and the pear itself lack the sweet sophisticated taste I once had. 

Cream Brulee - Standard. The "brulee" was a bit too thick so instead of crisp it was a bit hard and chewy. I didn't like the texture of the "cream" itself neither. 

Overall the foods were above average and the prices were more than reasonable. I will come back.
author: Pauline N.

description:
My hubby and I came here for date night to relive our honeymoon in France, and we were blown away.

Tucked away in a residential area, Bistro Central Parc is a true neighborhood restaurant. It's cozy unpretentious atmosphere and friendly service made us feel right at home. Not to mention their food is seriously amazing.

Food: Usually, I write in order of deliciousness but everything was yummy. So I'll just lay it out chronologically. 
-Potato pancakes with melted brie & arugula: Potato pancakes were crispy on the outside, soft on the inside with a slice of soft brie melted on top. Arugula provided a nice bitter contrast.
-Scallop risotto in lobster sauce: Hands down the best scallops I've ever had. Ever. It was melt in your mouth buttery goodness. The lobster sauce was so perfect, I could have had it alone as a lobster bisque. To be honest, the risotto was a bit undercooked and starchy but the scallop and lobster sauce made it for it and then some. 
-Lamb chops: I'm not a big fan of lamb but this blew me away. It was cooked to medium rare perfection, and wasn't gamey in the least.

After dinner, we took a romantic walk through the park. It's not the fanciest park, but it was quiet and peaceful. 

If you're looking for something fancy and expensive, this is not your place. But if you want authentic delicious French food, Bistro Central Parc is THE place to go.
author: Connie C.

description:
We've been here already a few times and it was perfect every time. 
Of you're really craving French cuisine that comes close to a Bistro in Paris: this is the place to go! The meals are excellent and are true eye candies! 
The staff is super-friendly and gives excellent advice if you're struggling with making a choice. 

Little hint: Open Table seems not to be reliable at this place. Calling them to make the reservation is the way to go! 

I don't know why it still is quite easy to get a table on short notice. The restaurant is truly amazing. So, please disregard this review. Hopefully it will remain a 'secret' (just kidding).
author: John D.

description: Very good service and wonderful food. The peppercorn filet was amazingly tender and had a strong peppercorn taste that I love! The fries were also very good and crispy on the outside. The seafood Paella special was also very fresh and flavorful. Great little spot for a casual yet elegant dinner.
author: L V.

description:
Came here for a dear girlfriend's birthday.  Cute place in the mist of a residential neighborhood. Waiting for our party of 8 to arrive i can see that the patrons are mostly neighborhood regulars, the host knew many by name and greeted them with hugs. Nice. 

The dinner rolls were warm, which is always pleasing. We ordered a nice round of appetizers. Heirloom tomatoes with goat cheese. Stuffed calamari. Mussels in white wine sauce. All very yummy. French onion soup (not as flavorful as expected per sis). 

For main course I had the lamb over chocolate braised lentils. So good! So good I didn't really pay attention much to what others ate. Except the scallop over risotto with lobster sauce... The presentation was beautiful and risotto was buttery and amazing. 
All in all...cute place. Awesome food. Reasonable prices. Definitely worth a few repeats. But...parking's a bitch.
author: Winnie Y.

description: I had the pleasure of celebrating my sister in laws birthday on Thursday August 6, 2015 at this charming French Bistro. The food was amazing, service friendly and attentive. I just spent Christmas in Paris visiting my daughter who was studying abroad in France and can't wait to bring her here when she comes home. It reminded me of Cafe Constant on Rue Saint-Dominique in 7th arrondissement. Same casual atmosphere and incredible menu. My favorite was the duck confit and beef cheeks, although the Filet and Paella specials were exceptional as well. Very impressed with the wine list. Our waiter Alex was very knowledgeable and suggested wines that met our large party of 8 varied dinner choices. Looking forward to my next trip to San Franciso with friends. Will definitely be back to Bisto Central Parc.
author: Deanne G.

description:
This place is fantastic. The service was good and friendly. The restaurant is clean. Unfortunately it was a T Mobile dead zone for me. 
Onto the food, 
French Onion Soup: nice burnt taste of the cheese covered the savory soup. It was not very salty, which was good. 
Lobster risotto was great. Very al dente. Topped with magnificently seared scallops, great texture. 
Pasta of the day: penne pasta with salmon and spinach. It had just the right amount of cream sauce. I wouldve liked to have more spinach. Still delicious.
Bouillabaisse: the soup is delicious. The fish cooked just enough to still taste raw and fresh. The scallops were even more delicious in this dish. Nothing tasted overcooked. 
Its all about street parking here, luckily, there aren't a lot of hills around the restaurant.
author: Steven T.

description:
I was so excited to drive by a few days ago and see people inside of this place! I've been watching this space ever sense I moved to the neighborhood 4 years ago to see what was going to be moving in there, finally the wait is over!

My friend and I went from brunch this morning and LOVED it!

I had a cappuccino and Eggs Florentine and my friend had the Salmon Benedict and a cafe au lait. Both came with breakfast potatoes and a little salad.  The holandaise sauce was light and the flavors went perfect with the spinach.  

I loved how clean and light the space is and the fresh flowers throughout.  Plus, the service could not have been better.

I cannot wait to go back for dinner!
author: Erica S.

description:
Wow, if it weren't for the gift certificate my family received for Christmas from my uncle we would have never found this place. Let's just say French food isn't a frequent visitor to the palate of our family (primarily because none of us have been exposed to it), but it was a delight to try something new.

We made reservations for 6pm on a Friday evening and it was pretty quiet when we arrived. We were promptly acknowledged and seated when we were asked if we preferred a bottle of still or sparkling water. We asked for sparkling -- little did we realize at the time until glancing at the menu that it was a $7 decision -- no matter it was a family dinner after all.

APPETIZERS:
- Escargots bourguignon (garlic and parsley butter $10): It was the first time for my little brother and I trying escargot. For 6 pieces, it was just okay. It honestly tasted like chewy pesto. It wasn't bad, but it wasn't too memorable either.
- Moules marinieres (Mussels , white wine, shallots , parsley, cream. $12.50) YOU. MUST. HAVE. THESE. Honestly it was probably the highlight of the entire meal. The broth is absolutely fantastic, and as others noted, you must ask for more bread to soak up the goodness. They were a bit small, but BCP makes up in volume. I counted 27/28 shells for the order. In terms of value, the mussels couldn't be beat.
- Pommes frites (french fries $5): The waitress recommended this to soak up the Mussel broth. Yum.

ENTREES:
- Risotto aux coquilles St Jacques (Risotto, lobster sauce, scallops $22): Very generous with the scallops. Probably tied for the best scallops I've ever had in my life. Perfectly cooked. The risotto was just okay by itself, but with the scallops they were the perfect combination! I had the best entree. :)
- Carré d'agneau, ratatouille (Rack of lamb with rosemary fleur de sel 
 and ratatouille $24): Little brother and mom both had the rack of lamb. I guess you could use the term "rack"  loosely, because it was two pieces (albeit perfectly cooked medium rare) Neither of them were too fond of the ratatouille. Too much tomato in their opinion.
- Filet mignon (green peppercorn sauce, Potato gratin $24): The older brother and dad ordered meat (of course). My dad's came cooked perfectly at medium rare. On the other hand my brother's was a bit underdone. He asked for medium rare and it was definitely too rare for him. We sent it back to have it re-fired. Unfortunately it came back still underdone. My brother was hungry, so he dug in anyways. He'd eaten about 2/3 of it when the owner came back to check on the meat. Unfortunately we showed him it was still undercooked, but it was fine since he'd eaten 2/3 of it. He took the plate without a word and walked back towards the kitchen. Uh-oh, hopefully we didn't get the cook in trouble. :( The owner brought back the thrice-fired fillet (with a new potato gratin) replated. I guess third times the charm because it was (finally) medium rare.

DESSERT:
- Creme Brulee ($7.50): Definitely in my top 3 creme brulees I've ever had and it was a perfect size for sharing.

Our server was very apologetic about the filet mignon ordeal that she comped one of the orders, so it was a nice gesture. Overall we had a great family meal trying (and enjoying) a different type of food that we would otherwise not ever tried.

Great place for a date and hope to be back soon!
author: Jenna H.

description:
This place is crazy .. crazy good! 

Came here a while back with a couple of friends.. I was absolutely wow'ed by everything. We had the filet mignon with the foie gras on top, the lobster rissotto, the boullabaise, mussels, and the grand finale of all desserts - lava cake.

The lava cake was the most beautiful dessert I've seen in while.
As of now this is my favorite French restaurant in SF.
author: Catalina C.

description: Visiting San Francisco and heard this was a great place. Went with four friends and didn't make a reservation, but was able to get outside seating. Their outside seating isn't too uncomfortable as it is heated and enclosed, but it gets pretty crammed if you are dining with a party larger than four. I had the Risotto aux coquilles St Jacques and it was great. The lobster sauce really made it, and the scallops were cooked perfectly. Simple dish, yet a lot of flavor. A safe dish if you are not sure what to get. Also a more filling dish than I presumed it would be. My friend started off with the French onion soup, which looked great as well. This restaurant was a little more pricey than I am used to, but worth it. The service was ehhh, our server was attentive to our needs but on the other hand had little to no personality. Overall good experience.
author: Michele U.

description: Delicious! Came here on a double date and ordered the heirloom tomato salad (special) for started as well as the fish of the day which was a pistachio encrusted halibut with cauliflower puree. The salad was good but the fish was amazing. It melted in my mouth and was easily washed down with our two bottles of rose. The wine was a little pricey ($45/bottle) which is why I'm not giving this place 5 stars. Service was good, food was divine but wine too marked up.
author: Margot M.

description:
A bistro is, in its original Parisian incarnation, a small restaurant serving moderately priced simple meals in a modest setting. 

My fellow yelpers,  this bistro is worth experiencing.

This restaurant has the intimate-friendly-neighborhood-spot on lockdown. The crowd keeps the place bustling and loud, but in some sense you feel special just eating at one of the tables.

The food is moderately priced, no entree was more than $24, the wine list shares that moderation. The service is two-notches down from fine dining, but this is a bistro - so it makes sense. 

If you're looking for the classic, French dining experience with white linen-tables and 4 waiters, don't waste your time looking for a parking spot. But if you want to try a delicious risotto in lobster sauce with scallops, and enjoy a casual relaxed dinner with friends, BCP is worth your visit.
author: Brett W.

description:
I had brunch here in Saturday around 11am. The place wasn't too full, which was great because, unlike most other brunch places in this city, we could actually hear each other talk!

The orange juice was delicious, definitely freshly squeezed which made for a great start.  I ordered the croque Monsieur, which was really good.  It had just the right amount of everything. Nothing was too heavy or overwhelming. The accompanying greens were quite salty when eaten alone, but was much more balanced when eaten with the croque. I liked that the plate came with plenty of cornichons to cut the richness of the croque too.

Croques were a popular dish at my table of 7. One person got the French toast, which wasn't very sweet (a good thing!) and another ordered the frisée with poached eggs, most likely so he wouldn't feel as guilty ordering a side of potatoes. 

I don't drink coffee, but I hear it was quite good as one person in my party had a sip of someone else's, and then ordered her own coffee she liked it so much.

The service was good and friendly, though it dropped off a bit toward the end as the place filled up.  Prices are very reasonable.  

Definitely a cute hidden gem type of place considering it seems more like a neighborhood restaurant than a "destination" restaurant in the city.
author: Naoko M.

description: I'm disappointed to write such a poor review. This only applies to the service I experienced which started off rude and improved to mildly indifferent throughout the evening even with my trying to be friendly and thankful. I suppose I can conclude that the server was going for a stereotypical French experience:/ I've waited tables and bar tended for 7 years at fine dining restaurants (Ruth's Chris, Vic Stweart's) and was amazed at the lack of personality/professionalism from my server. Not one smile all night. Rude about the wine selection and actually tersely corrected a question I asked about a certain varietal. Opened the wine like I would expect at an Olive Garden (bottle on the table spinning it around rather than keeping it in his hand with the label stationary) which I wouldn't minded one bit had he not been so presumptuous about pointing out my lack of knowledge about wine. The food was very good. The atmosphere was also great. The hostess who seated me was sweet and set the tone for a potentially lovely evening. My only complaint is the service which unfortunately plays a huge part in the experience. Maybe he was having a bad day but that's not really a good excuse. And with 2 servers covering 10 tables I would hope that he wasn't very slammed. I won't be back and was sorry to have gone at all.
author: foodandwine b.

description:
It feels like Paris. Real Paris, not the movie set. A lot of it is attitude: the staff seems to be mostly French. They expect you to ask questions about the menu. They like it if you ask for a wine recommendation. They expect you to spend a couple of hours having dinner, so you will not expect your food to come out in a New York minute.

In traditional European restaurants, they have fewer seatings than in US restaurants. You can go to a movie or out to dinner, not both. The focus is on enjoying the company of your dining companions and sharing the enjoyment of the food. I'm sure they could cut a corner here and there, make more money, and we would not notice. But once one has the extra money, one cannot use it to buy more pride in what one does.

So, the food: I will update with details, but in short: each dish was very good on its own, and also fit into a well-coordinated meal. I don't know how they do that. The menu does not have Garanimals™ notation, so I guess everything can go with everything.

This is a place for special occasions, first-dates that will be remembered for years, and celebrating the wonder of being with friends and lovers.
author: Richard H.

description:
another great neighborhood French place.

I could easily compare this place with Bouche and L'ardoise.. great food, spectacular service and quaint and warm environment. as far as price goes, this place is tied with Bouche. L'ardoise is a bit pricier.

heirloom tomato salad: just one of those things you can't go wrong with.. the tomatoes were just great. light dressing really shone with the tomatoes.

moules: ah, rich and just goodness.. so good. the broth was so butter-licious and tasteful! they were not shy about the number of mussels either! (which is always great!)

risotto with scallop: the highlight of the dinner.. what else to say? the name says it all.. and it exceeded my expectations i had for the dish.. strongly recommended!

trout (fish of the day): probably the best trout dish i've ever had.. since i'm not usually a huge fan. it was just perfectly cooked and served in a large portion.

I'd like to say i just wish they had more staff! it was quite slow but i guess that's what one should expect from a real French bistro. :)
author: Sung C.

description:
I adore Bistro Central Parc. 
This is a fantastic restaraunt. I almost don't want to review it because it is such a gem but I can't deprive the world of greatness. 
I love the ambiance. It's a small, dark, relaxed restaraunt adorned with candle light and is tucked away on a quiet street.  It really has a great personality and truly makes for an incredibly intimate place to enjoy a fabulous meal. 

A friend and I walked over on a Saturday night for a late meal. They were very busy and unfortunately we didn't make reservations but they were so kind and made it a point to accomodate us at the bar.

You can't have a great restaruaunt without great food and wine. I ate so much it literally hurt to walk home...four blocks. The bread is amazing and they will give you as much as you can eat. I love escargots in garlic and butter and they are exceptional here and a great way to start off the meal. The duck melted in my mouth and I ate it all. Of course we polished off the meal with some incredibly decadent creme brulee. All of the emplyees are incredibly gracious and you can sense they know they have a great thing going ont. This is place is something special.
author: Denise S.

description:
I was really amazed with this place and so lucky I stumbled upon it! My boyfriend and I were driving around looking for good brunch places with outdoor seating on Sunday... thank you Yelp App! Bistro Central Parc is hidden in a Nopa neighborhood, you feel like you are tucked away at a lil cafe in Paris.  Our waiter was very nice and attentive.

We ordered the mussels which came with a to die for creamy white wine and garlic sauce. We ordered a size of fries and ended up dipping in the sauce cause we couldn't get enough. All their salads looked amazing, we got a simple green salad which was a good compliment to the mussels and fries. 

Wanted something sweet so we ordered the french toast which came with fruit, homemade syrup and fresh cream. It was amazing! 

I am excited to come back here for brunch and try their omelets but equally excited to try them for dinner.
author: Kristi E.

description: The food is delicious and service is outstanding. Great French Food without "The Frenchiness"...
author: Fernando A.

description:
Wow...this was definitely one of the best meals I've ever had! I had the rack of lamb and personally, I thought it was the best dish out of the four dishes that were ordered in my group. My boyfriend had the filet mignon and it was cooked to perfection. We also tried the scallop and lobster risotto; it was amazing! 
 I am definitely coming back here soon and I cannot believe I haven't been here sooner.
author: Irina M.

description:
Compared to all the French places in the neighborhood, this is the BEST!

And, well, the only one. But that's besides the point.

Friendly French employees (owners, staff, chefs, whomever just happens to be there) welcome you sincerely when you walk in. Wine list is small but I have yet to be disappointed with their recommendations the 4 times I've been. They have an Oregon beer on tap, so that's already 3 stars in my book. 

Cute, quaint on the inside yet unrecognizable as a restaurant from the outside, I think the neighborhood is more than pleased to have the addition to local businesses.

They have varying daily specials (one of which was a filet topped with fois gras and a truffle sauce drizzled on it!) which includes a $10 pasta du jour and a few other things, but I suggest from their menu constants: the mussels with some fries, the seared scallops on lobster risotto, and the lamb. Just incredible. I've had 90% of their desserts and you just can't go wrong.

Bonus star for serving brunch on the weekends. Delicious French toast for sub-$10? Eggs Benedict within walking distance from my home? SOLD.
author: Jasmyn M.

description:
Went there for Sunday Brunch - solid solid french bistro food. the menu selection isn't huge, but what do you expect from what is basically a neighborhood joint? The owner is French and very friendly, as he made jokes to our early morning party about how everyone was suffering from "jet lag" together (referring to our recent switch to daylight savings time). 

Our party had an assortment of food - eggs benedict (classic), croques monsieur & madame, french toast, and lots of coffee. 

the atmosphere was inviting and the food was quite good. if only parking was just a wee easier... but then it's San Francisco, so having to spend some time finding parking is simply to be expected.
author: Rachel M.

description:
The French are not exactly known for their variety of vegetarian fare, and Bistro Central is no exception.  That said, the vegetarian option that they did serve to my dining companion was quite tasty, she said.

But what I really want to talk about is meat.  Meet the meat:

From bone marrow appetizers to steak frites, duck confit and filet mignon, we witness the French at their best: full of hearty, rich, and flavorful meat.  On my recent visit I had the beef bourguignon, a classic beef-rosemary-red wine saucy dish.  This rendition was quite a pretty presentation (not the usual "mystery lump stew"), and it was simply delicious.  For dessert, we shared a heavenly creme brulee.  It was large enough for even creme brulee-obsessed me to share comfortably, and it was perfection enough to satisfy even creme brulee-obsessed me.

And the coup d'etat?  Why the friendly, welcoming servers and owner (who stopped by each table individually to make sure that each and every diner was in some sort of sumptuous, gluttonous heaven).

In short, while maybe not the best place to take your veggie friends, I'm a huge fan of this comfortable, affordable, neighborhood French restaurant.
author: Ravena F.

description:
came here to treat a friend out for her birthday and gotta say, completely worth it. 

we ordered the kobe beef tartare ($10.00), which was amazing. nice seasoned rare beef, topped with a raw egg (which you mix together) and paired with grilled bread slices to pair. you can ask for more bread when you run out (which is free and a great plus). i ordered the Carré d'agneau, ratatouille (lamb chops) ($28.00) and it was the best lamb i have ever had. VERY tender, with great sauce glazed over it. the ratatouille was perfectly seasoned and soft, but not mushy. my friend ordered the Risotto aux coquilles St Jacques. she said the scallops were delicious and paired well with the risotto but the risotto was only so so by itself. since it was her birthday, the staff gave us a sponge ice cream (how my friend described it) and a candle for her to blow out. they even dimmed the lights and had the whole restaurant sing happy birthday to her. we also got 2 glasses of dessert wine and she got a free cup! great place to have a birthday, i must say. 

the staff is very friendly and informative (we didn't know about mixing the egg for the tartare). the interior has a modern decor feel to it and dimly lit. the restaurant itself is not very big so i wouldn't recommend this place for large parties unless you call in ahead. the location has bad parking so come early or you might spend some time finding parking (found ours next to the park). 

all in all, this is a great place to take someone for their birthday. one of the best experiences i had eating out in sf.
author: Alan C.

description:
Honestly, everytime i visit central parc bistro, i just have the most amazing meal every single time. our server was extremely nice, he made sure we got everything we needed, great recommendations etc. 
i couldnt get reservation online, so i called, and it was all good to go! 

filet mignon was so good! and callop risotto.. oh man. must try. gem spot in SF
author: Christine K.

description: I went with a few friends for brunch.  We had Egg's Benedict x2, an omelet and some french toast.  The egg's benedict were nothing special, the french toast was sizable but not impressive looking and the omelet was huge, but plain.  Coffee was not great either
author: John M.

description:
A little bit disappointed. We tried fish and steak, none of them really stands out. The potato comes with one of the dishes is very dry --- they might just boil it in the water. 

Service was not good either. The waiter was pretending that he knows everything, not only to us, but the neighboring table as well as I noticed.
author: Ting R.

description: Good place to have French food ! This place is very pack so better Make a reservation !
author: Anita J.

description: Filet mignon with seared foie gras.  Do I need to say anything else?  Adorable, affordable, delectable little French bistro.  Oh how I wish you existed in my town.
author: Gio R.

description: Great neighborhood restaurant and absolutely worth a visit if you don't live nearby. Nice atmosphere. Very good service. A very nice menu with a lot of options. I've been there perhaps 3 times and will go back.
author: Frances G.

description: Had an order of the Wild Mushroom Risotto w/Truffle Oil (~$11): creamy yellow risotto cooked with small mushroom pieces.  Food was delicious, staff was comfortable, and the ambiance was unassuming.
author: Rishi C.

description: How lucky are we NoPA denizens to have a gourmet French restaurant tucked away in our residential island of bliss? It's a dream come true, and Jacques and his crew are superb and skilled every single time. I have been there for dinner, breakfast, and for a few solo glasses of wine whilst in the middle of your average, minor weeknight existential crisis. It's a casual, plain restaurant with phenomenal food and service, and I feel so lucky to be a half a block away from them.
author: Serena Q.

description:
I'd looked at the menu few months back and have been wanting to check this place out, and since my husband and I'd returned from Europe last week, I thought it would give us a great opportunity to reminisce about out trip over a French meal.

I was a bit surprised at the location, as Bistro Central Parc is in the middle of nowhere, and we drove passed it twice before finding it.  Nevertheless, I adore hole-in-the-wall type of places, and I thought if the owners have the ingenuity to open a restaurant in such desolate place, then the food must be or had to be really good ... and IT WAS!

Unlike the handful of so-called French restaurants I've tried in SF that serves watered down version of French cuisine, the food at BCP is authentic and delightfully tasty.  Although their menu isn't extensive, it has all of the usual favorites like Magret de canard, Carré d'agneau, and my personal favorite, Bouillabaisse.  

Unfortunately, as most reviewers have mentioned, the service is virtually non-existent.  Although we were used to lack of service at restaurants in Europe for the past weeks, this is San Francisco after all, where patrons are expected to tip, and bringing us our food and drinks then abandoning us for the rest of the night doesn't constitute a "bistro" style service.  It's just plain "bad" service.  

I'm not really sure why so much emphasis is put on the wait staff being able to speak French.  It really doesn't concern me what language they speak as long as they provide good ... or I'll take even acceptable service, and the owner(s) should be aware that this is an area where improvement needs to be made.
author: S. I.

description: I had such a lovely dining experience when I visited in October! This is a true French bistro and everything about the place is authentic from the food to the staff. My waiter presented me with a fantastic wine pairing that I could not have beaten myself and the all of the food was so delicious!
author: Karl S.

description:
I ate here last night while entertaining out of town VIPs (i.e. someone's parentals). We all left happily stuffed, which is impressive if you consider that one of the parents has a phd in french literature, and is aka very knowledgeable on french cuisine. Plus, all the waitstaff and the owner seems to speak french or is french. Pretty cool.

We needed a reservation for a Thursday night dinner, and couldn't get anything later than 6:30pm.  When we left at 8, the place was paaacccked, including every bar seat being taken.

Anwyay, the food:
Sweet bread & mushroom appetizer - the sweet breads were fatty and delicious, and the demi glace on it was also pretty darn good. There were 3 pieces, which is plenty for one or good for 2-3.

Monkfish Risotto - One of their daily specials. It was delicious, and just on the verge of being too small. But thankfully I got a bite of a confit de canard which was just enough to make me contently full.

Apple tart (can't remember the french) - Also really good. The crust had a lovely apple taste to it, and it came topped with whipped cream wrapped with a bruleed/carmelized-eclair shaped wrapper. 

I'd definitely come back to try the other things people have raved about (I had to suppress the urge to check Yelp review highlights at the table...something about poor etiquette) and to possibly even check out brunch here too! Also, might need to come back soon so I can get some more foie gras before it's banned!
author: aileen c.

description:
Myself, my husband, and a friend.  We all got different dishes.  If you are looking for a menu recommendation, we all agreed the best app was the potato cake with Brie and salad, and the best dish was the scallops with risotto.  No room for dessert, but the profiteroles looked amazing.   

Prices are very reasonable.  Worth a try for sure!
author: Tai N.

description:
What a find!  Bistro Central Parc is in my opinion the best French food in the City, better than Chapeau! and Chez Papa.  Every dish we tried was outstanding, no matter how simple.  Price for quality is surprisingly low. 

- French onion soup ($9)
Perfect, not too salty (my pet peeve), not too rich.  Just right.

- Foie Gras 3 ways ($20, special appetizer)
1. Seared foie gras with brandied? cherries?  Ah, delicious!
2. Foie gras pate.  Not bad, with some sea salt on top.  
3. Macaroon with sweet foie gras filling?  Honestly I wasn't sure if the filling really was foie gras.  It was more like a desserty macaroon.  The macaroon cookie parts were excellent though.

- Scallops over Risotto ($22)
Scallops could not have been more perfectly cooked!  Portion looks tiny, but it's very filling.

- Filet Mignon ($24)
What a steal for filet mignon, and what a filet it was!  Did they massage the meat?  I have no idea, but it was as tender as it gets.  Done perfectly, medium rare as I asked.  It was fantastic.

- Tarte Tartin ($7.50)
An interesting take on an ordinary French dessert.  Thick wedges of apple, piled on a thin crust.  The presentation was excellent.  A nice, light way to end an overall rich meal (but rich in the right way).

We'll be returning here again without a doubt.  

Only concern is that because it's a neighborhood restaurant (the only restaurant for blocks), the parking can be tricky.  Came here at 9pm on a Friday night and was able to find parking when circling around a bit, but I can imagine circling a lot longer on other nights.
author: F O.

description:
How have I never reviewed Bistro Central Parc? I live two blocks away and have many-a-time frequented this little neighborhood gem of a bistro. 

Here's my haiku ode to their French Onion Soup:

It comes piping hot
Steam rising up from the cheese -- 
All melted on top.

Oh, french onion soup!
Made by the masterful chefs at
Bistro Central Parc,

How I adore thee,
How you have comforted me
And warmed my belly.

A trusted classic
Break off a piece of baguette
Let the soup soak in.
author: Hannah L.

description:
After a year of living in SF and trying many restaurants, BCP has become our regular go to bistro for a casual dinner with great service (they treat you like family) and fresh French culinary delights - some new and some traditional - but always fresh. This place is always busy and vibrant with laughter but not overwhelming. If we get an early table, we head down to the park for a lovely walk before heading home.

Definitely a 5 star bistro experience!
author: Chris C.

description:
Two dishes were highlights and would definitely make our "Best of SF" list:

French Onion Soup. Cheese and caramelized onions were all in abundant supply, but it is the broth that makes the soup. Bold, slightly meaty, yet balanced on the sodium scale. Very well done.

Scallop Risotto in Lobster Sauce. Perfectly cooked scallops, but it is the subtle, sublime sauce that makes this dish one of the better seafood offerings we've had in SF.
author: Darrin K.

description: The restaurant is small and very San Francisco, but I expected the ambiance to be a little cuter and more...French. That's the only reason it lost a star. The escargot, beef check, and duck confit were all tender and delicious. The service was also impeccable. We wanted a Cab to go with dinner but they were out, so he substituted with the Troublemaker Meritage. It was absolutely delicious. A great, fancier dining experience at a reasonable cost, highly recommended.
author: Kristen B.

description:
I loved this place. It's smack dab in the middle of a charming neighborhood (parking is a bit of a challenge) and if you blink you'll miss it. The staff is actually french, the food was uniformly good and best of all they didn't harass us when we waited nearly an hour to order because the fourth member of our group as caught in traffic. 

I had the scallop risotto which came with five large scallops, very tasty. Other diners had a lamb special, fish special and hanger steak, all were good. For dessert we split a tarte tatin, lava cake and strawberry special. The special was 'eh" but the other two were wonderful.

This restaurant has a really charming unpretentious ambiance and the price is just write - around $20/entree.
author: Rachel H.

description:
My favorite spot in NOPA!

I have had almost everything on the menu.  That being said, I regularly come back for the sweetbreads, salmon tartar & the braised beef cheeks...

The restaurant has a warm neighborhood feel.  Jacques is always friendly and welcoming.
author: Megan M.

description:
Fantastic restaurant.  After another yelper recommended this place to us, we decided to dine here before the foie gras ban takes effect on July 1st.  However, due to our late reservations, they were out of foie gras.  boo...

-French onion soup - One of the best I've had in the city
-Salmon tartare - it's tartare wrapped in smoked salmon, good but get sick of it after awhile
-Beef tartare - very good, but not as good as chez papa bistro
-Filet mignon w/ foie gras - the foie gras didn't quite go w/ the filet, but the meat was tender & juicy.

Overall, a very positive experience.  Will definitely be back in the future.
author: Carrie-C N.

description: LOVE this place. Made a reservation on a Saturday night. Service was great, really nice environment, and great food. I had the beet salad and filet, both great. Definitely a neighborhood gem!
author: Lauren M.

description: Absolutely wonderful!  We are from out of town so our daughter picked out the place .  We were so pleased!  The service was great  the food was great and the wine was great!  Will definitely go back!!!!  I had the scallop risotto and it was wonderful !
author: Michelle W.

description: Loved this place! Went in for dinner with my hubby - he had the quail special and I had the rib-eye - both were delicious! App was the baked brie which was equally awesome. Friendly and fun service! Would DEF go back! Those who don't drink, I had their red wine cooler, and it was so good!
author: Teema C.

description:
This is by far one of the best restaurants I have encountered in SF, and the prices are very reasonable.

Great service.  The wait staff was very attentive, well informed, and well spoken.  The manager stopped by twice during our meal to check on us.  There was a good energy level, but was still quiet enough for conversation.

The food was excellent.  French Onion soup was prepared traditionally with copious amounts of melted cheese to top it off.  Well balanced flavor and nice presentation.  The filet was prepared medium and was perfectly tender and juicy.  The green peppercorn sauce added a nice flavor and did not overpower.  The risotto with scallops was perfectly cooked and well portioned.  The lobster sauce was rich and flavorful.

Definitely need to come back and try the brunch that everyone seems to enjoy.
author: Patrick R.

description:
Not good.
WASTE OF MONEY!
That's not what risotto is, at all.
Very disappointing scallops.
French onion was okay. 
I don't know if everyone else is just lying because they know the owner or what.
I didn't order a steak and fries, so perhaps that's where I went wrong.
My favorite part of the meal was the butter- even the bread was too stale.
I didn't even like the dessert.
The waiter said something about how it's such good French food.
It turned out to be a joke instead.
author: Cheska Tangerina G.

description: Good French food served Paris style - without fake smiles. Screw fake smiles, just give me more of those delicious beef cheeks, and baked brie, and onion soup! Maybe not so much more, as the portions are pretty generous. The prices are reasonable as well.Will be back for more..
author: Oleg R.

description: Really good food, but a bit expensive.
author: Anne-Sophie B.

description:
One of my favorite places for a fancy but not overly-expensive dinner.  Great for special occasions without breaking the budget.

And the food is LEGIT.  Been here a number of times, and every time the food has been superb.

Apps are around $10.  Main courses around $20.  And corkage is only $15!  That is unheard of in SF.   It's always a steal if you can get out of a nice restaurant in SF with 2 apps, 2 main courses, 2 desserts, 2 coffees, and a corkage fee for around $100 overall-- at a legit French restaurant no less. 

Occasionally the servers seem a bit rude, touchy, or condescending. Just roll with it- they usually provide excellent service regardless.

For food I recommend:

Beef tartar- excellent
Salmon tartar- BEST THING EVER.
Cassole-  delicious
Beef cheeks- amazing!

Come here, enjoy the excellent food at a good value, you won't be disappointed.
author: Chris L.

description: Went there tonight for my friends birthday. The food and service was excellent. Will definitely go back.
author: Gail L.

description: Great meal.
author: Morris R.

description:
**** Food ****

Superb quality in terms of the price range. This is what we had for dinner:

Carrot soup: fresh and not too creamy
Salmon tartar: very good

Vegetarian ratatouille (over risotto): a bit too much cheese for me but still very good
Magret de canard (duck): the fruits tasted superb

Dessert of the day (sampler): very good

**** Service ****

Very friendly and attentive without being pretentious. The owners are really French.

**** Ambiance ****

Small and cozy restaurant with open kitchen.

**** Summary ****

French restaurants tend to be too pretentious to me. This one is a rare neighborhood gem. Will definitely go again.
author: Yoshikage K.

description: It's hard to find a great brunch in San Francisco, but this place I loved.  Very quality food with  bistro feel.
author: Judith Q.

description: We went here for breakfast as the reviews were amazing but my eggs benedict was mediocre & the coffee was horrible. I wouldn't go back again for breakfast. However I can say the waitress was lovely so service was great so may try dinner here one day.
author: Hayley L.

description:
Very tasty classic french dishes, lovely atmosphere and service

Three of us dined here, all foodies (and one of us is French!). Highlights included the steak frites, the pepper steak, and from the desserts the Tarte Tatin and the profiteroles. Refined and relaxing atmosphere and attentive service, and a warm welcome from the owner.
author: Mary M.

description:
Great food, cool people, nice but not stuffy atmosphere, satisfying meal, worth every penny.

The bouillabaisse is outstanding, The Warm Brie Potato Pancake appetizer is incredible, The Scallop Risotto great!
author: Alexander M.

description:
When I got to Bistro Central Parc, the space seems a little crammed.  I sat next to a party of 10 and I had little wiggle room after sitting down.

My date and I ordered a salmon tartar to start.  The salmon was fresh and de-li-cious! Combined with the two slices of crunchy bread it came with, it was perfect. For the main course, I had duck while my date had scallops with risotto.  The duck was cooked to medium with a hint of pink on the side.  The raspberry sauce was amazing and it went well with the duck.  For the scallops, they were cooked just right - lightly seared on each side. The risotto was creamy and flavorful.  

In conclusion, I highly recommend this restaurant and the pricing was very reasonable.
author: Matt M.

description:
I love this place. 

Bistro Central Park reminds me of those Mom & Pop gems of restaurants that used to be all over France, which have unfortunately disappeared over the years. 

I discovered it a couple of months ago, and it is now our "go to" place. Every single dish I have tried was better than what I remember from growing up in France. 

La choucroute: incroyable.
Les desserts: orgasmiques.
Le service: superbe, relax et sympa.
Le patron: passione par la bonne bouffe.

Just go. Or rather, don't go: more for me!
author: L. N.

description:
Had a nice dinner here for four recently. Gorgeous looking salad and cassoulet. The duo of fois gras was half great- the roasted peach and warm slice was amazing. The cold slice had the consistency of bad pate or peanut butter. Mussels were good, although the broth could have had more flavor.
Beautiful sugar work on the desserts!
Service was excellent, ambiance is very nice. It's a great little neighborhood spot. I'd recommend it.
author: Jessica P.

description:
Service - Good, attentive. 

Food - excellent, especially the desserts. 
*Mussels Curry: not too creamy nor oily. Great for appetizer. 
*Brie: a must-try appetizer. I personally love to eat brie, so I really liked this dish. 
*Duck Breast: the portion of duck breast slices is not much, but the taste is excellent! The wine-taste is strong.
*Seafood Platter (I forgot what it's called exactly): a light entree. Great complimentary to the heavier Brie appetizer. 
*Creme Brulee: really delicious. The display is very pretty as well! 
*Chocolate Volcano Dessert: a quite heavy chocolate dessert after eating appetizer and entree, but looking at the magma of chocolate flowing out of the chocolate cake cave is too irresistible from putting my spoon down. 

The service, food and the ambiance of this restaurant are all wonderful! The price is very reasonable for a place like this. Highly recommend it :)
author: Pui L.

description:
At first glance, the place is a bit spartan, no white table linens or fancy decor, but don't let that fool you. The food here is absolutely top notch. I went there for my birthday and was completely satisfied. And this is the only place where the owner would personally greet the customers when they come in AND leave the establishment.

We shared the beef tartar and sweet bread appetizers. The tartar was fresh tasting, although it didn't stand out. The sweet bread, on the other hand, was the best that I've ever had. It was wonderfully prepared and the sauce, oh god, the sauce!!! I'll never deglaze with wine again. It'll be nothing but port from now on. That sauce is nothing short of tears from heaven. My lady-like disposition was the only barrier that kept me from licking the plate.

For the main courses, we had the filet with foie and the rack of lamb. Both the meats were medium rare and has the wonderful sauce that I mentioned above. The foie was velvety and the meat perfectly cooked. The ratatouille that accompanied the lamb was a standout also. So buttery and delicious.

For dessert, I had the tarte tatin and my companion had the lava cake. The tart was a sort of deconstructed take on the classic dessert and I loved it. The cream was encased in this thin sugar and nuts cylinder that gave it a wonderful crush and caramel flavor. I had a bit of the chocolate cake and it was light and complex. 

All in all, I had the most wonderful experience at Bistro Central Parc. Will definitely come back for more.
author: Alice W.

description:
What a lovely place! 

Our waitress Aurelie was very attentive, she walked us through the menu. Everyone else was kind and made us feel welcome .

Now, let's talk about food:

Escargot Appetizer = Not great.... I know , French restaurant you expect that to be outstanding but sadly they weren't , the sauce was lacking flavor.

Hanger steak special = Phenomenal ! It came with THE French fries, cooked to perfection 

Scallop Risotto = Tricky thing to order at a restaurant in my opinion, you either hate or love it , I LOVED IT 

Profiteroles = Perfect way to end our meal 

Can't wait to go back for brunch !
author: Mrs. Bauman M.

description:
Executive Chef/Owner, Jacques Manuera, a French Native and an 18 year veteran in the restaurant business has brought us his newest venture; Bistro Central Parc. This 9 months new French bistro located in the residential area of Hayes Valley/NOPA neighborhood is quaint, cozy and understated. Upon entrance, we were personally greeted by Jacques, who immediately led me to the open kitchen and introduced me to his Chef de Cuisine, Nicolas Jardin.

The menu is classic bistro French fare with California influences. We began our dinner with the Ris de Veau sur lit de Champignons - sweetbread with mushrooms. Sweetbread - culinary term for the thymus gland (known as throat sweetbread) and the pancreas (stomach sweetbread), of the calf and lamb. Why is it called Sweetbread, you ask? I have not a clue but I do know I enjoyed this dish very much... More so than the last time I had it at Chez Papa. Pan-seared from the outside, tender and silky on the inside. The mushroom and sauce meshed well with the sweetbreads. They did not reveal the type of sauce used for this dish, tasted similar to the Bordelaise sauce.

Trio de tartar de Saumon - trio of salmon tartar, saimon roe and gravlax. Classic plating of this classic dish. What I liked about this is that you can taste the freshness of the herbs, the salmon tartar and the gravlax (old gravlax tend to have a heavy fish scent and somewhat slimy).

Kobe Beef Tartar -Slight tart from the mustard, fresh and perfectly seasoned to peak your appetite. Typically the texture of beef tartar is quite gooey after you mix the meat with the egg yolk (which I do not care for) but surprisingly this wasn't the case. It maintained its texture without the excessive moisture from the egg.

Full review and pics, visit http://triplexbexx.wordpress.com

thanks! =)
author: Rebecca L.

description:
Really did not understand the popularity of this restaurant given my experience. The place was packed for a Sunday night which was a good signal but the slow service quickly diminished the good first impression. That did not get any better with the food.

They were actually out of a dish I wanted to try but tried the beef tartare nonetheless. Good but not spectacular. Had nice presentation and good flavors.

The entrees were just not up to par. The scallop risotto with lobster sauce was pretty bland with under-cooked rice and unseasoned while the scallops were over salted.  This portion size was more for appetizer.

The duck confit with lentils also missed the mark. Duck was tender and cooked right but again no seasoning at all. Lentils were dry making it hard hard to swallow .

This restaurant is not worth the price you pay although the venue is pretty good for special occasions.
author: Ed L.

description: This has quickly become our go-to week night date spot. We sit at the bar, drink wine and eat the delicious mussels & steak frites. The owner is lovely and the spot has a great neighborhood feel- families, couples, small groups. Highly recommend if you live nearby!
author: Gretchen S.

description:
Great restaurant - they had live music, the food was excellent, and it has a nice atmosphere.

I had the duck breast, and I have to say it was some of the best duck I've ever had. The presentation was great. 2 friends had the scallop risotto which was delicious as well.

Reservations are definitely recommended as it is a pretty small place. Overall a great evening and not too pricey for what it was.
author: Jake L.

description: It's fine but not amazing. I was really looking forward to the place and the staff are very nice, but the good was forgettable.
author: Mehdi A.

description:
I went here for my birthday and another time for brunch.  Simply, the food is the best I have ever had.  No one in our group had a bad dish.  While not inexpensive prices do match the quality you receive.

The place is small and can get a bit noisy at times, but the quality of the food and service more than make up for it.
author: Evan M.

description: Food was just okay. Service not so great. One of the servers was pretty rude. He told us off just because we were trying to check out photos of their dishes on yelp.
author: Panchaya P.

description:
I can usually overlook fruit flies buzzing around our table the whole meal or the surprise up-charge for corkage from what was quoted by phone. 

BUT: we were settled in at our table, already on our second glass of wine when we were rudely told by the maitre d' that we would have to move outside because they had overbooked, and had other customers coming shortly. (!)

No offer of free drinks or desserts, either. We refused and after demanding to speak to the owner, they backed down. Perhaps wherever the male maitre comes from this is acceptable, but not SF, LA, NYC, or London.

I hasten to add that the ladies who were our servers were very professional and efficient and should be commended for their efforts.

The food was acceptable at best, with the wild mushroom risotto and the onion soup being the best picks.

 There are plenty of other restaurants nearby. Go elsewhere.
author: rick r.

description: Excellent service, scrumptious food, and very comfortable ambiance.  Service of  each course was timed very well, never rushed. The food is authentic, rich with original flavor,  The Caprese was excellent, the best I have had for a long while. Filet Mignon was tender and jucy. Profiteroles are tasty, but not too sweet. Will go back again definitely.
author: Zhi L.

description: Beef tartare was good appetizer. Ordered the ribeye with fries, sadly the fries were the best part of the entree.  The steak wasn't very good, I compare it to the quality of sizzlers steak, but at least they have steak sauce at sizzlers.  This was one the times when I really wished I had some steak sauce.  Good service though, I do like the French accents.
author: Peter L.

description:
**sigh**

I'm deeply saddened by my experience at Bistro Central Parc. All of these fabulous 5-star worthy Yelp reviews really got my hopes up that I would have the same experience. Sadly I didn't have anything close to that.

The place was nice. I liked the ambiance. The dishes sounded delicious -- definitely a lot of potential here. However I chose to listen to the waiter and go with one of the specials.

MISTAKE.

It was good. But not "WOW THIS IS DAMN TASTY PARTY IN MY MOUTH" good. For all the hype this place has I just expected more. I'm trying to keep good thoughts and am hoping I just caught the kitchen on an off night. However I'm beginning to think this place is just a tad bit overrated. But I am intrigued by their Brunch menu and might consider trying it one day.

Sorry Bistro Central Parc. It just wasn't the business this time around.
author: Sara K.

description: I absolutely love this restaurant! The food is amazing. I would suggest any of their risotto dishes! The creme brûlée is also to die for. Great ambiance and wonderful food! What more could you ask for?
author: Laura C.

description:
This is one of the hidden gems in the city. 
Great food in a warm, unpretentious setting. The service is excellent, the owner is so friendly., and the prices are very reasonable, you just can't go wrong here.

Filet mignon with foei gras, short ribs, beef tartare.... mmm...

After reading all the other reviews, it looks like I will have to try all their seafood dishes and update my review.
author: July N.

description:
French Onion soup: Excellent
Escargot: just OK
Melon Salad: Excellent
Bouillabaisse: Amazing
Filet minion:  Excellent
Rack of Lamb: Excellent
Steak Fries: OK
Poach Pear with vanilla ice cream: excellent
Volcan Chocolate: OK
author: Thien B.

description:
I went here for the first time yesterday and this could very well become my favourite french bistro in San Francisco. Very close tie with L'ardoise.

The French onion soup was excellent and very flavourful. Some places just can't get the veal broth right, this version does not disappoint.  As a main course I had the filet mignon, topped with seared foie gras and potatoes. It was cooked to perfection.

Very highly recommended if you are looking for a casual dining experience with quality food.
author: Emmanuel P.

description: Phenomenal food. Magret de canard - the duck breast - was delicious, and we ended our meal with the decadent Volcan au Chocolat... We loved our waiter, Alex, as well. There is more to him than meets the eye (hint: he knows Sanskrit).
author: Nikhil B.

description:
I wish I could give more than 5 stars. Plenty of raving reviews have been written already so I had high expectations. And I was not disappointed. In fact, my dining experience even surpassed my expectations. I came to Bistro Central Parc for the first time on a Friday night and had a wonderful dining experience. And what I was most impressed with was the warmth and friendliness of the owner and entire staff. 

FOOD:
We ordered the filet with foie gras and scallop risotto. Both were fantastic though filet was my favorite. I think some mentioned smaller portions, and while it may seem so, the dishes are also rich and a good balance of portion to flavor & density. I was very satisfied. For dessert, creme brulee - also great.

SERVICE:
The owner Jacques greeted us at the door, checked on us during our meal, and came by for a few words and to say good bye when we left. Another gentleman - I think Claude - asked how we enjoyed the meal, how we heard of the restaurant, chatted with us as we left and wished us a warm good bye. FANTASTIC. Throughout the meal, our server and the staff were so attentive. At one point I saw a dish being brought out with a glass cover - short ribs, I believe - and they use the glass cover as a smoker. Their server saw me looking with interest at the glass as he walked away, so he came back and showed us the glass and we caught the smoky aroma. It was a full and busy Friday night, but to have such wonderful and memorable service is something that makes this one of my new favorite restaurants.
 
LOCATION & STUFF:
Nestled on a quiet corner in a very residential part of NOPA. Subtle exterior. Parking can be tough as mentioned. Make a reservation if you can - we were about 30 minutes late, but they were able to accommodate us. It's small inside but there are quite a few tables. It may not be quite as intimate as some other restaurants, and you may hear some of your neighbor's conversation depending on where/how you're seated, but if you want a wonderful and authentic French meal, you must try Bistro Central Parc. I absolutely love it.
author: Veronica H.

description: We came here for a post Valentines dinner. We started things off with some Brie app. For entrees, I had the rib eye steak and frites and she had the scallop and risotto. Glass of red wine paired to go with our entree. Dessert was a lemon pound cake with vanilla ice cream. Everything was excellent! Service was very attentive. The owner asked us how was dinner after we were done, which shows he cares. Highly recommend this place!
author: Rossi K.

description:
Can you say, AMAZING?  You can huh?  Well then, head over to Bistro Central Parc!  The staff was super nice and the owner? was flirtatiously charming.  We had a large party and between the 7 of us we all really enjoyed our meal.  You can't go wrong with anything but don't forget to check out the specials.  

I'm still dreaming of the steak tartare!
author: Rosalind S.

description: We just had dinner at Bistro Central Parc. The combination of a warm atmosphere, a very welcoming owner, a very attentive staff and ultimately very solid food has made it a five star evening. It's one of these places were you feel you could go every day and you'd end up being part of the family. The bouillabaisse is fantastic and the spacial dessert, pecan pie, also exceptionally good. Really a great place.
author: Alex A.

description:
Came here after learning that Chapeau!, a more popular destination for Francophile gastronomes in the city, was booked for the evening.  Can't really compare the two -- I've never been to Chapeau! -- but I'm not at all disappointed I decided to try this place out.

FOOD:  The food here is fantastic for the price.  We got to try the following:  

Potato pancake with brie and mizuna salad ($9.50):  Surprisingly tasty alternative to the mussels, which weren't available the day we went.  Pancake itself was perfectly fried and crisp, albeit a bit dry when eaten alone.  The melted brie helped lubricate the whole shootin' match.  Mizuna was rock-star (did I just call salad greens rock-star???  I think I did ...) when paired with a deliciously light and refreshing raspberry vinaigrette.   

Duck breast with mushrooms, bacon, potatoes and spinach in a cherry sauce ($19.50):  Amazing as well.  Didn't show up on the online menu.  Prepared just as requested -- medium rare.  The meat itself was a bit on the chewy side, but I don't begrudge Bistro CP for what was otherwise a very tasty protein in a wonderful sauce, with savory accompaniments.  

Risotto with scallops and lobster sauce ($19.50): Not sure I tasted the lobster in the sauce, but risotto was still quite tasty -- very creamy and al dente.  Scallops prepared perfectly -- deeply seared on the outside, while just cooked through on the inside.  Not rubbery and overcooked, as scallops easily can be. 

Ratatouille ($5):  Comes with eggplant, zucchini, red bell pepper, onions, and tomatoes.  Standard, but provided good balance to the rich entrees.  Bistro CP has affordable sides, generally speaking -- and they're cheaper than getting a second appetizer.

We were really full after the entrees, and decided not to opt for desserts.  Pretty standard fare, though -- I recall seeing profiteroles, creme brulee, poached pears, chocolate cake, and apple tarte tatin as choices.

Bread was served warm, but was in my opinion too hard on the outside.  I felt like a mole rat digging my way through the crust just to get to the good, soft part.

SERVICE/AMBIANCE:  Service was generally good, and the owner personally checked in at our table, which was appreciated (but not really necessary).  Waiter was attentive, but not overbearing, though he could have been friendlier (though that might have been asking too much of the Frenchman).  The space is narrow, and as a result the restaurant gets a bit noisy when it is packed (which it seems to be during most of its open hours).   Some menu items were out, which is unfortunate.  Call if you really want something in particular to make sure they have it.

PARKING:  Parking, as others have noted, is painful.  I parked at the garage for Lucky (2 free hours) on Fulton and would suggest others do the same.  Yes, risk the ticket or buy a pack of gum from Lucky to assuage your guilt.

FINAL NOTES:  As noted above, I haven't been to Chapeau! and can't compare the quality of that experience.  But I'll offer a few quick observations, namely that Bistro CP seems to hew more closely to the tried and true, while Chapeau! offers more interesting ingredients and innovative combinations (e.g., Skate Wing, Basil Napoleon).  On the other hand, Bistro CP is cheaper -- my friend and I escaped with a bill of $80, which included the food, tax, tip, and a glass of wine.  I don't think you can get that kind of value anywhere else in the city.
author: Peter C.

description:
Review is for 2/14/2011


I'm no expert in french cuisine; I can pretty much say "will you sleep with me tonight?" in French, but that's it. And I know most restaurants are practically ravaged and raped by star-crossed lovers (or anyone trying to get a lil' somethin somethin) on such a day blessed once a year by the Saint-Valentine's-Baby-Cupid-Thing(OFFICIAL NAME), but I was still very disappointed in this place despite such high reviews. 

Never been to a french restaurant before but wanted to, so I decided to make reservations here for 8:30PM on V-Day 2 weeks earlier after taking a look at their menu online since they appeared to have some vegetarian options. 

First off, it was extremely busy. Of course, it's V-Day, right? Ok, I understand. However, I don't understand how they thought it was ok to squeeze in SO MANY tables in such a tiny place. Romantic, intimate, dinner for 2? More like for 6 since the other couples seated to either side of you are so close, you practically end up learning everyone's social security number by the end of the night. (If only my undocumented primos were nearby!)

I don't know how they "organized" the night, but we had to wait a while to be seated and were terribly uncomfortable by how close we were to the people already seated since there was such little room. 

The menu was also not the same as the online one. We had only one option to choose from (as vegetarians), some vegetable entree that was 17$. I was very displeased when they brought out my WARM 9$ red wine AFTER getting our food because I definitely needed a buzz to be able to pretend that the pathetic serving size would fill me up. 

I can't speak to the authenticity of the cuisine, but on my way to the restroom, I spotted my fellow frijoleros in the kitchen, of course. Food itself is good but not worth 17$.

My hope for a sexy French night turned into a menage a NO.
author: Veronica G.

description:
Where was this place when I literally lived 2 blocks away?!?

Wait staff: attentive, knows the menu, helped pick a very good wine.
Ambiance:  quintessential north of the panhandle San Francisco.
Food: excellent, for the price paid.  We started with 3 hors d'oeuvres for the 4 of us.  I had a filet mignon with foie gras which was simply outstanding. We shared 3 desserts for the 4 of us. Also quite good.  Portions weren't the typical Americanized ginormous, but enough that we were sated by meals' end.

You should check it out.  I'll be back, sho nuff sho nuff.
author: Jaime B.

description:
Hands down one of the best restaurants i have been to in the city! (though we signed a verbal pact not to write about it on yelp because we want it to be our secret finding). lol. But I cant be that selfish! haha

Everything, and i mean everything about this dining experience was exquisite. went for a friend's 30th bday dinner, met a whole bunch of people for the first time (fabulous company), great wine (cotes du rhone and a riesling bottle), and YUMM YUMM food. I cant remember what everyone ate right now but i got the endive salad (walnuts, Roquefort.. omg yumm), and being a vegetarian asked the server for his recommendation and he said "You have to get the lasagna!!" So, of corse i was skeptical, its a french restaurant and this man is asking me to get Italian food? But everything else he recommended so far was on point and i am so so happy that i listed to him. It was the best lasagna i have ever (ever) eaten! so crispy, flavorful, homey, i think i am having a food orgasm right now! lol

Other food that was tried - the mushroom risotto, the pea soup, poussin, beef bourginon, filet mignon, the fish special (sea bass), the chocolate cake, the apple tart... every single dish was licked dry and then some.

Excellent neighborhood restaurant, amazing service which would be ideal for date night too! love love love
author: Sapna E.

description: I liked this place very much. We went for brunch and all of us really enjoyed it. It is pleasant, not noisy at all, without any fuss about getting a table, the service impeccable and the dishes were very good: I had a croque monsieur, very well made, the other friends of mine had the classic omelet and Frisée aux Lardons, all of them excellently prepared. I think I would like to try the dinner as well but, in the future, when I have the chance to be in that area, I will be very happy to stop by and enjoy a nice meal and a beautifully spent hour or so.
author: Luca R.

description: Me and two friends went on a Wednesday and lived the service and, even better, were amazed at the presentation of the food.  Oh, the meals were delicious. We had the almond trout, the risotto and the tart tatin. Ask about the $20 prix fixe before 7pm.
author: Virginia T.

description:
Delish!! Somehow reminded me of Frascati (even though this is French and the former is more Italian American). Really tasty apps and entrees. We had the brie pancake with arugula (yum!) and mushroom risotto with truffle, which was lacking salt but put truffle on anything and I'll eat it! The filet mignon was superb (albeit small) and my chilean sea bass special was plate licking good! Also on the small side...

The service was a tad slow-- but we noticed its a one-man show over there. One waiter literally manhandling the whole dining room. The manager did come out and help run food but the waiter was pretty much taking care of the bulk. Expect to come and make somewhat of an evening out of the dinner, not wham-bam-thankyou-maam experience, which can be nice if you're into that sorta thing. 

It is a tad more expensive for just a night out for dinner-- would recommend for a nice date or special occasion. Overall, a cool ambiance and open style kitchen--would totes recommend!
author: Sabrina S.

description: Fantastic little spot right around the corner from my girlfriends house. We decided to come in on Saturday for brunch and do not regret it! Everything was good, from the eggs Benny to the Croque Madame. The only thing I wish was that my French Onion soup would have come as an appetizer and not along with the main courses. Chef Jaques came by and checked up on us which was a very nice added touch. We will definitely be back soon to try dinner!
author: Alex G.

description:
My boyfriend and I had a reservation here yesterday to celebrate our anniversary.  We were greeted warmly at the door and seated immediately.  It's a cozy little place -- tables are very close together, although that didn't bother us during our meal.  There was also some red fabric draped along the ceiling with hearts hanging from it; early Valentine's decorations perhaps?

SOUP:
I started off my meal with the soupe a l'oignon.  I'm a sucker for French onion soup, and I wasn't disappointed here.  The broth was sweet and light, and didn't hit me in the face with harsh onion flavor like other onion soups I've had.  The caramelized onions within were melt-in-your-mouth tender, and there were chunks of bread in there too.  It was topped with a very generous bubbly layer of melted Gruyere.  Mmm mmm mmm!

ENTREE:
I got the moules marinieres.  The mussels were cooked perfectly!  Tender, not overly chewy.  Every bite I took, I reflexively said "mmm..."  And the broth was fantastic!  So creamy and rich.  I saved some bread to sop it up with at the end.  Boyfriend dipped his fries in, too.  These mussels were just shy of the best ones I've ever had (and those were in Pittsburgh, PA of all places!)

Boyfriend got the steak frites for his entree.  He ate every bite (even the green beans, wow!) and definitely enjoyed it, though he later remarked that he liked the steak at Chez Papa just a little bit more.  I stole one of his fries and had a dip of the steak sauce, very tasty.

DESSERT:
Creme brulee is my weakness.  If it's on a dessert menu, I HAVE to order it.  The creme brulee here was absolutely delicious, but it was soooo huge and rich, I could barely finish half of it.  It's a good dish to share, I think.  I was hoping my boyfriend would have a few bites, but he was too occupied with his Tarte Tatin, the presentation of which was fantastic by the way, and which he, again, ate every bite of.  I felt so bad leaving behind that much deliciousness, but I just could. not. eat another bite.  Both our server and the owner came over to make sure I liked my dessert, which I think goes to show how much they care about the diner experience here.

I would definitely return!
author: Katelyn M.

description: My happy place. Great French food at a reasonable price. It's the perfect neighborhood restaurant.
author: Frankie W.

description: We started off with the sweetbreads as recommended by our server. The brown sauce was sweet and savory. Lovely.  I ordered the sea bass which was the fish of the day. My partner ordered the beef stew over papardelle. Both were delicious. The sea bass was on the upper edge of well done. Thankfully not dry. There was a crispy skin atop. Stacked over a cauliflower cheese bake (must find out how to cook this) and a pile of sauteed spinach with a moat of the best lemon butter sauce ever. The papardelle was my favorite about my partner's dish. The sauce was thick, meaty and rich. We shared a bottle of zin and skipped on dessert. I love that our server had a thick French accent and came up to us upon entering with the closeness as if he would have planted two kisses on us. Extra bonus that we were surrounded by other guests speaking French!!
author: Kathleen T.

description: Very solid local french bistro. Loved the Risotto with Lobster, Chicken Cordon Bleu and the Endive Salad. Will definitely come back.
author: Mark S.

description:
I moved to NOPA 6 months ago and i have heard great things about this place. i got a chance to go there on Friday with GF and this place is absolutely amazing. I wish I had not waited that long.

The menu is small and simple but everything we ordered was amazing. The Eindeve salad is to die for. I had lamb shank and my gf had the Rabbit special. both weer delicious.

They have a good wine selection but we ordered beer. No squirm about ordering beer in french rest. Very down to earth owner, friendly staff and great service.
author: Subhash J.

description:
Oh Bistro Central Parc, you never seem to disappoint. We came here yesterday for my cousins party and i think everyone had a great time. So we came here with 6 people and everyone finished their food.

My cousin who normally eats like a rabbit. Finished her WHOLE appetizers, French Onion soup, and her Fois Gras Filet Mignon with Potatoes (she also finished this). To my amazement this almost NEVER HAPPENS. 

What we ordered:

1.) French Onion Soup x3 (good, but not as good as Chapeaus... IMO)
2.) Beef Tartare (Better than Cafe Claudes, love this)
3.) Mussels (Better than Plouf's but not hard to be better than there.)
4.) Mushroom Risotto (something my cousin wanted but was good)
5.) Brie Salad (some vegetables are nice).

Main courses:

1.) Filet Mignon with Fois Gras (tender as ever and fois gras is rich as it should be)
2.) Trout (wasn't offered a piece... you who you are, but looked fantastic)
3.) Scallops and Pork Belly (delicious and tender)
4.) Vegetarian Risotto (didn't get to try this)
5.) Lamb (no after taste that some lamb has and tender)

Not only was the food good the service was good. I will be back to write a follow up on Brunch when i try it again for brunch. But from what i remember? It was just as good as dinner if not better.
author: Benjamin L.

description: After reading several good reviews on this restaurant I could hardly wait to enjoy a "French" dinner at Bistro Central Parc. I started with an heirloom tomato salad with crispy polenta on top and it was delicious. I ordered scallops with risotto priced at $24.00 I felt it should have included a vegetable but it did not. My panna cotta was served in a wine glass and flooded with whip cream....there was hardly any panna cotta. I would not recommend ordering panna cotta.  All in all, I was somewhat disappointed.
author: Lesley K.

description: Delicious and great service.  Really like this place.  Brunch is great. Eggs florentine rocks
author: Megan j.

description: Sweet Bread with Mushrooms, French Onion Soup, Special Fillet, Scallops Risotto, a side of Frites, and great wines. What a perfect dinner for me and my boyfriend. The food and service was beyond awesome. Will definitely come back!
author: Steffie M.

description:
The people who gave the bad reviews either 1) don't know what French food is supposed to be like, or 2) came on an "off" night. 

We've been to L'Ardois and Bistro Central Parc and we think we love Bistro better, which we never thought we'd say.  I was here last weekend for the first time and thought it was AMAZING.  I just got back from two weeks in France and thought Bistro Central Parc was as French as it gets!  The restaurant itself is small but charming.  The owner, warm & very welcoming.  We had excellent service throughout the entire meal and the servers allowed us to try the wines we chose for dinner.  Great wine selection.

What we had:

Mussels with white wine broth - great!
Side of french fries - amazing - similar to Cafe De Amis - must be fried in duck fat

Special of Short Ribs with au gratin potatoes - my husband said it was the best he's ever had.  Presentation was very cool - it came out under a glass dome of smoke so that the rib picked up the smoke flavor.  Incredible.

Filet Mignon with peppercorn sauce & au gratin potatoes - this steak literally melted in my mouth.  I will be back to have this again.

Dessert was the Tart tartine (apple) - also very good, just like apple pie...we loved it
author: Kim D.

description:
I am really impressed.

Everything folks have said about the amazing value for such high quality and beautifully presented food is true. And the restaurant has a delightful neighborhood feel that is not the least bit pretentious.

From the moment we walked in the door, we were treated graciously, shown to our table right away. We had a few different servers, but it didn't feel inconsistent at all - you could tell everyone was working together to keep all of the restaurant patrons happy. Our primary server was a woman who was so sweet, and gave really good input on the dishes. She steered me slightly away from the chicken towards the seafood risotto, and that was a GREAT choice. All of our appetizers - beef tartare, truffled mushroom risotto and a potato pancake topped with brie - DELISH. Even the basket of french bread was so good - crispy on the outside, soft on the inside. Do leave room for dessert - because the molten chocolate volcan is heavenly.

At the end of our meal, the owner came by to introduce himself and shake each of our hands to thank us for coming. Such a classy touch. Small business owners depend on their customers' word of mouth, and I am happy to spread the joy - cannot wait to try brunch next!
author: Kiesha R.

description:
Upscale food, casual atmosphere....I LOVE IT!!! (does that make sense?! oh well...to me it does ;-)

GREAT neighborhood bistro!!!  Unassuming, unpretentious and just plain ole good french food.
