My husband and I were still having withdrawals from our recent trip to France and wow...this place just took us back.  The food was excellent, the service and staff were friendly and family oriented, wine selection was great.

Warm Brie over potato pancake salad - how original!  The cheese and potato pancake mixed with organic greens just blended so well in our palates.  Beef Bourguignon tender as "heck" and sauce so rich but not overwhelming, Rack of Lamb was not gamey at all, tender, juicy and flavorful with that awesome Ratatouille...(and my husband is not a vegetable person) LOVED it! and for dessert...we asked for a recommendation and viola...perfect!  warm apple turnover thingy...hehehe...and presentation of the food was something out of Fleur de Lys but not Fleur de lys prices.

Overall, we had a superb dining experience without breaking bank! 

"Les aliments délicieux et excellent service. Merci d'une grande expérience à manger."
author: Grace D.

description:
I've been to Bistro Central Parc 4 times now and I've never been disappointed. 
The food is fantastic, the service attentive and the place has a good vibe. I found the crowd to be an interesting mix of young and older folks depending on how early or late you are there.
The owners are always on site and are most welcoming and sweet.
Parking, surprisingly, has not been a problem...
Truly a gem....
author: Anita B.

description:
Maybe they know how to do dinner???

As for breakfast, it's a bad joke.  

Well... back to Chef and Butler!
author: Dan M.

description:
This makes for a great neighborhood french dining spot.  The food is good food.  The ambiance is just shy of romantic but makes it fun and inviting.  And absolutely great service.  

My family took me here for my birthday and we went to town on the menu (just the way we Kwongs do it)

-Escargots - these were ok.  a bit on the bittery side i guess from the pesto
-Beef tartare - tasted good
-Bread - and the fried ones at that were amazing 
-French onion soup - nothing outstanding but still really good
-Salmon trio - a bit of a disappointment. It's mainly just smoked salmon and a little bit of roe....i was hoping for like sashimi or something, but my bad for thinking japanese cuisine?
-Duck confit - this was really good on its own, but the lentils are just not my thing
-Scallops - these were ok  but risotto was pretty good since it was packed with a lot of cream and butter and cheese...yUM
-Foie Gras over the filet mignon - good.  
-Sea bass fish special - this was ok but on the smaller serving size 

In all, the portions are fair, not super generous as one reviewer seemed to state.  (sorry. We eat a lot)

And for my birthday, they let me take home a mug!  how cool is that?!  So definitely, this will now be a local favorite French restaurant.  Looking forward to my next visit!
author: Vincent K.

description:
Brunch: the French toast was ahhhmazing. Like woah. 5 stars.

Service was less than mediocre from the cranky older woman (the actual French waitress was too sweet though and therefore makes me more inclined to give 4 stars rather than 3 overall).
author: Lindsay A.

description:
Wonderfully prepared French food at an affordable price!!! I came here recently with friends and thought the food was fabulous.  I ordered the french onion soup and the risotto with lobster sauce and scallops.  The french onion soup was good but the risotto was phenomenal.  Scallops were perfectly seared (not too raw and not overcooked).  The risotto was very flavorful.  One of y friends had the steak frites and said it was perfectly cooked (medium rare as requested) and well seasoned.  Most of the entrees are under $20 and every day they have a their daily specials.  Can't wait to come again to try the other entrees!

It's located in a somewhat obscure location in NOPA and parking can be a tad difficult to find but well worth it. I recommend making reservations given the restaurant isn't that large. If you get there early, you can sit on the counter (first come first serve).
author: christina t.

description:
The restaurant is in our neighborhood and we love it.  We bring family and friends whenever we have visitors.  
The food is consistenyl amazing.  The waitstaff is friendly and the service is great!
I love coming here and I love feeling confident that we can count on great food and a great ambiance!
author: Lexi F.

description: A wonderful atmosphere, and even more wonderful food. My husband and I went on Valentines Day, and we were not disappointed. The owner is very friendly and kind, and he greeted everyone at the door. He gave me a rose on the way out, which I thought was pretty cool. I had the Braised beef cheeks. They were pretty good, but had a pretty strong flavor of wine, which I do not love, but that's just a personal preference. The meat was cooked perfectly, and fell apart in my mouth. I had something chocolatey for dessert. I don't remember exactly what it was, but it was delightful. My husband had the halibut, which was amazing. Oh and also, the prices were great!!
author: Emily D.

description: I liked this place! It is a small and cute french bistro - not too fancy or anything like that. Great service and good food. We were able to get reservations here the same evening - unlike some of the other very popular restaurants. The food is reasonably priced with most entrees between $20-$25. We had steak frites and the risotto with scallops. The scallops were really good. Although we enjoyed our food - as visitors to SF we would probably try a different restaurant next time we visit!
author: Julie P.

description:
My husband and I dined here in October for our anniversary. We didn't know anything about it and left feeling like we had been going there for years. Right off the bat, the service is impeccable. We felt extremely taken care of. From suggestions on appetizers to wine to entrees - every question was answered with incredible knowledge. The food is outstanding. Traditional French dishes but the highlights are their specials. Wow! They blew us away. When dined pleasantly for a few hours. Desert was on the house along with a delicious glass of desert wine. Jacques, the owner, came around to welcome us and thank us for our visit. He was a joy to talk to. 

When we returned this past week, the server and owner recognized us immediately and we were again treated like family :) This is our spot now! Can't wait to go back again!!!
author: Corri C.

description:
Nice, small, and relaxed atmosphere.  The restaurant can accommodate small groups, which is good for casual conversations. Can get a bit loud at times since they have live artist as entertainment. 

Food is decent, but the entree that really stood out was the risotto. Consistency of the rice was perfect and the flavor was exquisite.

Service was good. Waitress was attentive. 

There is only street parking, but if you get lucky the owner will allow you to block his driveway. A BIG PLUS!
author: Foodie F.

description:
Tonight, I came here with 3 other people to celebrate my birthday and another person's birthday.  (meaning that I didn't have to pay for my meal). 

The location is very narrow with plenty of natural light streaming in from side and front windows.  If you blink, you would miss it, as it blends into the neighborhood and the front of the restaurant appears almost like a house/apt building entrance way.

We were seated immediately.  Service was friendly.  The menu consisted of select choices of  classical French Bistro fare.  In addition to the menu, there were choices of specialties and of course, a list of WINE.

Members of my party ordered the following appetizers:
The food was good, classical French Bistro fare.  
baked cod
endive salad
wild mushroom risotto with truffle oil

Out of the 3, the mushroom risotto was my clear favorite.  Luckily, one of the diners in my group had been here before and did request the risotto be cooked more, so that it would arrive LESS al dente.  Even with that, the risotto was quite firm, but the mushrooms and the truffle oil imparted such a lovely, strong, pleasant flavor, that I have to recommend it. 

The baked cod, on the other hand, was just curious. I believe that it was mixed with mashed potato (potato puree), and sprinkled with bread crumbs.  Yet, it really lacked flavor, but the  consistency made it interesting enough for me to continue trying to pull out some thought about whether I liked it or not.  In the end, I'm still left up in the air.  It felt like it was missing a key flavor ingredient.  The fishy aftertaste could have used something to offset it.

The endive salad with raspberry dressing, pear and Roquefort cheese was light and refreshing, while the cheese imparted a strong pungency.

One of the diners in my party ordered the mussels in garlic, butter and white wine sauce.  He said that it was ok.  Unfortunately, my lesson learned from other shellfish experiences is that I'm allergic.  So, I can have no shellfish.

I also tried a bite of the lamb shank, which was tender and the sauce was not overpowering, but complimented the meat quite well..

Yet, my dish, the beef bourguignon was presented in a very different way.  It was a small portion served over potato puree.  The presentation was quite like a mini volcano with a ring of mashed potato around a mountain of stewed beef.  The flavor was slightly salty, but the beef was so tender that no knife was necessary (even though, I did use my knife before I realized this).

The highlight of the meal for me:  the profiteroles dessert and the kir royal.  I'm all about the carbs...

Three mini puff pastries sandwhiching little balls of ice cream and drenched in HOT chocolatesyrup.  *sigh*...  It was just the right portion size to make me comfortably full.

My friends had ordered the vanilla creme brulee.  The caramelized sugar topping was just the right consistency to get the desired "crackle" sound when you tap it lightly with a spoon (yes, I listen to it) and the custard was smooth.  Overall, not bad flavor.  Not the best that I've had, but definitely not the worst.

For 4 people, the bill came to ~$150 - ish for 3 apps, 4 entrees, 2 desserts and 2 glasses of wine (incl. tip, sans tax)

All in all, a solid meal.  Not the best French meal that I've had in the city and definitely not the worst.  The owner has charm and the restaurant is a cute addition to the neighborhood.

I've been to the Baker Street Bistro before and like the brunch there...maybe, I should try Bistro Central Parc for brunch next time?

Luckily, parking was plentiful today, but the area is hit or miss.
author: Hiromi N.

description:
This review is only relevant to the brunch, I have yet to enjoy dinner at the bistro.

This is a very pleasant restaurant with a comfortable ambiance and classy/clean wood decor.

Both times I dined here were the result of an excessive wait at Zazie (which I prefer).

Moules mariniere solid, but the broth was not as fulfilling as hoped.  The croque monsieur delicious, as it should be.

Overall, a nice place with good food.  Nothing exceptional so far, and a bit expensive, but a nice alternative if Zazie is too crazy.
author: Phil P.

description:
Thank you, Yelp, for helping me find yet another gem...no diamond...no GOLDMINE in the city!  Of all the French restaurants around...I have to say that Bistro Central Parc is one of the best (and that's saying a lot...)  

Service: Impeccable.  From the moment I called to make a reservation (she gathered that we were having an early dinner to catch a Saturday night show and made sure that we would get outta there on time) to the minute we were greeted as we exited the restaurant.  IMPECCABLE.  Personalized service, smart, attentive and friendly.

Food: Beautiful.  From gorgeous presentation to scrumptious eats...It doesn't get better than this.  We were a party of 8, so I'll summarize some of the highlights that I would definitely recommend:

French Onion Soup: I don't usually like French Onion, but I'd definitely order this next time.  It was packed with flavor and bubbling, hot cheese over it.

Kobe Beef Tartare: There goes the cute lil' quail egg again...It reminded us of wrapping up little wonton dumplings when we were younger, only we were eating it raw!  The beef was wonderfully marinated.  

Duck Breast: Hands down, the best dish...the duck was so tender, and everything that accompanied perfectly complemented but did not over power the meat.  If you love duck, you'll love duck at Bistro Central Parc.

Filet Mignon with Foie Gras and Black Truffle:  Did somebody say Foie Gras and Black Truffle?  Mine.  Second best dish...It was a special, off the menu, so I'm all about ordering the special of the night.  Medium rare filet cooked just as I like it, foie gras perfectly fat and the sauce was just rich enough to sop up and leave nothing on my plate.  I hated it.  Can I have another that wasn't so PERFECT?

As for dessert, ORDER EVERYTHING ON THE MENU...Everything came out like a work of art.  We didn't want to ruin the beauty of all the dishes, but they were too scrumptious for our tummies to ignore.  (I will have to say, however, that whomever said the Creme Brulee was the best they've ever had didn't have anything else on the dessert menu.)  

The Poached Pear: Easily a favorite!  A cored pear drenched in chocolate sauce.  Nuff said.

Molten Chocolate Cake: I've had some disappointing molten chocolate cakes, but this was the BEST EVER!  So warm, gooey and chocolatey that it made me imagine the horrid rain outside to actually be light flakes of snow.

I think I've found a spot to bring visitors that will make them feel jealous that I live in such an awesome city.
author: Jennifer L.

description: Not bad.  I think the price matches the quality of the food.  I had lamb and my wife had the duck.  Both were very tender and we had plenty to eat.  The service was great and the ambiance was nice and quiet.  The owner came out and made sure we were doing okay.
author: Rob W.

description:
Bistro Central Parc has completely changed my perspective on French dining. I had always thought adding "French" to the title of a restaurant was an excuse to be rude an elitist to your patrons while charging more money just because you added more butter to a dish. NOT SO HERE.

Recommendations

Pros:
-Family Operated: Probably owned by them as well, but I cannot speak to that. They are invested in the face and operation of the establishment and it shows.
-Food: spectacular! It is a very unassuming location tucked into a unlikely location for high-end dining, and, at the price point: i was expecting the standard far. I way WAY off. The food is immaculately presented and ever little detail of the dish is thought out. 
-Live Music: which they occasionally have at no cover
-Affordability: Again, based on the spectacular quality and presentation of the food, one would assume about 2x what ends up on your bill. GREAT VALUE

Cons:
-Noise: It can get a little loud in there, but one may still easily enjoy casual conversation.
-Seating: can be a little tight, so make a reservation.
-Smaller Menu: not a huge amount of variety
-Wine: this is where they getcha. Its pricy.
author: Nicholas S.

description: Seriously. SO GOOD. Really good French flavors, good wine (prices are great!). The baked brie is a MUST. The roasted garlic it comes with is perfection. And dessert... oh lord. We shared the chocolate lava cake, and it was heaven. The cake was perfect, and the filling buttery. Ambiance was perfect for a Valentines Day/Birthday Dinner for two. !0/10 would go right now if I could. Under $100 (before tip), for an appetizer, two entrees, a half bottle of wine, and a shared dessert. Perfect dinner!
author: Hannah A.

description:
nice to sit outside; fine to underwhelming food; and slow (and not perfectly precise) service

french toast - very unremarkable (not worth the calories); bread seemed like your basic white bread, and the fruit garnish a bit pathetic

frisee aux lardons with poached egg - best bite of the meal, but two poached eggs would have been much more generous

omelette - good, but again, not special 

if you don't have to wait, and you're in the neighborhood, it's a decent option, otherwise, explore elsewhere
author: Elizabeth D.

description:
Excellent food and presentation.  I had the filet which was easily the best I've yet to eat; my wife ordered the duck confit.  We thoroughly enjoyed our dinner and appreciated the service which was great, always available without being overly attentive and the beautiful presentation.  I gave it four stars because the dessert we ordered, tart tartan, was less buttery and a bit  too sweet for our tastes, but this was a minor detail in a stellar meal.

Stephen Kane
author: Stephen K.

description:
One of the best French Bistros in the Bay.  I have been hear three times, each time the Poisson du Jour blew me away.  As an example, I generally have pretty bad impressions with sea bass.  But for some reason the chef was able to retain the freshness of the sea bass without overwhelming the fish with spices to mask its taste. Don't even get me started with the trout Poisson du Jour... It was unbelievable.
The meat dishes I tried hear were ok, but I would definitely come back hear for the sea food concoctions.  
On a side note, The Foie gras salad appetizer was delicious as was the dessert.  Would definitely recommend this place to anybody.
Several suggestions:

1)  The place is small, so make reservations before coming here.  I was able to make reservation the same day before arriving.
2)  Parking can be a pain since this is in a residential area with street parking.  Plan to arrive 20 minutes prior to reservation to find parking.  If all else fails, try parking at the nearby Lucky 2hour parking lot several blocks away.
3)  The food is a bit pricey so don't be too shocked when you get the bill.  However, I think this is the few times where the taste justifies the price.
author: Al C.

description:
If your looking for authentic in your dining experiences, this is the place for you. Right down to Franko the server who takes every table in the place solo with the greatest of ease, well that is until everyone arrives at once. Jacque, the owner and maître d extraordinaire, schmooze's and welcomes waiting guest as if it were his own house.

Thank goodness we're only a block away. Everything from the escargot to the duck confit, I have yet to find a dish that didn't make me speechless. Their specials usually include a beautiful sirloin topped with fois gras and a sauce I want to bathe in. I don't know who their saucier is, but they have a gift! 

The wine list makes me so happy...not overwhelming and with some amazing French reds to go with the amazing French food.

The chef is so wonderful and excited about his food. I just wish I had paid more attention in my high school French class so I could understand him. He is the real deal and as far as I can tell, they are all family in some way. This just adds more to the romanticism to the whole restaurant.

Hidden away on Grove and Central, it looks like it should be someone's apartment. Well, Jacque's apartment to be exact.
 Prepare to be pampered and fed.
author: Kate M.

description:
Two words: Tournedos Rosseni!
And some more words: This used to be our local until we moved across the bridge, but we will be back, and often, because every dish is superb, the staff is friendly, the atmosphere is candlelit.  Jacques et Bistro Central Parc c'est magnifique!
author: Lynne R.

description: The place was packed, the service was a bit lacking though. Very rushed with entree decision after waiting quite some time like at least 15 min for our drink selection. Bottom line: good food, bad service.
author: Chrissie M.

description:
I really recommend!
I have been there 3 times already and I really love that place. As a Belgian, I really appreciate French food and have pretty high standards.

This place is this intimate restaurant with affordable prices and good food. The owner is really nice and welcome you when you arrive. It's always better to make a reservation because it's always full.

I personally like their capaccio, their boullabaise is a must to try if you like fish (it's one of the best I had in the city). I also like their lambs and some of their "suggestions du jour".
author: caroline s.

description:
The rarity of rating any restaurant 5-stars must mean it's that freakin' good... and Bistro Central Parc rightly deserves this award. 

We booked our reservation for a Saturday night dinner for two about a week ago on trusty Opentable (we like to rack up points for the dinner vouchers). I've always heard great things about this place and I knew that it was eventually gonna be on our list of "places to eat while in SF".

Parking was tricky. We circled about 10-15 minutes around the surrounding areas and because it was located in a, mainly residential, area, we had to park on the main artery, Masonic, running through that part of NOPA.

Walking in, we expected a French bistro vibe (hence the name), but we got more of a modern San Francisco modern restaurant vibe. When we think of french bistro, the memory of eating at NYC's Pastis always comes to mind. We arrived nearly an hour early of our 830pm reservations but were promptly seated at the bar. I was disappointed, at first, but once the first course meals started arriving, I forgot all about it.

The bartender, who had an awesome French accent, was very knowledgeable in the menu items. For hour`derves, we opted for the sweetbread with wild mushrooms and french onion soup, which both were exquisite, especially the sweetbread. I'm not usually a fan of organ meats, but the blend of mushrooms and the accompanying port sauce with the actual meat made it for a delicious first course. 

Main dishes included the seared scallops atop lobster risotto, which, by far, was the most amazing risotto I had tasted in San Francisco. Something about the balanced creaminess with the soft texture of the scallops, my partner also was amazed at how rich and flavor full it was. My BF ordered the fish of the day: halibut with sliced potatoes. His first reaction after biting into the potatoes, "this has got to be the best tasting potatoes I have ever eaten." Not that we're huge on throwing those heavy terms like "best" and "ever" around, but our experience here definitely deserved those descriptions. 

Volcan au chocolate was our choice of dessert. The presentation was equally as impressive as the taste. Chocolate syrup designs, filled in with color, was used to create an intricate artwork that likened to a glass mosaic that you'd find in a cathedral. The cake was soft on the outside and warm and gooey on the inside. Perfect ending to a great culinary adventure. 

It came out to about $91 total for 2 appetizers, 2 mains and 1 dessert. This restaurant's food quality compares to another affordable SF French restaurant, Chapeu, and lives up to it's name of being a true bistro with excellent food and awesome service. This is not our last time that we'll eat here. HIGHLY HIGHLY RECOMMENDED.
author: Carloalexi M.

description:
My girlfriend and I  found this place through the yelp application on my blackberry.  We didn't know what to expect, but we were surprised by the Bistro.

This place is one of the neat places that seem to dot the San Fran restaurant scene.  It's a true French Bistro, our waiter was French, the cuisine was too, and it appeared that English was the minority language in the Sunday night crowd.  It was like for a few moments I had walked out of the Golden Gate Park area straight into the left bank of the Seine.

The meal was presented well, the portions were filling, but not overwhelming.  The staff was great at introducing a pair of Americains to true french food.

The restaurant itself sits at the corner of a pair of residential streets.  It's not in a street full of other restaurants, you really have to seek it out.  However that quest is well worth it for a unique french meal.
author: Travis N.

description:
Great neighborhood French bistro with excellent service.  Friendly, warm and entertaining waiter Gerome.  Jacque the owner equally as friendly and warm.
Food delicious from start to finish.  Tried the daily specials....duck confit salad, beet salad, beef cheeks, rack of lamb and to die for desserts.  Definitely will return!
author: Cincia H.

description: Lovely ambiance, delicious food, and friendly service. This place is a gem in the Nopa area that is a great treat for a date night out. A little on the pricier side, but well worth it!
author: Lauren D.

description:
BISTRO CENTRAL PARC is a wonderful modern French bistro/cafe with... ATMOSPHERE! ATMOSPHERE! ATMOSPHERE! 

Ultra modern setting with comfortable seats, cool black concrete floors highlighted with copper trim, & pleasent flower arrangements throughout the restaurant ! TRES CHIC!  

BRUNCH was wonderful when went went on a lovely sunny San Francisco Sunday.  The modern, clean lines of the bistro just shined in the brillant sunlight. It would look stunning at night!

EGGS BENEDICT were the BEST, yes, you read that right, THE BEST that I have ever had in SAN FRANCISCO. 

The EGGS BENEDICT veggie version was perfectly prepared eggs over a properly cooked bed of deep green spinach with a soft touch of 'sauce'. The muffins were nicely toasted. 

But, back to that 'sauce' ! IT WAS PERFECT! Not too much. Just the right amount to add to the flavor and NOT sog down the muffin, nor the taste buds!  HEAVEN!!!  (see my photo)

The EGGS BENDICT with SALMON was also beautifully prepared with just the right amount of sauce, and a good helping of salmon. Throughly enjoyed. (photo, too)

CROQUE MONSIEUR- finely sliced ham inbetween two slices of toasted bread covered with incredible melted cheese. OUI OUI C'EST MAGNIFIQUE!  (see my mouth-watering photo) 

The POMMES FRITES were like the wonderful tasting fries found in the cafes of  PARIS! Nicely crisp and tasty! 

PAIN PERDU-'FRENCH TOAST'- This was a nicely prepared breakfast item, with a side of fresh fruit and creme anglais. Tasty .    

The service was a little relaxed, coffee came a tad late & refils had to be asked for repeatly, though, one would probally blame that on the sunny day.  The waiter and waitress were so charming and sweet, it would be impossible to fault them in any way.  We maxed tipped them for their service.

Helpful suggestions:  (Hence the 4 stars, and not 5 stars) It would be nice to have a full dessert menu at lunch. (We were so in the mood for creme brulee. It's a French restaurant after all!)  Wine lists should always be offered to each table no matter what the time of day! The 'NO SUBTITUTIONS' of any menu items is a tad harsh!   

OVERALL the BISTRO CENTRAL PARC is a charming visit to a modern PARIS cafe setting with great food , lovely staff, and the forever charming CHEF JACQUES!
author: Addadada A.

description: We went here a couple of weeks ago on a Sunday night for dinner. I'll echo what everyone else has said about Bistro Central Parc. Very nice food, well-priced, great service, very warm welcome. We'll be back.
author: David G.

description:
Wow.  Fantastic classic and affordable French food with attentive service in a casual atmosphere, and it's in my neighborhood!  Most of the staff are French, not that that's a must, but it makes the experience more authentic.  Unlike most French restaurants which are more upscale than jeans and a tshirt, this place is super casual.  In fact  two of the French waiters we saw were wearing black skull tshirts and jeans and both have half sleeve tats on their arms.  The owner is super nice and welcoming.  He walks around and converses with the patrons and makes sure they're having a good experience.

The food was awesome.  For starters, we had the Escargots Bourguignon  which were as good as I've had anywhere, and Galette De Pomme De Terre, Brie Chaud which is warm brie on a potato pancake and a mizuna arugula salad.  For the main course, I had the filet mignon with foie gras sitting atop a potato gratin with green peppercorn sauce.  Yum.  My friend had the sweet bread stuffed rabbit with poached pears and a balsamic reduction.  Yum again.  Dessert was vanilla Creme Brulee we shared.  Yum a third time.

If there's one thing I can criticize about is that we noticed when the waiters were pushing tables together to accomodate a large party, there were empty packages of sweetener and chunks of bread laying on the floor and they walked by it several times and no one bothered to sweep it up.  In fact they put a table over it and just kicked it underneath.  More attention should be paid to cleanliness IMO.
author: P.J. D.

description:
I'd like to simply echo what other reviewers have written here, and say that this place is a neighborhood gem. My review will be focusing on my brunch experiences. I have not been for dinner here yet, but I expect it to be just as fabulous.

I've ordered the Croque Monsieur and the Salmon Eggs Benedict. The Croque's bechamel sauce adds a nice creamy layer that complements the cheese and ham. It's crisp on the outside and juicy on the inside.

The Salmon Eggs Benedict is made with fresh eggs. The hollandaise sauce is spot on in terms of saltiness and flavor.

The rosemary garlic potatoes that can accompany both dishes isn't heavy handed with the rosemary. 

When you come in you are greeted and seated where you like. The last time I was there was Halloween, and some of the staff were dressed up. You could tell that they really cared about the place, and best of all, the customers.
author: Jim B.

description: The food  has been fantastic both times, and the server (I think owner) is always very friendly. The last visit, service was a bit spotty but I think they were just too busy. Highly recommended.
author: Blair S.

description: Love the casual yet intimate environment here.  The pork chops here come deliciously close to rivaling NOPA.
author: Jenny K.

description: This is an great place to dine.   The cassoulet is out of this world.  The staff are very friendly and prompt.
author: Justin S.

description: Today I thought I would just stop by and say Hi to Jacques, my old coffee mate from the hood.....it was more than a visit let me tell you. I walked in & was immediately escorted to a seat by Jacques next to a single woman from DC. Turned out to be a very delicious choice, she was getting the bone marrow dish which they only serve here and there...it was us and the angles singing together so tasty..... What a great experience and so happy to meet the professor from Virginia and the lovely healing coach from Virginia too. The culinary experience is unsurpassed!
author: Steiner A.

description: This little place is an amazingly great French cuisine spot! Experience was great, came here with family.
author: Charlton H.

description:
This is our "go to" neighborhood bistro, though I'd travel from afar to eat here. It's only been around for five years or so but it has a feel of being an old-timer in the best sense of the word.  The staff are all very friendly and accommodating without being obsequious. They always greet us as if we are there every week when in reality it's just every couple of months.  They are good about squeezing us in with last minute reservations or with none at all.  The prices are fair and the wine list is pretty good and they offer a nice range of prices.  
The other night we took a friend there for a farewell dinner and all three of us were quite pleased (as usual) with our meals.  The duck confit salad is delicious and so was the special calamari salad. The mussels (and go ahead and order the fries...) are always perfectly done and meaty. We usually get the traditional broth but the curry flavored option is also quite good.
The duck breast is perfectly cooked and they don't overdo the sweet aspect of the accompanying sauce.  My husband pretty much always gets the filet mignon and it's really one of the most delicious and dependably tender versions in the city.  I'm not a lover of beef but I always have a taste and each time it's perfection. 
For dessert we split two: the molten cake and the crème brulee.  Molten cakes are starting to seem a bit cliché to me these days but the way they do it here at Central Parc is well worth trying.  Just oozing chocolate deliciousness. The crème brulee was also quite good.  As usual, we left satisfied and happy.
As as aside, we went there last New Year's Eve because we just wanted to stay in the area and not have to drive etc.  Usually I hesitate to got restaurants on NYE (or Valentine's Day...) due to the set menus and harried service.  Here they did a great thing: they kept their regular menu but broke the evening down into seatings.  We got the 7:30 seating (at the bar - it was a last minute decision) and it was just the usual delicious food without the rush and crush feeling of NYE. Their next seating started at 9:30 and there was no rushing us out, even though we were probably just wrapping it up at 9.  Also we've sat at the bar a few times and have really enjoyed it.  Anyway, we love this place, the food and all the hard working staff.
author: Patrick D.

description:
Hidden gem in the neighborhood.  Food is excellent quality.  Staff are friendly and helpful.  Haven't had a bad experience yet.

Special recognition to the wine list; which is all around the same reasonable price point.  Lets you ask for a staff recommendation and enjoy what comes back...
author: S M.

description:
Love love Bistro Central Parc!

From the Steak Tartare to the very friendly staff. Jack and his wife are great hosts and we certainly can't wait to go back!

Un grand merci!
author: Nez B.

description:
I ate only brunch here, and it was good. I'd come back for dinner and thus would hope to enjoy the food even more, based on other reviews. Overall, my experience was fine, though not exemplary. 

The sign above the door is subtle, such that I walked right past the restaurant the first time. The interior is larger than it would appear, which is helpful because table-turning isn't the owners' goal. The service is French: helpful and efficient, yet operating more leisurely than a typical American pace. Admittedly, I needed to reset my internal clock in order to stay relaxed and present. 

We appreciated the bottle of water (free, choice of sparkling or still) on the table. Also, steamed milk for coffee and truly fresh orange juice were welcome touches. 

My omelette was good, plump but not undercooked, and full of spinach, mushroom, swiss. The eggs benedict were only ok however.
author: Mike H.

description:
We had one of the worst dining experiences this last Saturday evening.

Went there on Saturday evening after setting up a reservation for 9:30 via OpenTable. Showed up and they didn't have a table ready so we agreed to be seated outside even though it wasn't our preference. 

We ordered the carrot ginger soup for both and the wild mushroom risotto to start and then the filet mignon and the chicken breast for our main entrees.

It took awhile to receive anything to nosh on but finally received one piece of warm bread each. 

The soups and risotto came about ten minutes later. 

After that it became frustrating. Our waitress was scarce. We had to ask other passing staff for more bread, butter, even water. 

We waited for our entrees for over forty minutes. Our original waitress finally came by and told us our order had been placed behind a large party.  "That is the way the orders fell", she said.  No apologies or offer to comp us anything for the inconvenience.  Just rude.

The manager then came by and asked us about our meal.  We told him that we were not happy with the lack of service and extended wait for our food.  He said, "it happens", shrugged his shoulders and walked away.  What an ass.

Sorry...we have been to L'ardoise, Le Charm, Chapeau! and even Chez Maman and had better service.  At each of those listed we have seen the restaurants handle large groups and our smaller couple without extended waits...so sorry, no excuse here BCP.

The Food: 3 to 4 stars
The Service: 2 for the waitress, 1 for the manager.
author: Thomas E.

description:
Wow!! Such an awesome service and delicious food! Like some reviewers say, this restaurant is the hidden gem of SF. It was a bit hard to find this place because I couldn't see the sign; its location in residential area didn't really help, either. Parking was pretty bad--there is no specific parking lot for this restaurant. So by the time I found this restaurant, I was crossing my fingers, hoping that it was good.

So my friends and I went into the restaurant. The waiter who greeted us was super nice. The atmosphere was great and somewhat romantic as well with their dim lighting. 

The food was so delicious, too. We ordered Magret de Canard, Carre D'Agneau, Filet Mignon, and onion soup, and all of them were great. I particularly loved the onion soup because of the cheese. It was my first time trying the lamb so I was a bit nervous about it, but it went very well. 

One thing I really liked was the portion--it wasn't too much or too little. So we were glad that we didn't share our plates. But of course, for the amount of food we got, it was a bit pricey. Overall, though, I'd come here if I get another chance to visit SF.
author: Katherine B.

description: Loved the food.  Great Scallops and Filet of Sole special.  Half french half local staff.  Great service.  I will be back to try more of their food.  Loved it and worth the not so inflated price
author: Hans S.

description: The restaurant didn't hold up on a second visit. The hangar steak, which was supposed to be medium but was well done, was so tough I worried about my teeth, so I had to spit out the only piece I ate and hide it under the pommes frites. The sauce on the steak was thick like it had been sitting around for a while. The sweetbreads tasted like they were not cooked to order, and the poached egg on the frisee lardon was cold. At best, this is neighborhood fare at higher end restaurant prices.
author: Sarita O.

description:
My GF said, "Hey Bu, I just heard a radio show that the guy who used to own Baker Street  Bistro opened a new restaurant."

Me, "Oh No, I liked Baker Street  Bistro. But where?"

My GF, " Central and Grove."

I was like, " That's not that bad."

We were looking for a restaurant because my number 2 son  just got back for summer from NY. I wanted to take him out for dinner.

I made a reservation for 3.

So, I went to pick my son up and drive down to Hayes Valley but we found out the place is on "Central Ave'. 

I was like, "Where the Hell is Central Ave?"

My #2 son said, "A block way from Masonic."

My #2 son went on to say, " That's not Hayes Valley. Not even close."

My #2 son said', "This is NOPA."

I was like, "Whatthe NOPA?"

My #2 son, "North of Pan-handle."

I was like, " Oh, It's not a good area, No papa No ma. North of Pan-handling. Jesus."

So, we were looking for a parking but found 2 blocks away. 
it wasn't that hard.
It is pretty good area now but It wasn't like this before. 
I remember when I was a student, I lived Fullton and Central for 2 years, only a block away from the restaurant. It was really  filthy neighborhood. 
Anyway,
We walk into the corner entry, a big narrow hard wood door, we took the table right by the door, the owner came, my GF was there, they speak French something, my #2 son speaks French too, I speak Japanese but that doesn't count. 

Menu:
We shared a Galette Brie Chaud, Potato pan cake and a thick Brie cheese on it and a bunch of Mizuna, Japanese water green vegetable underneah.

My GF had Lamb carre, medium rare.
My #2 son got Duck leg.
I got Filet Mignon, medium rare.

About the desserts:
My GF had Fraises de la Modena
My #2 son got Tarte Tatin
I got Profiteroles.

Profiteroles was A Bomb!
It's kind of a childish sweets but I loved it.
It's 3 small eclairs but vanilla ice cream in it.

Like I said, the area used be a not too nice area but ... it's nice out here.
Really!
My GF and my #2 son were talking about how NY changed.
They were talking about that there was an idea in NY few years back.
The Mayer of NY decided to put a free porn TV program to keep dubious people at home.
Really?
Free Porn TV?
I'll stay home.
No, I am kidding but God sakes that was it?
Really?
FXXX! Why didn't any one think that?

Well, I think most city in US isn't really safe because we don't have good education system in the Government.
Lack of education.

How about SF?
What a happen to this area?

I do hope the place stay here for long.
Btw, the food was excellent. Sexcellent, I should say.
The service was absolutely wonderful.

... need a shade for the front door.

I just wonder that who took over the Baker St Bistro.
I miss the place.
author: Nobu K.

description: Exquisite and deserves the 4.5 help rating.  We went for brunch today and the service was excellent.  French toast was awesome and husband raved about the risotto and crime brûlée.  First visit and we will be back!
author: Ottis M.

description: One of my favorite restaurants in the city. Filet mignon, pommes frites and a glass of red wine is my usual happiness! Very reasonable prices. We tried the brunch for the first time a couple weeks ago. Loved the Croque Madame! Solid good food everytime.
author: Alanur K.

description: Sat at the bar and had a great meal with great service to boot! Our server was fun, informative and right on with his recommendations from the wine, dinner and dessert!
author: MARCUS L.

description: Nom nom nom. This place was amazing! I came here with my family for my dad and sister's birthday. I have to give it a 5 star because their customer service and the food was too good. The whole environment was great. There's a indoor seating and outdoor seating with heaters! For starters, the waiter brought us water and bread. The bread was soft and it was just good especially when you're super hungry! For appetizer, we ordered Moules marinieres (mussels with white wine, shallots , parsley, cream) and then for our main dishes, I ordered Risotto aux coquilles St Jacques (lobster risotto); my mom ordered Magret de canard (duck), my dad ordered the special which was some kind of fish, and my sister ordered Steak frites! It was amazing. I tried all 4 dishes. One thing that sorta sucks with my entree was that it's a really small portion. Like the plate is big but the portion is super small. I guess I should have expected that since we are in a 4.5 star restaurant....but yeah, I wish they had a bigger portion for fat Americans like me haha! :) For dessert, we ordered chocolate mousse, apple tart, and cream puffs with ice cream! It was yummy!!!!!!!!! The chocolate mousse had like chocolate filing in them and that was like mouth watering! Apple tart was also very tasty. The cream puffs with ice cream was also amazing. My dad really enjoyed his dessert. After we finish paying the bill which was around $200, we were walking out and the owner of the store was shaking our hand saying thank you to us and to come back soon which was super nice gesture. I'm hoping I can go here again because I definitely love the food besides the small portion lol.
author: Monica W.

description:
We had a very good food and good time at this restaurant.
We loved the steak tartare and the salmon tartare. Magret de canard was wonderful too. 
Serveurs were quite plaisant and sweet.
We will come back.
author: carole d.

description: Perfect little brunch bistro. Definitely cured my hangover and they don't bombard you with huge servings. Nice place. Have to go back for dinner one night
author: Mimi D.

description:
We were looking for a French place to eat lunch and yelped and found a bunch of places with good reviews, so we chose this one. Parking was difficult on a Saturday 11am. When we arrived 1/2 of the place was filled. We were seated and ordered our food. Nothing on the menu, except for the duck confit was French. They had mostly breakfast menu. i order the duck confit and my man ordered the NY steak w/ egg and fries. The food took forever to arrive, at least 40 minutes. The busy got super busy and they had waiters, whom never came to check on us during the entire meal. 

When the food finally came over, my dish was very skimp, just some lentils underneath a meager piece of duck leg. The duck had absolutely zero flavor--no marinade of any sort-- and seemed to have been dunked in oil for a quick deep fry. There was no sauce on it at all. It was completely dried & unpalatable, like a piece of leather.

The cooks are 3 latino men in the kitchen and it seemed nobody in the kitchen was properly trained in French cooking. I guess that's why the menu doesn't reflect any French dishes at all.  Even my man who isn't hard to please with food, agreed it was a bad meal. I won't be returning here. Very disappointed.
author: Tiffany W.

description:
Ok, at first glance this place looks quaint, quiet and understated.  There is really no reason that you would be in this area of Nopa at night and walking by, you might miss it.  But this is by far one of the best restaurants in San Francisco.  Here are my top ten reasons why:

1.  The food is consistently good everytime---the flavors, the presentation
2.  They have a great small, reasonable wine selection- I love the Sancere Sauvignon Blanc
3.  The staff is very attentive and charming- Jacques the owner is very friendly and the waitstaff has good recommendations
4.  Risotto with scallops and lobster sauce- I die!
5.  Beef tartar... I dream of it, and my dog dreams of the doggie bag
6.  Rossini--filet mignon with seared foie gras over scalloped potatoes with a wine reduction sauce- almost better than sex (I said almost...:)
7.  Frisee salad with lardons and a perfect soft poached egg... a whole lot of yum
8.  Asparagus soup--very fresh with not too much cream
9.  Creme brulee- heaven on a spoon
10. They have an open kitchen and the chef is not bad to look at while he is cooking your food;)

Go now, go often...
author: Suzann S.

description:
Dining here was such a wonderful experience! My girlfriend brought me here
for my birthday dinner and it was probably one of the best birthday dinners I've ever had- not just because of the food, which was incredible, but also because the staff is so friendly and welcoming. We told the host we had a reservation, he shook my hand and wished me a happy birthday. We were seated right away and our very friendly waiter greeted us shortly after. We ordered the baked brie and salmon duo to start, a bottle of '08 Cotes du Rhone, I chose the stuffed daurade which was one of the specials and my girlfriend ordered the steak frites. Our waiter came over with our wine and let me know that my mom had actually ordered us the bottle- she called ahead and paid for the wine for my birthday- pretty sweet of her I think. The wine was absolutely excellent! I was very impressed with the presentation of our appetizers- everything was plated carefully and beautifully! Not only did the food look good, but it tasted excellent as well! 

The fish I ordered was also delicious; it was stuffed with a mix of fennel, onion and bell pepper. Alongside the fish was a frisee salad which had a light and very good dressing. I loved my dish and ate the whole thing! I'm not a huge fan of dessert and we had eaten too much to even have room to think about dessert, but when the staff turned off the lights, sang happy birthday and served us a cream puff covered in chocolate we  found some room and had a few bites. I was also given a mug which was a very nice touch and a great souvenir as this is definitely an evening I want to remember. The owner of the restaurant also wished me a happy birthday and was so very warm and friendly. I love this place and if I wasn't leaving the city soon I would try to visit more regularly! I highly recommend this place to everyone.
author: Natalie M.

description:
Authentic French fare down to all the employees speaking to each other in French.  This place is small and cute and LOUD, but I attribute the loudness to GREAT FOOD.  

I have to say that our first impressions weren't the best.  With reservations set for 6:30, we strolled in at about 6:25 and were ignored for what seemed to be ages [reality of probably 3 minutes], but turns out the host [who is also owner/chef Jacques] was busy filling wine glasses for a table of oldies.  I guess oldies always trump the young'uns.  We were then informed that no tables were available and that it would probably be 30 minutes before one freed up.  Eh, wtf?

Anyhow, we decided to grab a glass of wine at the bar.  Here at the bar is where our night turned for the better and beyond.  The bartender was beautiful and had a sexy French accent, but most importantly, she was so incredibly nice that we decided to have our entire meal there.  After some previous yelping and our bartender/server's recommendations, we settled on:

Escargots Bourguignon [baked snails in garlic & parsley butter]: Came out bubbling and delicious, we used our bread to sop up the remaining butter.  

Risotto aux Coquilles St Jacques [seared scallops on risotto in lobster sauce]: The only food gripe of the night - scallops were extremely salty, but otherwise seared to perfection.  Risotto was al dente and lobster sauce tasty.  One of their most popular dishes.

Confit de Canard, Lentilles braisées [duck confit, braised lentils]: MUST ORDER.  The meat fell off the bone with a slight touch of my fork.  The skin was crispy and tasty a la lechon.  Shit I'm salivating.  If you like lentils, it's delicious.  I took leftovers home and actually had the lentils and sauce with some rice.  Hella bomb.

Creme Brulee: This alone makes the place a must try.  It is the best you will ever have.  Ever. Ever. Ever. 

Tab: $75 including wine for each of us. 

Parking: Good luck.  

We tipped our server well and if you sit at the bar, you will too.  I will be back soon to try more of their menu.

Take note: They recently took Beef Bourguignon off their menu.  Definite disappointment as it was what we came for but our meal did make up for that and more.
author: Heidi L.

description:
Would have loved to have tried this place, but when we arrived at 2:33pm we were told the kitchen was closed. 
Hours listed on Yelp are Lunch till 3pm, and the friendly staff said they have always closed at 2:30. 
Keep that in mind, the hours listed for lunch are inaccurate. 
Wouldn't have minded so much if we hadn't gone out of our way to go there. 
So this rating has nothing to do with the food, just the accuracy of web info.
author: Eric M.

description: So charming, delicious and authentic French. The owner Jacques was lovely and accomodating to my dear friends who had their wedding reception. We would love to return to this neighborhood gem on our next visit.
author: Annie R.

description:
05.07.10

BCP has been on my list to try since they opened.  I was expecting a quaint little neighborhood restaurant.  It surpassed expectations.

When you have a big group of people for a birthday dinner on a Friday night and no prior reservations, you start to panic.  BCP came to the rescue.  Not only did they make room for us, they treated the birthday boy to his dessert AND a souvenir BCP cup.

While the boys went for the lamb and the beef, I decided to cut back and went for the risotto.  Rich, flavorful, creamy and filling.  That's enough to bring me back.

When I think French food, I think hoity toity and expensive.  This felt like anything but.  The service is superb, and the owner even came out and chatted with us.

Thumbs up!
author: Jenny L.

description: It was OK- pretty average french bistro food- quantity left me hungry and price was still pretty high for the amount we got. I give them an A for effort but there are better places in the city to eat.
author: Minna S.

description:
Five stars for dinner, I had a lovely time at a big table, and the service was just lovely.  The owner REALLY wants you to like it, and most of the staff we saw appeared to actually be French.  There was a weird incident where the waiter overfilled the champagne to the point of spilling a half a glass onto the table and didn't really apologize or anything, but it didn't keep the experience from earning five stars for dinner.  I loved every dish, and the desserts I thought were fantastic.  The ambiance was lively without being too loud, and the service was attentive and genuine (minus weird champagne moment).

When I went back for brunch I was a little disappointed.  Why pay $4 more than pork store for an eggs benedict that tastes just the same as pork store?  And without the free mimosa?  And also, not to sound TOO much like a frenchie food snob, but I was REALLY hoping that if there were ONE place that I could get a REAL cafe au lait, with the two little pots, one with coffee and one with milk that you get to mix yourself, just like in France, that it would be Bistro Central Parc, you know?  It had all the ingredients for it, dedicated French owner, outdoor breakfast tables, I mean... I was really hoping.  But alas, no.  

So overall, 5 stars for dinner and 3 stars for brunch makes this place a 4 star spot.  I'll definitely go back.  For dinner.  And maybe brunch if it's sunny.  And I'm feeling bitchy enough to ask for two separate containers for a real au lait.  Maybe.
author: fraggle l.

description: One of our favorites after spending the day at the park!  Always good. Duck. Steak frites.
author: Brian W.

description: Oh man. This place was amazing. We came here after a day in the city, and it was a perfect ending. The food was delicious, the staff was super friendly, and we left fat and happy. We ordered the beet salad, the beef cheek (it was a special) and the filet mignon  - it was all amazing and I kind of wanted to eat like four more servings of all of it. We finished off with the beignets and they were amazing as well. Highly recommended! And make reservations - it's small and the outside isn't the best in foul weather.
author: Sarah K.

description:
I knew this place was going to be one of my favorite places when I passed by one day strolling through the neighborhood. 

Perfect Location.  This is kinda my ideal type of place, a quiet neighborhood bistro.  Nestled in NOPA away from the busy Fell and Divis.  The more local resident passerby add to the look and feel of a real nice European style restaurant. 

Ambiance takes advantage of this.  Nice, not too done-up, very casual, relaxed and social.  The owner was out and about tonight, chatting with people at the bar, people eating dinner, and even the dudes playing catch  in the street outside.  This is the quintessential homey bistro restaurant.

So the Bistro part.  Yes the food is fancy compared to the other stuff.  But that's okay.  Its ideal when you want that extra umph in your meal without putting that extra effort in your outfit.  That being said, I think they know best about the French comfort foods here.   Roasted Duck, Potato Pancake Salad, Dessert were the highlights of my meal.  I would come here anytime for that stuff, even if I am on a date or if it was a sweatpants kinda night.
author: Beef E.

description:
I made a reservation here couple weeks back for a friend's birthday and he loved it!

We decided to do outdoor seating because the weather was nice and they had heaters. The staff was extremely friendly from the beginning of our dining experience. They gave my friend a a mug and chased me down a block when i left my phone at the restaurant ( Thank you!! ). 

I loved everything we ordered besides the escargot. The scallop risotto and sweet breads with mushrooms were both deliciousss. Yum! My friend had the fillet Mignon; a little too dry for my taste. 

I would definitely recommend this place to fam & friends!
author: Patrice P.

description:
Jaques has another winner! Baker Street was such a homey place we were sad to see it go. Bistro Central Parc is another level of restaurant and Jaques has nailed it. The food and service are are superb. We had rissotto with mussels and lamb dinners. Can't wait to return on our next visit to the City.
Love Jaques, always the most gracious person!
author: chris a.

description: I came here as a nice treat to welcome myself back to the Bay Area after 6 long months of overseas travel. The staff were absolutely amazing in their service and showmanship of a classy brunch. The food was perfect to order, no onions, delicately presented and delicious to the last bite!
author: Jess C.

description: I really like this bistro! I have been there a few times and everything I had was delicious.
author: Chris H.

description: Very nice hidden gem, the food is good, the truffle risotto is fantastic, everyone is super nice & hospitable. The wine is good & the prices are not outrageous. A great go-to place since we live around the block!
author: Nicole L.

description: A fabulous experience from the warm and friendly atmosphere to the excellent food. We had the veal and Carbonara specials. For desert we tried the Profiteroles. A great choice! We will be back!
author: M R.

description: One of my favorite dinner date spots in the city. You get 5-star food without paying the 5-star $$$$. Highly recommend the escargot & beef tartare as appetizers, and duck confit as entree. Bouillabaisse is also exquisite.
author: Andrew M.

description: Came for brunch today. We ordered the pomme frites, lobster risotto with seared scallops, and the Croque Madame. We also got fresh squeezed orange juice and coffee. The service was prompt and the waiter/waitress was friendly. For us, the food was hit and miss. The pomme frites were $8.50 which seemed a bit much. They weren't anything special in my opinion. We were expecting better frites for 8.50. The fresh squeezed orange juice was from delicious oranges. The juice was great!  The coffee was good too! The Croque Madame was just okay. The ham used didn't seem like anything special. There was not a whole lot of cheese. However, the best part of the meal was hands down, the scallop risotto. The risotto was cooked to perfection with a delicious flavor. The scallops were seared to perfection and cooked just perfectly. Loved it! I would have given the restaurant a three, but because the risotto was so good, I bumped it up to a 4. We will have to try dinner some time. Worth going to.
author: Zachary J.

description: OMG! This place is absolutely amazing! It's very cute inside, and the casual atmosphere was nice. The food was unbelievable. I started with the cauliflower soup, which was lite and lovely. Nice subtle flavor. For my entree, I had the risotto in lobster sauce with scallops. The rice was cooked to perfection. The sauce was rich and flavorful. The scallops were prepared exactly right. I finished the evening with the profiteroles. Vanilla ice cream filled pieces of heaven complete with a delicious chocolate sauce. This was one of the best all around meals I've had in a very long time, and while I enjoy dressing up for dinner, having amazing food while wearing jeans was wonderful.
author: Jen S.

description: I celebrated my birthday here and it was fabulous.  Top-notch service and delicious food.  The restaurant is small but very cozy and charming.  The waiters are adorable with sexy french accents too ;).
author: C C.

description: We came here for my parents' birthday dinner.  Very French service, so they aren't in a rush to push you out.  We had a divine bottle of wine, for $40.  The service was great.  My mom and I had the daily fish special, Sole.  it was out of the park--perfect green beans, perfectly seared sole, and then a to-die-for reduced butter/caper sauce.  My boyfriend had the pork chop, which was huge, very hearty and almost like a BBQ.  We will definitely be back for the brunch or another occation.
author: Alicia U.

description:
Super cute neighborhood place!

Make reservations on the weekends! I think weeknights are not going to be too bad - they also have a long bar you can sit and order food at, as well as a robust wine list.

Jacques does walk around a lot and makes sure you food is good and you are enjoying your dining experience - everyone here is hard to understand = French. And very helpful (and one hot busboy-!).

we had:
fries - fine, hard to mess up. $5
Side of seasonal veggies $5 - very tasty.
Mussels - AMAZING, save some of the bread for dipping in the SAUCE - SO YUMMY
Escargot - very garlicky and good
This brie on potatoe pancake thing - yummy, large 'salad' portion under it.
Of the Mains:
Duck confit - good, tasty lentils and decent portion (for a French place). Not sure I would get it again.
Seafood risotto with scallops - Great, very tasty and lush.

Can't wait to come back and try the desserts or BRUNCH!!!
author: Jessica L.

description:
First off, make a reservation unless you are a fan of loitering in cramped spaces because this place fills up fast by 7pm. The size of the restaurant is relatively small and quaint (after all, it IS a bistro). Dinner is pretty pricey, a full meal (appetizer, entree, dessert) will rack up a bill of at least $40. Is the meal worth $40? Yes, if you order the right things.

For starters, the salmon tartare. It is visually appetizing, but the taste isn't really there. I didn't find that dish that good. Definitely wouldn't order that again. For the entree, I had the trout, it was really good, there were potatoes (I think) that were rolled up into balls and they tasted just like french fries.. It kinda makes me want to make my own french fry balls! And lastly I had the vanilla bean creme brulee. The creme brulee itself was flawless, but what really put it over the top was the temperature it was served at. For some reason, it was heated perfectly where the custard was just amazing. I know I know, 'amazing' is not a flavor, but if it were, it would be amazing flavored. Great restaurant nonetheless!
author: Ryan L.

description:
this is the greatest neighborhood hidden gem to ever exist.

brunch is good, but dinner is really where it's at. the filet is perfect, the atmosphere is cozy and the service is spot on. jerome has waited on us every time we've been and he's wonderful. very knowledgeable about the menu and wine list. i've never had anything on the menu that wasn't delicious.

this place blows other, more well-known, more expensive, restaurants out of the water.
author: Kristen A.

description:
Oh la la, a French bistro (with actually French people) right in my neighborhood? We stopped in for brunch this Sunday and were warmly greeted, almost like regulars... and after finishing my croque monsieur, will surely become one. 

I tend to judge French eateries by their steak frites at dinner and by their croques for something more simple and casual. Done right, this "Crispy Mister" of a sandwich can elicit moans and gasps of pleasure. All for a grilled (or fat fried) ham and cheese sandwich (well with a creamily decadent Béchamel sauce).  

BCP's version was perfect to the point of requiring a knife and fork to enjoy it completely. I wanted to luxuriate in the melted goodness, savor the cholesterol, if you will. 

Needless to say, I'm looking forward to my next visit, this time during the evening hours for a tantalizing tandem taste of red meat and red wine. But yes, you will most certainly see me back again for brunch.
author: Nish N.

description: The food is inexpensive, but it is not particularly good. It has a family-run feel (and the feel of a family out of its league), resulting in inattentive service and long waits for everything. We didn't get to order for 45 minutes, had to flag down the owner to order wine (which then took another 20 minutes to arrive), etc etc. Won't be back.
author: Charles D.

description:
SO EXCITED TO WRITE THIS REVIEW!!!!!

I live in the hood (up the street 1 block) and have been walking past this place for over  a year. Talk about the great anticipation for a french bistro so close to home. Tonight, we were finally able to walk inside of the bistro we saw being built for so long :))))

Okay, so here is the skinny: even though it was their opening night and they were slammed (people waiting outside and everything), it was a GREAT first impression. Here is why:

1. great vibe inside, after waiting for only a few minutes, sat at the bar immediately.  The staff said hello to us, and our waitress, I think her name was Christine, was very attentive and super super nice. Also, we loved their copper lined floors, pendant lights above the bar, and overall decor.

2. Menu & wine list is awesome! We tried all of their reds by the glass and they were delicious. My favorite was the Malbec. Food was superb! We had the mushroom and goat cheese tart for app, filet mignon and cornish hen for entree (both amazing), and the chocolate volcano for dessert.  We loved every single dish....they were each a slam dunk, made to perfection.

3. They take AMEX. this is huge for my husband and me. You wouldnt believe how many times we get told they do not take amex at a restaurant, super annoying!

4. Head Chef came to check up on us at least 3 times...SO nice of him and just so welcoming and truly caring.

After having 5 glasses of wine, 1 app, 2 entrees, and 1 dessert, the bill came out to $100.  Next time, we are bringing our own bottle of wine because corkage is only $15. Overall it was a fantastic meal and experience and I cant wait to come back at least once a week!!!!

Suggestions for the owners: having a red dessert wine on menu, a spell-checked dinner menu, and for the price, a more generous wine pour into the small wine glasses.
author: Veronica P.

description:
If I lived in this hood I would eat here at least once a week, Oh how lucky our friends T n T are to be living within walking distance to this little gem. We went here Friday around 8ish and the place was packed, thank goodness for reservations or else we would not have had a seat, props to the owner for having such a hit place and with only being open a week. good for you!
So about the food We had:
French onion soup  8.50- A little too sweet for my taste but not bad.
La Planche De Charcuterie- 15.50-  Good, I don't know if they make their own salumis  but the Pâtés and other cured meats had very good flavor.
Escargots- 9.50- Nice garlic and parsley flavor and cooked perfectly. 
Bouillabaisse avec sa rouille- 18.50 (cheap) All the seafood was fresh and again perfectly cooked, the sauce was very light and did not over power the fish. however  you could still taste hints of saffron and fresh tomatoes very very good.
Risotto with lobster sauce and scallops- 17.50- Creamy goodness and perfectly cooked scallops.
Mussels- 12.50- hmmmm I wanted to lick the sauce like cats lick milk
Desserts all 7.50 we tried Profiteroles-  really good cream puffs with chocolate and adorn with burnt sugar strings.  We also tried a few other but I can't remember right now so they did not stand out for me.
Coffee- Bleh, needs work.
author: Seb M.

description:
Came here at 9 on Friday with a group of 10 for a birthday dinner.  Even though the actual restaurant isn't huge, the overall atmosphere is pretty nice, and probably makes for a good date scene (saw a bunch of tables that seemed to confirm this).

I tried the rack of lamb and rattatouille, while some of my friends tried the filet mignon, and the pork loin.  Every meat was juicy and tender, and rather savory with whichever sauce pairings they gave.  I've been a little wary of French cuisine ever since I had a really dry duck confit two years back, but Bistro Central Parc has convinced me there is better food out available.  

Finally, for the price, it's a good amount of food.  Not overly expensive, and not "fatty American" portions.
author: Phil L.

description: We tried this Bistro last Fri night.  We had reservations but were running late.  I called and they were very gracious to allow us to come anyway.  We had a fabulous dinner.  Their simple mixed green salad was the best I have ever had!  A hint of fresh tarragon pushed it  over the top.  I had the NY steak, perfectly seasoned and perfectly medium rare.  It came with the best fries I have had in years.  Can't wait to return for their mussels.  The halibut was perfect and beautifully presented.  By the time we finished the line was out the door.
author: Bonnie R.

description:
What a find!  I think we like Bistro Central Parc even better than L'Ardoise.
Lovely, friendly place.  Everything that we ordered was excellent (the duck breast is a work of art!).  The chef was so accommodating to one member of our group who saw something that he liked from another table's customized menu; he sent out an order for us.
The desserts were fantastic - we had both the chocolate molten cake (with cherries!) and the claufoutis (kind of a cherry/pistachio bread pudding). 
The owner came over to greet us and was there to shake hands and say merci & au revoir when we left.  
We'll definitely return.
author: Maggie L.

description: love this place. My boyfriend took me there for my birthday. Amazing food and great service! We'll be back!
author: Tambo T.

description:
Do not go here if it seems busy. They just can't handle it.

I feel this place has fallen short of expectations. They have the typical "new restaurant syndrome" where they just don't have their act together (yet?). No quality control in food or service. They lack skills in attending to details and recovering after mistakes.

Three of us walked in on a Friday at 7, and stood at the door for a long while until we were acknowledged. Someone talked to one of us, asking if we had a reservation. When we said "No" he was about to walk away without saying a thing. He did not seem to know any formula for guesstimating a wait time, so we told him we'd come back in an hour and 45 minutes. When we returned at that time, we waited yet another 35-40 minutes to be seated at the bar. We came in at 7 and finally sat down at 9:20-ish, without much of an apology. The man who helped us, who  seemed to own the place, did not have any mind of time management and organization. They have no door greeting system and no one to write any reservations/names of parties with rhyme or reason.

I ordered the New York steak, which came out undercooked. The piece of meat was not good and the side pommes frittes  was very average. The bar tender also brought my friend the wrong dish (brought the duck confit instead of the duck breast). My other friend enjoyed her filet mignon. Their compensation was to take my friend's glass of wine off of the check.

Coming from the restaurant industry, I understand the stress and I am usually very flexible and accommodating when it comes to service mistakes. But this place really just had error after error on an average busy night. The bartender was nice and apologetic. The man who seemed like the owner sincerely invited us back. Nice people, but they are not ready to run a good business.
author: Kelly T.

description:
My Hottie Blade was out of town for this one and too bad because he missed an excellent dinner.  Our friend Rich lives in the neighborhood of Bistro Central Parc and wanted to give it a try so Fussy Fusspot went along.

Bistro Central Parc gets 43 of 50 Fussy Fusspot Points and 4 stars!  Fussy is tempted to give 5 stars because it was really great... but Fussy must stick to the scale and be fair.

---

Clean table and dishes?  5 of 5 points.

Yes, very clean.  All brand new and sparkly too.

Clean server? 5 of 5 points.

Several different people brought food over the course of the evening and they were all nice and clean.

Clean bathroom?  5 of 5 points.

Very clean with hot water for the sink and a garbage can right next to the door for the discarded towels.  Why is hot water an important component of the Fussy Fusspot scale?  Because the kitchen staff uses that bathroom too and the sign says they Must Wash Hands Before Returning To Work - but if they have only cold water running in the sink then how can they have really truly clean hands after washing?

Subtotal = 15 of 15 Fussy Points on the Clean Scale.  Perfect Score!  A+ for cleanliness.

Service?  5 of 5 points.

Excellent service from start to finish.  They even brought me some extra butter and you know how Fussy loves extra butter.

Ambiance?  5 of 5 points. 

Very nice combination of a France + San Francisco feeling.  Warm & cozy + clean & sleek at the same time.

Friends from Finland Practical Scale?  3 of 5 points. 

Quite practical for a restaurant in SF.  Parking in that neighborhood seemed reasonable and the restaurant was easily accessible for a wheelchair or other special needs.

Food?  9 of 10 points.   

Very high ratings on the food.  I had the duck confit in lentils.  Now we all know that Fussy Fusspot loves his duck confit and this one was excellent.

Price/Food ratio?  4 of 5 points.

Rich and I shared an appetizer and each had an entree.  Total $47 including tax.  Nice price for a casual middle-of-the-week dinner.

Bonus?  2 of 5 points.

Two bonus points!  One bonus point or the amazing and beautiful flower arrangement in the bathroom.  Second bonus point for the friendly way we were treated the entire evening.

Total:  43 Fussy Fusspot Points.
author: Fussy F.

description:
Wonderful little neighborhood dining destination. I've had the cassoulet, the short ribs and their chicken option usually rotates (sometimes it's half a chicken with raisins and carrots - amazing! and other times it's been just a chicken breast with varying preparation. 

Owner and service are always very friendly and attentive. Pricing is moderate. Dishes are simple but flavorful. Have only been for dinner so can't comment on brunch. Wine and beer only.
author: Steven H.

description: This place deserves all the good things that have been said about it.  We've been here many times and always had a good, reasonably priced meal.  This last time we got appetizers: french onion soup and escargot.  We've had both here before and both were better before, so it must have been an off night.  Our overall feeling of the place remains positive.
author: Greg W.

description:
Finally, a Valentine's Day with a +1.  Just you, me, and a stack of caselaw, baby, that's all I need.

On the spur of the moment, my valentine asked if I wanted to change our dinner plans to Bistro Central Parc.  I agreed, knowing nothing about it (except that it was French food, and this girl doesn't say no to cream and butter).

I love to cook (and eat), but I had never been to a non-Japanese restaurant that is as focused on presentation as much as quality of the food.   As much as the food was delicious (and it was!), the dishes arrived, looking like a work of art.  

One bottle of wine, mussels, scallops with risotto and lobster sauce (mine), and salmon over fennel and spinach with roe (his) later, we walked out, stuffed to the gills.  (The artistic presentation belied the fact that there was plenty of food on those plates.  Luckily, my valentine did not have to roll me home.)

What I liked the most was that as much as you might expect a place like this to be dripping in pretension, the staff was incredibly friendly (although I could only catch every other word due to their charming-but-heavy French accents).   They were equally as nice to us as a group of six older adults and a couple with a(n adorable) baby.  The chef came out several times to ask how everything was, and I ran out of superlatives to describe it.

Pricing: entrees ranged from about $15-30, appetizers from $10-15.  For the deliciousness and presentation involved, I would say it's well worth it.  The menu changes daily, which makes me want to come back frequently and try it all...well, maybe when I'm a real grownup with a real job.
author: Jennie K.

description:
Delicious and affordable French food with an approachable neighborhood atmosphere.  The dishes here are a great value-- $$ price for $$$ quality.  Meat entrees range from $15-$24.  I've gotten 1 starter, 1 main, and shared wine and dessert for under $60.

I've been here 3 times now and all the food I've tried was fantastic.  The 2 dishes I'd order again and again though are the moules marinieres (save your bread to dip in the leftover sauce!) and the braised beef cheeks.

I've found that Sunday nights are pretty easy to get a walk-in, but other nights have been packed so a reservation is needed.  Our server Alex has always been friendly and gives honest recommendations.

Bistro Central Parc has become my new standard for French food.

P.S. I'd also recommend Chez Papa Bistrot (in Potrero Hill) for similar food/prices.
author: S L.

description: One of the best restaurants in SF. Completely unpretentious neighborhood French restaurant that has delivered on every dish I've had the pleasure of partaking in. The beef tartare is an excellent, slightly spicy warmup. I generally eat one of the specials, but have also tried the lobster risotto. Everything is impeccable and the service is friendly, authentic, and warm.
author: Dave T.

description:
Wow! A French bistro *one block* from my house, in the outer reaches of Nopa! I'm still amazed that they have decided to set up in my neighborhood -- very pleased, but still, the pessimist in me is questioning how viable it is...

Nevertheless, we had to check it out - so we went by last night - the first Friday for the new place. The restaurant was very crowded (including - for sure - many regulars from the neighborhood.) Things were a bit chaotic -- to be expected, of course. We eventually got seated - the place feels a little bit cramped and congested - though, again, it is probably more crowded at the moment than it will be once things settle down.

Food, however, was uniformly excellent. Fairly predictable French staples, but our dishes were all elegantly served and mmmm... tasty. The mussels appetizer is served in a tasty broth - very plentiful serving. (Not "muscles", as the menu says -- it's unfortunate that the typos on the menu dont reflect the professionalism in the place.) For entrees, we ordered the peppercorn steak and the excellent scallops/risotto, along with a nice Burgundy -- recommended as a cheap but excellent option by the waitress.

No dessert -- we were too full to even consider it, but we were served glasses of dessert wine by the server, as an apology for our earlier (short) wait... a very nice gesture. In fact, the biggest positive for me was the wonderful, warm Gallic service -- the place feels inviting and friendly. There are clearly a few glitches at the moment, but the omens are good that there's a new, excellent restaurant in the neighborhood. (I just hope that the cynic in me is proven wrong...)
author: donal c.

description:
OK, it may be a few days premature to write a 'review' on Jacque's new restaurant - Central Parc, but this establishment fills a much needed void in the growing landscape of restaurants in the 'hood.  The opening is this Tues. 1/2/10, but a sneak peak of the menu shows a terrific assortment of choices including; Steak Fritte, Pasta's, Fish, Fowl and Vegetarian.

Jacque owned and operated Baker St. Bistro in Cow Hollow for the last 20 some years.  It was frequently listed in M. Bauer's top 100 in SF.  Lucky for NOPA/Western Addition or whatever you are calling it these days, he lives in the neighborhood and opened up something closer to home.   

One of the constants w/ Baker St. Bistro - in addition to the quality of the food- was the value for the dollar.  It looks like this philosophy will be continued at Central Parc w/ the avg. main course pricing in the 'teens.
