Additionally, the Prix Fixe option from Baker St. will be carried over to Central Parc with a price point of under $20.00 before 7 p.m.  

This is guaranteed to be a huge hit!  I have to rate it based on past experience (as Yelp won't let me go w/o some Star rating), but will update accordingly.
author: Stephen B.

description:
Grandma got the monkey for a sleepover so we tried out our new local restaurant.   We've been curious about this place when we heard the rumor that there was going to be a restaurant going into the building after it was finished.  (The former building was a victim of the "Pink House" crack house fire a couple of years back)

So after a cocktail at home we walked the single block to the restaurant.  We were saying to ourselves, "If theres a 10 minute wait we'll just go home and make another cocktail!".  The owner treated us like we were family and seated us by the front window.  Tried glasses of the Viognier and the Malbec - both were very yummy.  The Pomme Frites were to die for.  The Filet was delicious and rich and the Sea Bass special was melt in your mouth good.  Ended up paying $120 with tip for 4 glasses of wine, Hors 'd oevres, entrees and desert.    For the quality and comfort it was worth every penny.

...and there were kids in there.  Polite, well mannered kids.  We have one of those so that means we can drag her along.  Or not.  ;)

p.s.  The profiteroles were heavenly!
author: katie b.

description: An amazing dining experience! The owner was extremely kind and our waiter was a total character. The food was delicious- shared the Bass with Cauliflower and short ribs- the beef cheeks also melted in your mouth. We were celebrating 3 birthdays in our group and the owner made us feel very special. Will definitely be back!
author: Marika K.

description:
Well I have a new favorite restaurant. It's like my long lost French uncle moved into the neighborhood and turned his duplex into a restaurant. Notables are its delicious menu, attentive friendly service, and super clean, yet warm and comfy atmosphere. What more can you ask for?! Good for parties of 2 or maaayyyybe a few more. It's definitely cozy without being tiny. Get the risotto. 

PS. If you don't live around the corner like most of the clientele seemed to, street parking shouldn't be a problem, but if it is, go park under Lucky's just a block away.
author: Mandy Z.

description: Very good service and the food is wonderful.  We ordered the califlower soup and it was very creamy and had a great flavor.  We also ordered their beet salad: very good with the goat cheese and was very nicely presented.  I ordered the short ribs and my date ordered the steak.  The steak was definitely better and provided a better portion.  The short ribs were a little dry though I did not use their sauce because it was salty enough and I didn't want to make it any saltier.  The atmosphere had the laid back French restaurant vibe without out the extras.  The prices were of course spendy but not expensive like most French places.  All in all, a good place to dine in a casual environment.  Would go again.
author: Eating And Living Well U.

description:
Count me among the Yelpers who are really excited that Bistro Central Parc is open, and pleased with the results.  I apparently was lagging - I ate there the second night they were open (Wednesday).

The food and services were great - especially considering how little time the restaurant had been open.  The decor is pleasantly clean, and is open, bright and lively.  The food derives from classical French bistro food, updated for a cleaner and more modern presentation.  I'm around the corner, and consider them a near perfect local restaurant for a nice night out and interesting food that doesn't cross the line to fussy / overdone.

A particular standout was the scallop risotto with lobster broth.  The risotto was especially rich, scallops nicely browned outside and tender inside, and the lobster broth was succulent.  The presentation of the risotto (delived in a small spring pan form on the outside which was removed at the table) was both charming and functional.  We also had the frisee salad, duck confit over lentils and volcan de chocolate for dessert, all of which were very good.

As mentioned, it is a new restaurant.  Not sure what the schedule is, but they are working on the permitting and construction needed to add outdoor seating.   And in case you missed this, no one does outdoor dining as well as the French - I am confident that the outdoor area will be splendidly executed (an important criteria in my house).

Being local, I will gladly come back, and can only look forward to this new addition to the hood.
author: Stefan A.

description: We come here on the weekends. Very good food and relatively quiet place. Great to have weekend brunch and breakfast. Good coffee too.
author: SD Girl C.

description:
Knowing how busy popular restaurants are, we ate here on a Wednesday and got there right after the 5PM opening.  We were the first customers there and had a nice window seat.  Luckily, we got this table as it appears that most of the tables seem jammed together. We also found parking nearby, but pity those that come later as parking is really difficult around here.

They immediately brought us some french rolls that were made by Bakers of Paris.  We started off with a Frisee salad, consisting of greens, chunks of bacon, and topped with a poached egg ($11.50) and a bowl of split pea soup ($7.50).  Both were tasty, though a little on the pricey side.

Our main course consisted of  lamb shank with seasoned vegetables ($19.50) and the fish of the day ($19.00) which consisted of risotto wrapped with a thin layer of calamari.  Both dishes were accompanied by some tasty sauce.  The calamari dish was a little disappointing as there was mostly risotto.  At first glance, the dish reminded me of 3 hard boiled eggs and to call it a fish of the day is misleading.

Our wine consisted of an Argentine cabernet @$9/glass.  It was good wine.  For desert, we had an elegant volcan chocolate cake ($7.50) and a glass of tawny port ($7).  Both were very good. 

Service was excellent, though they were a little scimpy with the rolls and the calamari was not quite what I expected.  This is a nice place, but a little expensive for what you get.
author: Robert J.

description: I loved the food but the whole ambience is something that will draw me back again and again. We came on Sunday and were immediately seated. A few more tables were available. Our waiter had such a great energy and gave perfect recommendations for everyone in the group. My girlfriend had a stewed rabbit and I had mushroom risotto. We also had baked bree with crostini and escargo. Everything was delicious.
author: Mark L.

description: My husband and just  I went for our anniversary dinner. We wanted to stay close to home and our son. We were not disappointed! I would go back even if I had to drive across town.  Service and food were excellent. Can't wait to go back.
author: Hilary M.

description:
Had dinner here the other night and was beyond impressed. The french onion soup was fantastic, the salmon special was possibly one of the most delicious meals I've ever had, and the risotto with scallops was as good as the reviews say.

It's a bit pricey, but it's a great place for a date night and I honestly can't think of another restaurant in the city that serves such high quality food where you can walk in at 7:00 pm and get a table in a few minutes, no problem. The service is outstanding and the food was incredible; we will absolutely be back.
author: Brian D.

description:
I can't say enough nice things about this place and I have absolutely no criticisms.  I just discovered this little gem, and its down the street from my house so I'll be back often! 

 The truth is, the entire staff are so accommodating and down to earth that I decided I loved this place before I even got my meal.  But, they set the right expectation, because everything was fantastic from the french onion soup, to the beef bourguignon, to the tarte tatin.  They have excellent wine pairing and the waiters make the best suggestions. They menu is very french and so are the staff

The best part was that it was a refreshing change from the snobby food culture in SF.  Too many restaurants try so hard to be something that they're not, act elite to their customers, and therefore create an uninviting environment.  At the same time, lots of crappy restaurants exploit their customers because they are in SF and charge way to much for really bad food.  This place could charge so much more than they do, but they keep it real.  It's a quant little bistro with a cute ambiance, friendly people, and amazing food at great prices.  What more could you ask for?

Our neighborhood needs more restaurants like this!
author: Doxie M.

description:
Good times.  I considered giving them 5 stars, and if when I go back, it's just as good, they may get the upgrade.  Full disclosure - I live spitting distance from this place, so I may be biased.

Food:

We started with the escargot and the mussels.  Both very good, the escargot were tender from not being overcooked, and were garlicky to be sure, but in a balanced way, not overpowering.  Dunk that cute little warm french bread roll into that butter, mmmm...  The mussels were also solid.  The broth had a nice herbs and wine - maybe tarragon? - more good dunking.  Not a lot to the escargot, but the mussels were a decent portion.

My wife had the filet with green peppercorn sauce, and the bite I got was spot-on.  Boulliabaise was delish, and just the right amount.  Our friend got salmon, which looked good, but salmon never really excites me.  She seemed happy.

Dessert was the molten chocolate something.  Good-good.

Service:  Pretty good.  Took them a little while to take our orders (drinks, then food), but not egregiously so.  The chef is very present in the dining room, visiting all the dozen or so tables a couple times during the meal.  If you have a personal space issue, beware, he's a toucher.  Everyone has a french accent, which, if you find that sort of thing charming, can be quite charming.

Room:  The ambiance is nice, almost sleek, but somehow still neighborhoody.  It got a bit noisy inside.

Menu:  All your bistro favorites.  We're planning to go back for steack frites, soupe l'oignon, canard, etc...

Enjoy!
author: Matt G.

description:
I'm not one to give praise when undeserved and in the case of Bistro Central Parc, I'll stick by my guns. 

As I've never had lunch or dinner here I won't make the assumption that it's bad. And I can say with no reservation, that their French toast and eggs Benedict is just wonderful. But since breakfast has been the only meal I have had there, I have to point out at least two major flaws in their kitchen that almost every San Francisco resident will share as a restaurant, no-no. 

Their coffee is as watered down and disgusting as the crap I had in a Jiffy Lube waiting room. 

Not only is their coffee like Folgers instant, strained through at least three layers of paper towels, but they don't have cream or half and half. What is that about? A French restaurant without cream? A travesty. I have to mention as well, that my girlfriend ordered a soy latte and that was just as bad if not worse. One comes to expect that coffee can be pretty bad, especially at places like the airport or a casino lounge, but at a restaurant that claims to be French in style must have good espresso. Right? Nope. 

The soy latte consisted of likely, more of the same freeze-dried coffee but finer ground to work in an espresso press. Horribly watered down and on top of that, you are given a pitcher of steamed soy milk to fill at your own leisure. I'd like it in the cup, as a complete drink, please. Thank you. I have to add that after asking about the latte and whether or not they used espresso for the drink the waitress responded with a yes they did but she could top it off with some coffee. 

Please, if you must, get a coffee from any number of the wonderful coffee establishments around the area (Cafe Abir is my favorite) and forgo the abomination that is the coffee they serve at Bistro Central Parc. 

Go for food not the swill.
author: Seth F.

description:
This should be a 4 1/2 star review, though I'm loathe to bring down their rating -- the one (small) issue I had was with the appetizers not living up to the mains; I'm used to it being the reverse!

In terms of what I'd recommend -- the magret de canard and the hanger steak were top of the line, at competitive prices.  Think: rich, imaginative sauces; sumptuous, juicy cuts; and slow cooking.  I like that in addition to being perfectly scrumptious, the food is beautifully and elegantly presented.  The wine list is good and decently priced, and corkage is only $15 if you'd like to bring your own.  

It's also adorable that the wait staff is made up of Stanford philosophy grad students; you get brains and good taste, all in one. (You can even play that awkward "guess which class of mine you took/TA'd game..." ;)

This place gets my definite stamp of approval.
author: Melody D.

description: The heirloom tomato salad was excellent.  The other two dishes (cassoulet; tart tartine for dessert) were good but didn't stand out in any way.  The atmosphere seemed oddly casual and the service a bit too laidback given the prices of the food.    Might go back to try the brunch sometime.
author: Anita F.

description:
Really great neighborhood place with a high end feeling. The dishes are standard, rich French inspired meals and the pork dish with caramelized apples was a stand out. Modestly priced, well curated wine list. Def. a staple if you live in the area. 

Also, nice to hang out at the bar, have a cheese tart and soak in SF's Francophone culture. 

OH! Good desserts too! Crappy parking!
author: Brandi S.

description: We had some great appetizers, the mussels (no cream), and the ossobuco which was awesome. Also pleasant service. Great wine list!
author: Katarine Q.

description:
The food? Excellent. The ambiance? Very nice! The prices? Not bad. The service? LOUSY. Unless you are an American eating in a French Bistro in France. 

Our first mistake was to choose this place to celebrate a special occassion. Don't do it. And, apparently, making a reservation means nothing because we had to wait for over 30 minutes (outside in the cold) past our reservation time. Sure it was a Saturday night. but really? And when prompted for some kind of explanation, I felt a lot of French hot air being blown up my $!@&* with no apologies or even an offer of a glass of wine or something. Really?

40 minutes later and the dinner seems to progress nicely, even though we did have to remind our waiter about the wine order he took from us 15 minutes prior. This is a small place, mind you. The bar is 5 steps away.

We are talking and celebrating, and as the dinner comes to a close and as we are enjoying our desserts, the waiter swoops in with the check. "Uh, excuse me, may I please have a double espresso?"  I ask. It was feeling like an imposition. But wait.

He comes back with the corrected check, (why not just comp the espresso if it's that big a deal - it's not like the place isn't making money hand-over-fist.) Anyway, and yes, I know this was wrong, but I asked if he could split the bill for us. His answer? "You should have told me that before." Was he right? Yes. And he should have kept his mouth shut and, with a smile, go split the check. We're talking a $40 tip here!

So I say, "Really?"

For an introductory experience to a new place, I won't ever go back. Too bad.
author: Cristopher B.

description: My favorite restaurant in the entire city. The French Onion Soup is the best I've ever had. The dishes, be it a duck or a chicken or the filet mignon, are fantastic. Their wines choices are nice and varied, and reasonably priced. Their desserts are great too. This is the place you bring your significant other for a nice night out.
author: Howie N.

description: Yum yum yum. This spot is my new NOPA favorite. So intimate yet open. It is such an adorable French bistro. We first ordered the galette de pomme de terre (warm brie on a potato pancake on top of mizuna salad). OMG do die for. If they made a larger size this could have been my entree. The brie is perfectly cooked and not rubbery like some places. Our entrees were the lamb sirloin special and the NY steak and frites. Both were so amazing. My fiancees lamb was the winner. It melted like butter in your mouth and the glaze underneath was divine. My fries were delish when dipped in the peppercorn sauce my steak was drizzled in. We were beyond full so I can't comment on their desserts. Overall a big hit in our house and will be a place to take out of town guests.
author: Bri R.

description:
OH. GOD. YES. 

Any review that starts with one sentence made into three, written in all caps, with two out of three words being "God" and "Yes" means this restaurant HAS to be OHGOD good. 

I came here with 8 friends for an intimate birthday dinner.  The server and the owner (husband and wife) are French, and not "nose up in the air" French but "welcome you into my home for sumptuous meal" French.  The wine list is well-chosen.  The service was splendid and relaxed.  AND EVERY SINGLE DISH WE TRIED WAS OFF THE FREAKING HOOK FANTASTIC.  

Wow.  Some serious winners:

Endive salad.  How I love thee.  Strawberry vinaigrette with tarragon and shallots?  Yesplease.  Seriously pungent bleu cheese?  Yesplease. Perfectly tender endive?  Yesplease, squared.  This is a dish that was so beautifully presented that when they brought it out for a friend, two more of us ordered it on the spot.

Duck breast.  Fuck yes.  Tender duck boob served with brandy-soaked cherries, a please-pour-me-a-bath-of-this cherry sauce, beautifully layered with spinach, shallots, and fingerlings.  The cherry sauce covered the plate and had beautiful designs drawn through it with a cream sauce.  The whole plate looked like birthday.  

Lamb shank.  Fuck yes.  Let's just say this:  I requested a straw to suck the marrow out.  It's my birthday.  Thoreau, be proud.  

Creme brulee.  Um, they're French.  They nailed it.  Nuff said. 


Some friends wanted to leave a little early, and the owner pulled them aside and told them that they were about to sing happy birthday.  Made me want to invite them over to my house for dinner.

Oh, and what's bestest?  Local, organic food, and all entrees priced below $20.  BEAT THAT!

One of my new favorite restaurants, period.
author: Lopa V.

description:
Service here is warm, friendly and impeccable.  The staff really works together and treats you like family.  Though the restaurant was full on a Friday night in full swing, it wasnt too loud perhaps because the customers were of more mature age...no twittering twats on the mobiles.

We ordered the mussels which were cooked perfectly in a creamy sauce which was nice for dipping with their home made mini loaf bread.  I had the almond trout filet which was lighter in sauce served with green beans and potatoes.   Each savory bite simply melted in my mouth.  I had a bite of the hangar steak and the meat was very tasty and fries were crispy and delish!

Skipped desert.  This place is worth walking in the storm to have dinner.
author: May M.

description:
Excellent choice for early Friday night neighborhood walk-in dinner. 

We sat at the bar and shared:

Lyonnaise salad - great dressing, perfectly poached egg, could have used a few more lardons. interesting that it had whole tarragon leaves - nice diversion from the norm. 

Mushroom and goat cheese tart - very nice, lots of mushrooms and not overcooked, still firm. good balance of chevre and caramelised mushrooms. pastry flaky, crisp but maybe just SLIGHTLY overwhelming on the butter. i mean, you shouldn't feel sick after you eat something so tasty.

Mussels - excellent, both the mussels and the broth

French fries - pretty good. could have been slightly hotter, crisper and saltier. 

Bottle of French Pinot, only one on the wine list. well priced, more than palatable.

The service was pretty nice and we weren't rushed, even though we sat for a couple of hours and well after we finished dinner. The restaurant was full but not too noisy and not over-crowded. 

Perfect neighborhood bistro. Can't wait to go back.
author: Sarah D.

description:
Service was slow, but man, the food was Amazing.
Desert was the best part.
author: Zee B.

description:
I'd have to say the place was kinda cute if you're into noise, crowds, ... maybe if the day I went was not a busy day but maybe theyre always busy

my food.. well was expecting a steak au poivre bcos it said steak with peppercorns ...meat was tough, sauce too light... pomme frites with no mayonnaise!! what?! lol 
I forgot the name of the dish an acquaintance was having, filet mignon w/fois gras, with truffle sauce and crispy onions.... it was delicious! 

our meal took awhile, maybe bcos they had a hard time w/ our request for a white wine...what? white wine w/red meat? lol what a faux pas!
author: Just Us ..

description: My go to french place in SF.  The owner & servers are very friendly and hospitable.  The food is very good.  The prices are reasonable.  I've tried a number of items on the menu and have never been disappointed.  I've taken a many friends here and they have all enjoyed.  One came back to town and requested to go back, and he lives in Montreal so he gets to eat French food all the time.  They now have a heated out door area.  The inside can be a bit loud, the outdoor area not as much
author: David F.

description: We had an incredible birthday dinner here last night. Great and personal service, with food as fresh and tasty as it gets! The quality for the price point, really can't be beat. We had the beef checks and the filet minion for entrees, french onion soup, risotto and the brie on potato pancake for appetizers. All were outstanding although the french onion soup was a standout for me. Light on salt and the right amount of cheese, you could actually taste the sweetness of the onions. To top it off, we had the apple tartin and a dark chocolate cake for dessert. Rich and delicious! Overall, a fantastic dining experience. Thank you to "Yelpers" for helping me find this great place!
author: Karen J.

description: No wait on a sat during peak brunch time was nice. We were seated right away, that was the last we heard from our server.  I had to get up and ask for my check while our server rolled silverware.  The food; was excellent.
author: Shane K.

description:
We live nearby and BF took me for Valentine's day Eve.  We were greeted at the door by Jack/Jacques, the owner and seated immediately.   Our table was close to our neighbors (similar to RNM) and the room had a lot of hard surfaces that made it echo-y, so it is pretty loud and bustling sounding - slightly more trendy than romantic.
 From the moment I saw the menu, I wanted the bouillabaisse.  BF ordered the Fillet mignon.   For apps, we shared the leek & potato soup and the frisee with bacon.   All were absolutely yum!  

Service was great- attentive but not hovering, all delivered with a smile!  Our water glasses were full and dishes removed promptly but not before you finished the very last bite.  

For dessert, we had the sorbet trio (they made it themselves!) and the molten chocolate volcano cake. 

I can't wait to try brunch here- I hope they have a nicoise salad . 

Price-wise, it was a little much to be a place to go on a Wed. when we just want to grab something - it is in the category of NOPA or RNM, when you want to go someplace nice, though I'd be willing to pop back for mussels and a glass of wine on a lazy night.

As we left, Jacques thanked us warmly and invited us back, and I liked that :-)
author: Maria C.

description: Moules et Frites; Sancerre Rouge; Tart Tatin. Fantastic food, friendly staff and terrific neighborhood ambiance. As good or better than anything in Paris
author: John D.

description: This place is very impressive and I feel so lucky to have just moved a few doors down. I have been for dinner and brunch. Everything is delicious and the staff is friendly and very accommodating.  The prices are very reasonable for this type of fare. The mussels in curry sauce are amazing. It's pretty popular for a neighborhood joint and I am praying it's popularity doesn't expand too far out. This place is fantastic. I am bringing all visitors to my hood or the city to Bistro Central Parc.
author: m t.

description:
YUM! I was in SF to visit a friend and she knows that I'm all about trying out new restaurants. She told me she found this place that has amazing French food and it doesn't cost you an arm and a leg. So we ventured over to Bistro Central Parc on a Friday night. The place was crowded, but we luckily had reservations. The host really nice and even let my friend park in their driveway since she had circled around for more than half an hour looking for parking.

Since we had a party of 6 we were able to order a lot of the dishes. I highly recommend the following:
1. french onion soup - my friend wished the french onion soup she had in Paris was this good
2. salmon tartare - not only does this look amazing, it has great flavor and texture
3. mussels (moules marinieres) - I loved the simple white wine sauce
4. Beef bourguignon - perfectly cooked and very tender
5. Lamb shank - I usually don't like lamb because it can taste too game-y, but this lamb was delish!

Not only was the food good, but the service was excellent. They were extremely attentive and friendly. I would highly recommend this place to anyone! :)
author: Christina C.

description: Came here for dinner on a weekday with a friend. It was perfect! I loved everything about it. The service was outstanding and the food just... Amazing. The French onion soup was the perfect flavors with exactly the right amount if cheese, bread, and onion without being too rich. My friend loved her mussels. I had risotto that normally comes with mushrooms, but I wanted to branch out as I always want mushrooms, and the waiter offered to make it with scallops. His idea, not mine, I promise! And the scallops were perfectly cooked, and probably the best scallops I've ever had.  The baguette was great, too! I wish I had enough room for dessert. This place exemplifies why French food is so good. It's simple and done very well. It was also super cute on the inside and outside, and I can't wait to come back! Just one suggestion-- make a reservation, as it is very popular and for good reason.
author: Dana B.

description: Steak frite was good for brunch, meat was tender, fries were crispy! My gf took the lamb and it was quite good as well, a little bit greasy though! Service was a little bit slow.
author: Gregoire V.

description: Everything is excellent here.  The appetizer, we had duex fois gras - hot and cold - the hot one is seared to PERFECTION!  excellent selection of entrees and service is 5 stars too - given they are so busy!
author: Kathy C.

description: We really can't get enough of this place... We eat here at least once per month. Everything is always delish, especially the specials, and the wine selection is very curated and yummy. The service is great and the ambiance is lively and fun. Really love it!
author: Nicole P.

description:
Great service. Great gourmet food at a reasonable price for what you're getting. I tried the mussels in curry sauce, escargot, endive salad and chocolate lava cake. Everything was delish. They gave us lots of extra bread to soak up the sauce the mussels were in. Actually the bread was a little tough...but I'll let that slide. :) I liked the interior of the place as well.
They even let us park in their driveway since we couldn't find parking!
author: Carmita T.

description:
General critique: portion sizes were small which is OK by me.  I don't like huge portions given I'm a small eater.  Price is reasonable give the portion size.  I like the neighborhood feel.  Staff was friendly.  Food was average.  

Fresh warm rolls: Good start

Mixed field greens: There were way too many chopped onions and I had to pick them out.  I was expecting a light vinegarette but it was pretty much dressed with olive oil, salt and too much onion.  I wouldn't order this again

Escargot: Very tender but underseasoned

Risotto of the day (risotto with ratatouille topped with handful of the same field greens from the mixed green salad): Risotto was a tad on the too al dente side and seemed just a tad undercooked.  Flavor was decent.

Flank steak with roquerfort sauce: hubby liked it

Profiterole: Good, what you would expect of a profiterole
author: Irene C.

description:
Reasonable prices, nice ambience, very good service, some good dishes--and at least one exquisite one. 

The escargots were fine. The butternut squash soup was pleasant, but lacked depth; perhaps squash is out of season now. Someone had the risotto topped with scallops, which seemed pleasant enough when I tried it, but not terribly exciting. Perhaps, though, the risotto simply paled in comparison to my dish, the skate with capers, which was first-rate.

If you have a chance, you must go to Bistro Central Parc to try the skate with capers (a special that I had on a Sunday). It is a lovely combination of flavors and textures. Two skate filets drape a small mound of cooked cauliflower and asparagus. The slightly creamy sauce complements the sharp capers and is balanced nicely by the neutral cauliflower. Against these flavors, the astringent asparagus shows nicely. I also enjoyed the combination of textures: smooth, soft, slightly chewy fish, distinct cauliflower flowerets falling apart in the mouth, al dente asparagus. Perfect. 

For dessert, the waiter, who had recommended the skate, also recommended a strawberry mousse. Give it a few minutes to warm up from frozen to chilled, and you'll have a nice combination of pastry, a fruity mousse, and a thin layer of jam (not too sweet), topped with mint and a slice of fresh strawberry. Well done. 

I look forward to trying more dishes.
author: Nat C.

description: Hubby and I came here for date night last week and loved this neighborhood gem.  We shared the pate appetizer and had the scallop risotto and filet mignon rossini for entrees.  The entrees were surprising really good.  We finish dinner with their chocolate cake.  Dinner with 3 glasses of wine was just around $100.  Loved it so much that I made reservations for dinner here this week with two friends.
author: Mac S.

description:
This place is such a gem. The few places that tried in this location in the past few years didn't make it-but I REALLY hope Bistro Central Parc sticks around. 

Went for New Years dinner (oops this review is only 4 months late) with fiance and another couple. At the very beginning, there was a weird thing where they thought we had made a resi for 2, but I definitely had called and confirmed 4 people. Either way, they fixed it and we were seated right away. 

At this point, cant detail every thing we ate, but holy crap was it out of this world. We all had scallops apps, and different meat dishes-venison, steak with foie gras etc--everything was unbelievable. 

Service was great, friendly without being overbearing; wine was delish and fairly priced. 

I haven't gone for brunch / less formal occasions, but I know people that have and they raved :)
author: Afton T.

description:
We had 2 date nights this week and let me tell you, this was by far the better of the two!!! My building manager of all people recommend this spot as this photographed it. Anyway after himing and ha-ing we went and am I glad we did. 

Decor is lovely and you can tell it is new construction by the crisp lines. Not a packed resto which is always nice. Came in and a table lickity split at 8:30. 

I had a Kir and my gentleman caller has a Cote du Rhone. We started w/ a potato, monk fish delicious hot terrine if you will. And I know terrine is not the best way to describe, yet it has a pesto/ oil on top!! So good!!! I had the beef bourginion and the gentleman had the rack of lamb. 

I am not a lamb fan, yet it was amazing!!!! And the bouef was fabu as well. I mean the fat was creamy for god sakes, does not get much better than that!!! 

This is my new french place and for sure not as formal as Chapeau!
author: Nicole F.

description:
We are so lucky to have this place right down the block from us! It's slightly off the beaten path from Divisadero but a romantic neighborhood bistro. All the staff we met is actually French... bonus. 

Ambience is casual, clean and classy. The French Onion soup is plentiful and delicious. The lamb shank was huge and juicy... fell off the bone. Sometimes, the vegetarian option is kinda sad. But in this case, they had a delicious and flavorful risotto that I think meat eaters can enjoy too. 

We had a perfect, light bottle of their Pinot Grigio to compliment our meal. I believe it's very affordable for what you get. We spent about $40 per person, all in, with appetizers, entrees and wine.
author: Cameo E.

description: Quite possibly one of the best French bistros in the city. I could rave about the food but the other 350+ reviews probably cover it pretty well. The owner coming over and genuinely asking about the meal was a nice touch. Our waiter shook our hands good bye. These people know how to run a business and treat their customers. Definitely coming back. Quick note about parking: it's difficult to say the least.
author: N S.

description: J'adore!! Nicolas Jardin is truly an artiste and he makes delicious french food that looks and taste amazing I will totally go there again and again because you get high quality food & service for all around hundred bucks for tow people.
author: Mattin N.

description: The greeting and wait staff was warm and friendly.  The food was very good.  What put me off was the layout.  We had a table for two and a few inches away from another table for two that was against the wall.  The waiter couldn't fit between tables so he awkwardly took their order and served their food over their shoulder.  The big problem was that we were also next to the bar.  The people sitting at the bar were fine. The People who would come over and stand there talking, etc. with the backs of their coats hitting our plates of food was just outrageous.  One of these times the owner saw this and moved the man out of the way back to the front of the restaurant.  This has been a theme lately where people's backsides have been on top of my meal.  I think this soured my over all experience.
author: Margot M.

description:
Great vibe. not to packed as we were there later in the evening 8:30ish. We started w/ a potato, monk fish delicious hot terrine. For the main I had Cote du Rhone which by itself was very nice but paired with the rack of lamb. Just wanna say " Holy SHIT!" prepare yourself for your socks to be knocked off! My gf had the beef bourginion, I would not pass up on ordering this one either. 

Now in comparison to Chapeau! out on celment....Bistro not as packed,  Chapeau! still very good and a bit elitest. I will choose Bistro anyday of the week.
author: Chuck G.

description:
We ate alot.

Steak tartare - pass, too vinegary says Brett
Salmon trio - pass, missing freshness/ too many salty/smokey elements
Pommes frites - not my favorite, reminds me of BK fries, I like McD fries
French onion soup - too brothy but good
Egg plant lasagna - DELICIOUS!!!!  i thought it might be a lasagna made with eggplant instead of noodles but its a lasagna with eggplant in it.  
Scallop with risotto - DELICIOUS!!!  risotto tastes like the sea and the scallops were delicious.  I don't like scallops but these scallops were special.

Great service and price.  Very welcoming French restaurant.
author: Wakako U.

description:
This is a new restaurant in my neighborhood that I walk past by frequently while walking my puppy.  

The chef is always smiling and talking to the customers so I thought I stop by today for brunch (not knowing that they serve brunch).  Brunch is served between 9 AM and 3 PM and then dinner starts at 5 PM.

The place is very cute and quaint.  This French lady works there and she is incredibly cute and friendly.  The ambiance is light and chill.  I would sit there and read a book while having a nice breakfast/brunch.   However, I must point out that the tables are a little small, I couldn't even fit everything on there and I only ordered three dishes to share with my sister.

My sister and I tried a couple of the dishes:

Mussels - The wine parsley sauce was perfect!  It did not overpower the freshness of the seafood and yummy with the bread.
Eggs Benedict - The muffin was different than other places I have tried.  It was toasted but with a hint of salt which added a lot to the somewhat more bland hollandaise sauce.
Half Portion French Toast - Soggy so not really preferred.  
Coffee - bland tasting
Fresh squeezed OJ - really good!  fresh squeezed.

I would come back and try dinner because I believe in giving it another try.  Plus, you won't know until you've tried almost everything!  But for now, I give it two stars because it's average but has not wow'd me yet.
author: Carmen C.

description:
What a charming little bistro. 
Never knew about it and so happy to have found it. 
The three of us ordered different dishes and found them all to be very good. 
Rack of lamb done perfectly, risotto had loads on mushrooms on top,
Frisee salad had very  soft poached egg (many places overpoached their eggs).
Escargot is only okay. Very small snails,  sauce not garlicky enough. 
chocolate lava cake was sooooo good, 
Everyone in the place seem to be enjoying their food.  Noise level was low so you did not have to shout to be heard across the table.  They did not cram you against each other, which is one of the things i hate about so many places nowadays. 
Really , I do not want to share my table or my conversation. 
I would definitely come back to this place . Too bad about foie gras.   Sigh.
author: Annie D.

description: This place is around the corner from my house and the owner is delightful.  The food is true French cuisine with a fine wine list.  The atmosphere is easy and elegant.
author: Kyra M.

description: My boyfriend (now FIANCE!) and I came for dinner back in August for my birthday while traveling.  Service was amazing, food was superb AND the owner came out and chatted with us and I was given a Birthday gift from the restaurant. Do yourself a favor while in San Francisco and eat at this delicious restaurant!
author: Trina P.

description:
This place is realllly good! high-end french bistro comfort food that was reasonably priced. Came with a group of five and we had a rather gluttonous evening trying the steak tartare, escargot, mussels, steak w/peppercorn reduction, seafood risotto, rack of lamb, and an array of desserts. All were delicious. One thing everyone remarked on (don't laugh), was the butter. The butter on the table was amazing. We were asking for extra bread as much for the accompanying butter as the bread itself, which was also good.

The only real thing I could ding, was that one of our party asked for their filet medium-well, and it looked medium rare, but he loved it anyway. 

The place is pretty small, maybe a dozen tables in what was probably an old corner store, once upon a time. 

Definitely going back.
author: pedro w.

description: Yes, it's French. Yes, it's good, but limited wine selection and the wait staff isn't always the most amicable. A great restaurant is more than just about the food on the plate.
author: Adolfo M.

description: My first time to the restaurant and I was more than pleasantly surprised. The food was fantastic, the staff friendly and accommodating. The new owner recommended a delicious bottle of red wine to compliment the meal AND the price was reasonable. Bistro Central Parc is my new favorite SF restaurant.
author: Cindy B.

description:
I guess I dissent from the incredibly high evaluations of the bistro.  It's OK.  It's a nice neighborhood place.  It's new and a nice venue.  But the food and service are only OK.  

To begin with the service, I dined Sunday evening and was alone in the place for some considerable time.  Despite this the server was reticent, distant, detached in that strange gallic way. 

The food was nice but bland.  For example lentil soup, a special of the evening, was thick, tasted of lentils, but could have used seasoning.  A place really should be assertive in that regard if salt and pepper are not on the table.  

I had been concerned that goat cheese would overwhelm the mushrooms on a  mushroom and goat tart.  Not so.  I could barely taste the cheese for the mushrooms and the pastry was not so flakey or abundant as I would have desired.  

All of the components of a bouillabaisse were nice enough yet the dish was a bit boring,  It needed some zest, some assertiveness, some interest, some spicing.  

While to me the food seemed flat others may find the obviously good ingredients in each dish more to their liking.
author: David D.

description:
For her birthday, my wife requested a dinner with a few friends at a restaurant no one had been to previously.

Enter Bistro Central Parc... I stumbled across BCP, here on Yelp. What a fantastic find! From start to finish, Jacques and crew were on their A-game. I was impressed (and I don't use that word lightly).

Setting up the reservation via email was super easy. Day of, half of us got there a bit early -- parking was easier than expected/we got lucky ;)

Instead of making us stand around, we were offered our table, even though the rest of our party had yet to arrive. A bottle of wine and an order of the mussels and frites later, the other half of our party trickled in right on time.

Our waiter never missed a beat: as people arrived, wine glasses hit the table and were filled before coats had time to settle on chairbacks.

Food-wize: you can't miss. EVERYTHING we ordered was delicious; rich but not heavy; French but not pretentious :) Mussels/Frites, the New York steak, the Tournedos, the Rack of Lamb... and the desserts. YUM :)

They even gave my wife a BCP coffee mug for her birthday :)

I cannot recommend BCP enough. The staff are thoughtful and efficient. They're pros. The food is fantastic.
author: ryan m.

description:
This was my first time to the Bistro Central Parc.  After reading such glowing reviews I assumed it was going to blow me away.  I was pretty disappointed.

For appetizers, we ordered the escargot and the New Zealand Pinot Noir to go with Dinner.  The escargot was very good.

Next came the Entrees: I ordered the Filet medium rare and it was barely cooked.  It was purple in the middle so I had to send it back.  When it finally came back, it was good but not great.  My companion ordered the risotto which he said was good.  Overall, good but definitely not great. 

Maybe this place needs some time to settle in.  The service at the bar was kinda slow and it was difficult to get anyone's attention.  

For the prices, this place is definitely not worth it.
author: Rachael K.

description: A very nice feeling tasty French Resturant in an easy going vibe. We had a great time trying all kind of food that offers, especially French Onion Soup & Mussel on White Cream Wine, Awesome!!
author: Nop P.

description:
Made reservations for a Valentine's dinner at 9pm on a Sunday evening. Maybe it was the high expectations or the busy night, but BCP just didn't impress me. In fact, we were both pretty disappointed by the end of dinner. It made me quite sad really...

We started with the beef tartare, which was good. Actually it was probably the best thing we had all night. The flavors were good, but with beef tartare, I like to taste more beef as opposed to feeling like it was just covered with seasoning.

We then shared the scallop risotto with lobster sauce and the duck confit. Both lacked a bit of flavor - maybe something that could have been fixed with more sauce? The scallops were hit or miss - some were too salthy. The risotto was hard and definitely undercooked. The duck meat was tender and fell right off the bone, but was definitely lacking flavor.

At the end of dinner, we decided against ordering any dessert. Didn't want to risk making the experience any worse. 

Too bad I waited all day for this meal, seeing the amazing reviews. Definitely think there are much better options in the city for people to try.
author: Angela S.

description: Bistro Central Parc was a great spot!  We headed over there with my mom and a friend from Ireland and it pleased us all.  We tried steak frites, the special heirloom tomato salad with goat cheese and a couple other specials.  Everything was cooked perfectly and absolutely delicious.  Can't wait to return!
author: Stacy B.

description: 4.5 stars.  Great service and awesome food.  My first taste of French cuisine.  Wait help explained the menu and made perfect recommendations.  This was my best meal on this trip to SF.  Recommend you make reservations.  Very close to Univ SF.  A little noisy though, especially when the accordian comes out.
author: Derek C.

description: Four of us had dinner here last night and everything was absolutely fantastic.  The ambience intimate and vibrant and fun.  The food was totally delicious.   This is an unpretentious, moderately priced, wonderful neighborhood spot that I will come back to again and again.  Great job BCP!
author: Matt S.

description: This is my first recommendation for anyone looking for a nice/romantic/good value dinner in the city.  I love the ambiance, the owners, the wine selection, the risotto and all the food I've tried there.  Delicious cozy french food for a good price.  Plus, it's on an adorable unassuming block and what every neighborhood bistro should strive to be like.
author: Madeline S.

description: Wonderful spot!  Friendly staff.  I had the eggs Benedict and it was one of the best. Super nice atmosphere in a quiet part if the city. Definitely a nice restaurant worth supporting. We live in the neighborhood and this is officially one of our normal spots now.
author: v n.

description:
Ate there on January 1st with my family. 

Terrific. Simply could not have been better. 

My new favorite restaurant in San Francisco.

Gracious hospitality, fantastic presentation, and the food was simply perfect.

I had the filet....so good.

Others had the Duck Confit, Hangar Steak, and a Veggie dish.

Two hours of Heaven. 

Desserts...oh my goodness. What a beautiful thing to eat. 

Owner treated us to a bottle of very good Champagne. 

Magical evening. 

We went back this morning for brunch.

Terrific again.

I simply am baffled by anyone who does not find this place to be terrific. 

Well done Bistro Central Park, well done. 

All of this and priced like a 3 star restaurant. 

Amazing.
author: bill r.

description: We love going to BCP.  I have found they have one of the better filet mignon's in the city.  Prices are very fair for what you get and the staff has always been friendly.  One time they lost our reservation and you could tell they were trying to figure out how something like that could ever happen.  They were able to squeeze us in and more than made up for it.  Stuff like that happens (understandable) but they way they reacted was impressive.
author: Kevin S.

description: Beautiful & tasty french place to go with a small group and share wine. Great customer service and flavourful.
author: Mario C.

description:
A gem in our new neighborhood!

In the mood for a special birthday dinner recently, my partner and I initially walked into Bistro Central Parc feeling disappointed that we couldn't get a reservation at the well-known french place in our new neighborhood, (Chapeau) so we had no expectations other than having at least a decent meal at a place in our new neighborhood....

I'm pleased to say that we were blown away!!  The look and ambiance was of a cozy and comfortable bistro, the service was attentive and friendly, the prices were very reasonable, and best of all, my dinner companion and I agreed that this was one of the best 5 meals we'd ever had together -- what a memorable meal it was!

We started off sharing the monk fish mashed potato terrine which was delicious and generous enough for two. Followed by the incredible Scallop risotto w/lobster sauce, and a lovely creme brule as a perfect way to end the meal.  Freakishly, there were 3 other birthdays being celebrated on this night, so we told our server that there was no need to make any fuss over a 4th celebration (mine) so instead of getting the dimmed-light-dessert-presentation, we were treated to a visit and some genuine neighborhood TLC from the owner, Jacques, who graciously presented me with a souvenir coffee mug from the restaurant!  

Jacques, who previously owned the Baker Street Bistro, spent a few minutes sharing his story of how he decided to open up his new restaurant on this once run-down corner, to provide this neighborhood with some good french/mediterranean food in a no-fuss bistro environment. Jacques has indeed succeeded -- Bistro Central Parc is a gem that we will be visiting often!
author: Rosann C.

description:
A french man told me this is perhaps the best French Bistro in San Francisco. But I think perhaps he was seduced by the huge portions.
Either that or I didn't order the right thing.

I hate myself for saying this, but please make the portions smaller! I order the beef tartar - A quarter pound raw hamburger showed up. I've never seen such huge portions in Paris. Steak frite - average steak, fantastic frite. Again huge portions. Bring your appetitie and chow down here! We all have that special friend who is very dear to us, but can eat you to the poor house - This is your opportunity to treat them without wondering whether you credit card can handle it.

The maître d'hôtel was so sweet he served us free samples of gorgeous wine. The restaurant was booked solid we had to sit at the counter. The good looking attentive staff definitely helps the dining experience.
author: Pandora B.

description: The most consistent restaurant in San Francisco.  We've been there 10 times and it is always great!  The regular mussels with a side of fries are the best I've ever had.  Sooooo Good!  and save room for dessert.
author: John D.

description: great food, very rich, and lower than expected corkage fee!
author: Jonathan J.

description:
What an addition to the neighborhood!

We went last night - opening night.  They DEFINITELY are working out the kinks, but for our patience we were rewarded with a wonderful meal and not very many drinks on our bill!  w00t!

Highlights:

Risotto w/scallops & lobster - this was amazing.  The risotto was cooked to perfection, the scallops not overdone (thank goodness).  Absolutely recommend.

Filet with Pepper Sauce - one of my favorite french dishes and they did an amazing job...wow.  I won't say it's the best I've had of this dish (that's kinda high praise and nowhere to go from there but down), but I can't remember ever having a better steak au poivre.

We were only so-so on the mussels - really, really creamy, kinda heavy for a french mussels dish.  The mussels were top quality so it was a little weird to not just leave em alone  more.

Jacques is a gracious host.  He makes you want to welcome him to the neighborhood and come back often.  Bon chance.
author: Chris A.

description:
Excellent French food in SF.  For Hors d'oeuvres, we had the brie on potato pancakes and escargot.  The brie was partially melted on the pancake and set over a bed of greens.  There was a light berry sauce (either cranberry or raspberry), that was just the perfect addition to the plate.  The escargot came on a nice little plate smothered in olive oil and garlic.  They say it was a parsley butter, but it almost had a taste similar to pesto, if you can imagine that.  It was actually a really great combination of flavors.  

For entrees, we got the scallops on risotto and lobster sauce and a veal scallopini special they were serving that day.  The scallops were grilled perfectly and had just the right amount of crisp on the surface.  The risotto and lobster sauce really gave the scallops a nice balance including some added texture with the scallops.  I was a little skeptical about the veal because the presentation was so-so, and I don't know why, but the veal scallopini I've often had at other places gets cooked too dry, but Bistro Central Parc got it just right.  What really made it nice was the tuna-caper sauce, which really made the veal and sliced potatoes taste amazing.  

For dessert, we got the lava chocolate cake, which was just perfect.  I highly recommend this as well.  It's topped with a scoop of vanilla ice cream and a thin crust of toffee.  When you cut into the cake, the inner chocolate perfectly runs out over the plate.  It wasn't too sweet, not too bitter, not too bland...just perfect.

Especially for the price, this MUST be one of the best French restaurants in the city (although I just moved here and haven't tried them all!).  The service is top notch too, so be sure to tip nicely.

Recommend bringing your own wine if you'd like.  I saw multiple patrons doing this, and I wish I would have done that. Also...cab or walk to the restaurant.  Parking is hard!!
author: Simon B.

description: I need to get here for brunch because their dinner was bomb, wild mushroom risotto and ratatouille were awesome and the prices were reasonable.
author: Robby W.

description: Yummy food, lovely ambiance and great service!!! We had a blast and left feeling full and satisfied.
author: Antonia T.

description:
Love it when new restaurants pop into the neighborhood...especially this one as it has great meaning.  For years, this corner building could not sustain any business that would open up because of the infamous "pink crack house" next door.  Crackheads would keep breaking into whatever business would open to support their drug habit.  Well a few years back the crack house burned down and the neighborhood was finally able to take this corner of the street back.  As such, Bistro Central Parc opened about more than a few weeks ago.  My friend and I live just a block away and we finally got a chance to try it last night!

First off, when you walk in, you get a warm greeting by people inside.  The handsome French gentleman that worked behind the counter/bar, which was later introduced to us as Julian, seated us immediately at two cozy seats at the counter and provided us with menus and a wine list.  Not shortly after, Jacques, whom I believe is the owner, also came by to meet and greet us. Both were so warm and welcoming and made us feel right at home.

The menu has a great variety of French dishes including duck confit, escargot as well as mussels.  Julian helped us pick out a couple glasses of wine, not sure why we didn't order a bottle since we knew we would get there.  Since French food is heavy, we decided to share an appetizer and main entree and also because we knew we could come back anytime.  We ordered the mussels and as suggested by Julian, the special filet of the night.  

The mussels were absolutely delicious!  The broth was buttery and light, well as light as butter can be.  The mussels were fresh and plump, not wimpy like at some restaurants. I couldn't stop dipping my bread into the broth and was tempted to pick up the bowl and drink it but of course refrained.

Then the filet came right at the perfect time.  WOW.  The dish was beautiful, a perfectly cooked fliet mignon topped with frois gras and two thinly roasted pieces of sweet potato.  Underneath was a delicious gratin and to bring the whole dish together was a perfectly reduced red wine sauce.  I can not emphasize how perfectly cooked the filet was, it melted in my mouth.  Talk about umami!

Then we moved on to dessert.  We both ordered a glass of dessert wine as suggested by Julian and then shared the Creme Caramel.  The wine was delicious and paired well with the Creme Caramel.  Jacques again came by to ask us how our meal was and then asked us if we lived close by, which we told him we did.  Two minutes later he reappeared with a bottle and refilled our dessert wine at no charge and told us he wanted to make sure that if he poured us more dessert wine we could make it home...haha...such a cute man!!

Bottom line, I can not say enough good things about this wonderful place that has been a part of saving our great neighborhood.  It was such a great experience that my friend and I have decided to make this our weekly girls dinner spot!  Thank you Jacques for making me a proud homeowner in the NOPA neighborhood!
author: Susan P.

description:
This is one of our favorite french bistros in the city.

We came here three months ago and i don't remember many specifics, but all the food we ordered was really good. 

My other half, who always orders lamb whenever he can at restaurants, ordered the lamb here medium-rare. He is somewhat of a lamb expert, having had it in so many places (his favorite is La Folie). The lamb here was good, but he thought they prepared it rare, not medium-rare. The server took it back, and then came back with the same plate and proceeded to tell us that this is actually what lamb medium-rare looks like. My other half thought this lamb was prepared more rare than all other places, but he didnt think it was worth the fight so that was that.

Also, the server's arm swung the wrong way at one point toward the end of the meal and broke my wine glass, spilling the little bit of wine left in the process (no clothes were marred). They gave us complimentary dessert to compensate.

In spite of all this, we would definitely come back here again. Which speaks for something, I guess. Something good.
author: j d.

description:
The food is good but not "my goodness! It's freaking amazing! ". I will not argue the quality of the food. It's the service that really amazes me because I cannot believe it can be this bad for a french restaurant. 

First, the server was super grumpy from the start. He had no smile and when we asked about the special. He went on for 5+ mins in mono tone. I got it, you probably have repeated it for million times but where is the professionalism? When I asked him if he has any recommendations, he gave me a stone face and simply said "I don't have any recommendations. If you see anything you like on the menu, then order it". Helpful and friendly! When the waiter came to replace our plates after we finished appetizer, he knocked down our bottle of wine. He apologized and promised to replace a new bottle. Never did. We had to ask them if they will do something about it 30 mins later, then the grumpy server came over and said they will not replace the bottle but will give you another free glass. Very complementary! Before we left the restaurant we saw at least two other waiters knocked down plates and broke glasses around our table. This is epic careless and rudeness rolled in one big souffle that didn't raise. Honestly, SF has gazillion great french restaurants. Central Bistro Parc is too proud for its own good :(
author: Ricki H.

description: I hesitate to write this as I'd like to keep the cag in the bag but what a gem!  I've lived in this neighborhood for many years now and seen this place over the past few.  Always meant to visit.  It finally got recommended to me so much by friends in the neighborhood that I finally pulled the trigger and am I glad I did!  Super down to earth staff and ownership.  The owner himself was walking around all night shaking peoples hands and just being a really welcoming nice guy...cheers to that!  Food was GREAT!  Price was right....wine paring/recommendation was spot on...wait staff was funny and attentive.  Great neighborhood spot...thanks Bistro!....I'll be back!
author: Gabriel F.

description:
great food, service and reasonably priced. 
but parking sucks.  take a cab there or be prepared to spend 15-20 minutes looking for a parking space.
author: Kitty L.

description:
Made Xmas Eve dinner reservations for 8 pm. When we got there at 7:50pm to check in, we were early but they showed that reservations were made for 8:15pm. Not sure why the change. My family and friends were in good holiday spirits so we weren't going to let this bother us. We were warmly greeted by Jacques, the owner, and asked to be patient as the restaurant was fill and bustling. At 8:25 pm, we were seated. A really nice gesture would have been to offer us some wine or sparkling water knowing we've been waiting for 35 minutes. 

When seated, the experience improved significantly. The waiter, Frankie, was energetic, fun, and French in his charm. The 5 of us ordered the following: 

Appetizers:
* Sweetbreads - my wife and daughter loved it. They were fresh, had great texture, and were married by a perfectly balanced redution sauce. 5 stars.
* Escargot - my friend loved it and sopped up the sauce with crusty bread. 5 stars.
* Mussels in white wine/shallot sauce - good sauce and generous amount of mussels. However, the individual mussels were very small and lacked good seafood flavor. Could benefit from finding another supplier. 3.5 stars due to great sauce.
* Mussels in white wine/curry sauce - same as above. The delicious sauce saved the dish. 4 stars. 

Main Courses:
* 3 Daily Specials: Tournedos Rossini (which is a beautiful filet mignon topped with foie gras and fried fingerling potatoes...this tower of flavor sitting on top of a potato pancake and surrounded by a peppery reduction). All 3 orders were ordered rare and they came out perfectly. This meal was divine and very rich/filling. $28 but worth it and would recommend it to carnivores. 5 stars.
* Duck Breast: Slices of medium rare duck breast on top of seasonal vegetables in an incredible reduction sauce. My wife loved this dish and from the morsel I had, I too loved it. 5 stars. 
* Pasta of the Day: Penne Carbonara for my daughter. Straight forward. She enjoyed it but this is definitely not their forte. 3.5 stars.
* 2008 French Meritage - $35 and delicious. Highly recommended with the meat dishes. Smooth and easy to drink. 

Service: 
* Jacques and His Wife: Warm, charming, and affectionate. Checked in on our table several times and made our 7 y/o daughter feel very included in such a grown up dining room. We were warmly embraced as we exited the restaurant. 5 stars.
* Frankie and Waitstaff: Warm, responsive, energetic, and genuine. They don't hover over you but check in every 10 minutes and get you whatever you need. 
* Ambience: small, intimate, high energy, and good vibe. Only concerns are how narrow the entrance is. As it was cold on Xmas Eve, many customers waited inside while their tables were being prepared. This caused congestion in the front and encroached on the guests sitting near the front. Also, the temperature in the restaurant was too warm...around 75 degrees. This was probably due to the thermostat turned too high, the large amount of customers, and the proximity of the open kitchen. 

Overall (even with the long wait and hot temperature): This place is a total winner and will become part of our short list of places to bring friends for an initmate, delicious, and authentic dining experience. This is comparable to Chapeau but more informal and higher energy.
author: H E.

description:
My favorite restaurant in town!!  The food is exquisite - always perfect!
A delightful selection of French dishes and the deserts that are close to heaven!
Service is great, love the French accents too!  Price is reasonable for such magnificent food.  
The bistro has a lovely European ambience - and it is so nice to see such a wonderful restaurant in a quaint residential neighborhood!  
Highly recommend!
author: Dee C.

description:
I went here for my birthday (not that that has any bearing on your reading of this review) and I must say it couldn't have been a better end to a good day.

I'll cut to the chase - the food was incredible. I had the frisse et lardons salad and my missus had the onion soup - both were superb. I think I'll choose the soup next time but the salad didn't let me down.

The main though was what topped the night off - filet topped with foie gras with a black truffle sauce - it could not have been better. Cooked perfectly.

As for the service - just right. True to its French routes, there was no rush whatsoever - read; for those that like to have their choices taken as soon as they sit, their entrees delivered as their starter is collected, then this is not the place for you. For all of you that enjoy an amazing meal in a great place, then this is indeed one you should check out.
author: Ben W.

description:
Came here for brunch w/ friend although as I was doing it wished that I came here for dinner. I'm a big bistro fan, although much prefer dinner menus. Having said that I think the food was quite tasty. 

The pommes frites (my yard stick for bistros) were light, not overly salted and very tasty. The omelet that accompanied it, however, was not the fluffy slice of heaven I was expecting. 

A solid offering to SF's bistro scene, but not a standout.
author: Pierre C.

description:
Let me start by saying how amazing this experience was in every way. Food- authentic and every dish thoughtfully executed and delicious. 
Jerome, the " right hand man" was hilarious and sweet. Our waiter ( didn't get his name) was knowledgable and friendly and didn't skimp on his pours either. Ask for suggestions, they welcome interactive dining. I love this place!!!
author: helen w.

description: A very wonderful place to bring a date or family! Brunch on the weekends is great and dinner throughout the week is fantastic too! The service is epic!! Looking forward to going back and trying more of the food.
author: Ethan S.

description:
I had an early dinner here last Thurs and I gave it 5 stars for great service, great price, great food, clean environment, and easy parking.  

The time I had dinner (6pm) probably contributed to the pleasant experience as I had no problems finding parking (not usual in this neighborhood), the staff readily available, and quick turnaround from the kitchen.

My wife and I had the pate appetizer, foie gras filet mignon,  risotto, and chocolate cate.  For the price, the food was outstanding and well proportioned.  I definitely liked their use of flavors and presentation.  Having dined at some nice restaurants around the city that were much more expensive, this was a great surprise that you can get great food at a decent price.

Thanks for the great experience Bistro and you'll see me back here again.
author: klb l.

description:
If I could give this place 6 Stars I would.  Haven't had such a wonderful dining experience in a long time.  Went for the Foie Gras and was not disappointed.  The trio appetizer - spectacular.  The portions are very generous.  The seared version with cherries - totally to die for.  Three of us got their special filet topped with foie gras.  What an awesome dish.  Again the duck organ was big enough to cover the entire steak.  The filet was so tender, it melted in my mouth.  They do not have a kids menu, but they were nice enough to bring "chicken and fries".  The chicken was a half of a cornish game hen.  It was plenty to eat for my 5 year old and a perfect option.  For dessert we had the creme brulee and and chocolate "volcano".  Both disappeared in seconds.  If you like chocolate, you must get the volcano.  The menu says it needs to be ordered in advance.  Definitely ask about it.  We are glad we got lucky and got one even though we didn't ask in advance.
We came here for the foie gras but definitely want to come back to try so many of their other menu items.  It's a beautiful little neighborhood restaurant with super friendly service.  The prices were more than reasonable.  If you are driving to this location, allow for extra time as parking can be a bit difficult.
author: Roy C.

description: Bistro Central Parc is a treasure. Warm, lovely atmosphere, outdoor seating for sunny days, and an absolutely impeccable menu for both dinner and brunch. It's a little gem that I would love to keep secret, but I they are too good not to write about. Their eggs benedict is out of this world, and their lobster risotto is unreal. Not to mention, their wine list is excellent and very reasonably priced. This is wonderful place, owned by wonderful people. If you haven't been, I highly recommend you stop by.
author: Brodie J.

description:
This is a cozy and delicious restaurant. I took the boyfriend's parents here (when I was turned off by Zazie's snooty host). I called for a reservation, and the host couldn't have been nicer. He didn't have the time that I wanted, but got me in as soon as he could. He seemed to know who I was when I arrived at the door, and welcomed all of us enthusiastically. 
The service was on point, without being pretentious. I appreciate that in a pricey restaurant like this one. Everyone was friendly, and down to earth.
The food was amazing. Everyone in our party was happy. I was proud to have picked the place out, as i was trying to impress the BF's parents. They were certainly impressed! Mission accomplished!
author: Jeannette F.

description: There are other French restaurants in San Francisco, and some that are even better at the "restaurant" part.  But, I don't think a single one does the "french" part better.  From the staff, to the menu selection, to the quality and authenticity of the food.  This bistro couldn't be more French if it was smack dab in the middle of the Marais.  For a truly authentic french dining experience, it can't be beat.  I can personally recommend the canard (both confit and magret) and the galette.  Tout était fantastique!
author: Gardner L.

description: Overall very good, fresh ingredients, owner very friendly. Service was good, but not great. The scallop risotto was nicely made but the risotto noodles/rice were a little bland- not great flavor, thick and sticky, scallops were awesome though. Steak and frites quite good. Parking can be brutal, can be noisy. Get there earlier for better experience.
author: Rice C.

description:
Who says there's no such thing as 5 stars? If they deserve it, they deserve it.

I've been here both in the morning and at night. The brunch is amazing! Excellent eggs benedit. Way better than Zazie's in my opinion and the grand prize = No wait. Yes, go back and re-read that line dear San Franciscans. Swallow it whole if you must. NO. LINE.

For dinner, I've had their corned hen and steak. Both are amazing but I'm all about appetizers and dessert. I highly recommentd their potato pancakes, poached egg on frisee salad and tarte tatin. We had a really good bottle of red wine too but unfortunately I can't remember what it was. Sorry. 5 points from me.

The best part of it all is that I live a block away. Ah convenience, how I love thee.
author: Jacinta H.

description: The food was extremely tasty, the service was great, and the ambience was very romantic. I recommend this place to anyone!
author: Robert F.

description: This is a cute little place nestled in a very residential neighborhood. If you aren't paying attention, you won't be able to find this place. The owner and staff were extremely nice, and were very accommodating even though my party was about half an hour late. I ordered the famous risotto with lobster sauce and scallops. It was really good and perfectly done. I also ordered the escargot appetizer but that wasn't as amazing. They were drenched in pesto  & oil so it was a bit nasty going down. I would still give this place a 4 star because of the ambiance, the attentive staff, and the main entree. The place is a bit pricey (but fair) but I have yet to learn about a cheap french restaurant.
author: Jenny C.

description: I have to agree with anyone that says this place is on point! Lets put it this way, the wine was reasonably priced and delicious. The french onion soup was well flavored and covered in melted cheese, the steak was the perfectly portioned and the peppercorn sauce was the best thing that could have complemented it. On top of the amazing food the atmosphere is cozy but not cramped and the service was right on point! its definitely on the nicer side so grab a date or a small dinner party and swing on by- you will love it!
author: Shanna T.

description:
Best restaurant in the area, and an excellent alternative to the (in my opinion) over-hyped, crowded NOPA. 

We ordered the steak frites and the polenta with ratatouile. Both were delicious, but my husband thought the vegetarian dish could have been more substantial. 

Profiteroles for dessert were great, although I will definitely be back to try the others. 

Excellent service and cozy, understated atmosphere. Generally psyched to have this place nearby. What a treat!
author: Irene P.

description:
Update:  Increasing to three stars as I got a polite explanation from the owner that the addition of the fries to the bill was mistake (I also got  a less pleasant reply from a server/manager which I'm choosing to ignore)

Chose Bistro Central Parc for a Sunday date night as the reviews raved about this place.

Food was good solid French bistro food. I would have given them 3 or 4 stars but the evening ended on a sour note. An order of fries was brought to our table by mistake instead of the table next to us - since we hadn't memorized the menu we assumed it came with one of our dishes. After we had started eating the waiter pointed out that it was brought to us by mistake and we offered to 'return' it. When we got the bill the fries that we hadn't ordered were on our bill - that's just poor form.
author: Sancho P.

description: A hidden gem. A charming and affordable French Bistro in the heart of the Pan handle. I love this place. The food was terrific and the ambiance is just lovely.
author: Catherine B.

description:
My boyfriend decided to bring me here as my surprise birthday dinner. We actually arrived right on time for our reservation at 730. Got seated right away, and I already was doing my homework on yelp on what I should ordered. 

So, we ordered the mussels with curry sauce and I got the soup of the day (carrot and ginger soup). Quite impressive. I am not even a carrot type of person, and I LOVE LOVE LOVE the soup. Carrot and ginger go so well together. 

For entrees, I decided the risotto with scallops and lobster sauce and my boyfriend ordered the duck confit. I thought the duck was OK, maybe I'm not really a duck fan. But my risotto was pretty flavorful. Sadly, I was already a bit full from my starters. SO, I had to pack it to go. 

The staff + boss? was extremely friendly. I got quite surprised when they dimmed the lights in the whole restaurant just to sing happy birthday. A bit embarrassed as well, but I think it was quite an experience. Felt a bit special when most of the people in the restaurant starts singing to me as well.
author: Willa L.

description:
This was our best meal of the trip to Northern California. The food was mind blowing and so reasonably priced. Service was very personable even though they were fully booked. The escargot with green onions, the mussels with curry, the lamb chops, the pork, the foie gras topped steak, and the beef bourguignon were life changing. 

Actually, this was one of the best meals I've ever had.
author: N C.

description: Great place with simple and clean atmosphere. Food was great. Everyone in our group of five really enjoyed their food. My dad even said that he had the best tasting lamb chops. Would return again. It was also very well priced for the quality and taste of food.
author: Sergey M.

description: I made reservations for a date here hoping it would live up to it's reviews. It definitely does! I came in 20 minutes late for it (Parking around here is difficult!) and they still happily sat me down. The staff and service here is top notch. As for food, we ordered the filet mignon and it came out perfect. Very happy with my experience here. =]
author: Anthony T.

description: One gray Saturday morning I brought my gentleman friend to Bistro Central Parc. We loved the ambiance and food. He had the eggs benedict and I had the french toast. Both were sublime. I look forward to going back!
author: Michelle L.

description: Cozy, romantic, delicious, friendly, and classic. At the top of our list for Sunday brunch outside with el puppy, intimate birthday celebrations, date nights, and family dinners. Also a sure-fire way to turn bad days around. The owners are lovely, the chef is handsome and French, and everything on the menu is spectacular. I am in love with Bistro Central Parc.
author: Kacie H.

description: Everything is delicious.  Consistent neighborhood spot.  Casual and comfortable.  Have the mussels.
author: Clarke H.

description: We happened in here on a sunny Sunday morning after crawling around looking for some brunch to eat. We walked out of a few places not feeling standing in lines with everyone else having the same bad idea we had of trying to find a breakfast joint on a Sunday. So on our way back home we gave Bistro Central Parc a try. Bam, parking spot out front, menus and a table when we walked in. It only got better from there when we were served a great brunch and mimosas. Tucked away neighborhood winner.
author: William R.

description:
A lovely neighborhood bistro, BCP does not try to be anything besides a bistro. We went today for brunch, and through the time we left at 11am, several tables remained available. That is a major plus in my book, as the usual breakfast suspects would undoubtedly equate to a multi-minute wait.

The eggs benedict (with side salad and delicious potatoes) and the croque madame exhibited precision in their preparation. Their flavors matched what you would expect, too. Price point is fair - roughly $10 per entree. Overall, I wouldn't journey across city limits to set up a brunch here, but the tasty food and seating availability are great draws for local residents.
author: Randy M.

description:
Again, Yelpers have saved me from my predictable boring dining ritual (eating at the same great restaurants). It's time to branch out but how do you choose? This hidden gem of a restaurant sits quietly in what I've always considered a residential area at the corner of Grove and Central.

The menu looked great and although this place is small, the food certainly speaks volumes! It's French all the way, and from what I could tell, all the servers were French too, which comes in handy when you want to know the pronunciation of items on the menu.

We decided to order mostly from the specials of the day.
 
The Terrine De Foie Gras was excellent. Perfect presentation and amazing flavors and the suggested Loupiac wine was absolutely dead on. 

The Escargots had a nice garlic flavor and were very good, nicely done.

The Eggplant Lasagne and Chicken Tajine were both good dishes.

This was a very satisfying dining experience and the chef knows what he's doing. We are definitely adding this to usual places to eat.
We were so full, there was no room for dessert! So next time, I vote DESSERT FIRST!
author: Hieu D.

description:
I had a great dining experience here... Mostly because of the food!! 

We did have to wait a bit for our table even though I had made a reservation, although there really is no waiting space in this small restaurant, we were all cramped by the door. Good thing is we sipped some great French wine while we waited .
